Ottawa, February 2, 1926.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 24th January, with enclosures, I beg to say that Mr. Gordon, Indian Agent, Norway House, should be given to understand that the plumbing supplies left at his Agency by Messrs. Paulin & Swayze, of Regina, should be returned to them as the Department does not propose to pay for them. The account submitted in this connection from the plumbers is re-enclosed herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Brandon Industrial School,
February 9th, 1926.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

The Department will be aware that we have to make all the bread at the Norway House Boarding School and bake it in a kitchen range with only two ovens. This has been a great task on the lady in charge of the kitchen as well as too heavy labor upon the girls.

Would the Department meet the expense of the following for this school?

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Bread Mixer           | $175.00|
| Portable Oven and Pans| 150.00 |
| Small Engine          | 127.00 |

Total: $452.00

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

I have your letter of the 9th instant, relative to the supplying of a bread mixer, a portable bake oven and a small engine for the use of the Norway House Indian Residential School.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTION OF MR. WM. GORDON,
INDIAN AGENT, ON THE NORWAY HOUSE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
DATED FEBRUARY 22nd, 1926.

The general tone of the institution is good. The building is clean and well kept, but is beginning to require considerable repairs. Despite the drain put in last summer, the north wall still heaves with the frost, cracking the walls of the building.

The new carpenter shop is a great convenience, as is also the root house. There has been no frost in the roothouse to date, but a small fire has been kept going almost constantly all winter.

The chicken house is very satisfactory, and the hens are giving a good return if capital cost is not considered. The stable is very satisfactory, with the exception of the ventilation, which is insufficient.
Indian Boarding School

Norway House, Man. March 26, 1826

Wm Gordon Esq.,
Indian Agent.

CANADA
Norway House,
April 21st, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to report that a few days ago I was asked by the Principal of the Norway House Residential School to take a look at the north wall of the building. This is the same wall upon which I have been reporting each year for about four years. The Principal stated that he was afraid it would fall down. I have no fear of that at present, but it heaves considerably, opens out the carpenter work at the top of the wall about three inches, and heaves the floor inside, with the stairways, etc., several inches, and is wrecking the building on each floor.

Last summer Rev. T. Ferrier secured from the Commissioner authority to put in a drain from the building to the lake. Mr. Ferrier pointed out to me the need of something being done, with which I fully agreed. I was doubtful if a drain could be made where he decided, but he was certain. The Principal of the school was to put in the drain, and the tile was shipped out. I had no information on the matter. When the ditch was nearly half dug, and a lot of the tile in and the ditch filled, it was found that there was so much rock that it could not be continued, and they were compelled to abandon it.

They then came to me for instructions. I had none. However, I told them that the only way I knew of getting a drain without putting in a long one, was to turn their drain pipes into the old water main, let the water follow this to opposite the septic tank, and then carry it from that point to the point of discharge of the sewers. They turned their pipes into the old waterline, but did not alter the outlet. The outlet is now into a box near the lake at the intake, and on the same side, where the discharge filters out through sand and sawdust with which the box is filled, and into the lake. The doctor objects, and so do I, to this arrangement, as this line is broken, and passes under a couple of old sewer lines, where the soil is likely to be contaminated, and the water is likely also to be contaminated. It is not so objectionable in winter, but I think it should be changed this season.

The drain appears to be working well. It keeps the floor of the laundry and the boiler pits dry, where trouble has always been experienced. However, it does not appear to help the wall any. Whether it would another year,

The Indian Commissioner,

Indian Office,
Regina.
I do not know, but I would be doubtful of its being of sufficient benefit to make some other protection of the wall necessary.

My previous suggestion for this wall was the addition of ten or fifteen feet to the kitchen on the North west corner of the building, and to put the foundation well below frost line, and down to the rock if possible. This would care for the North west side. For the North East I suggested a root house, which was required, built on the north of this wall, and the foundations well down as with the other extension. This could have opened into the room of the basement where the water tank is located. Last summer the roothouse was built in another place, so this cannot now be done.

May I say, that the outlet of the ditch should without fail be changed this summer, and also something should be done to protect this wall.

If a septic system is installed at the hospital this summer, as recommended and estimated for, one ditch and one pipeline might be arranged to carry both the outlet from the septic tank, and the diversion from this old line.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Wm. Gordon,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 22, 1926.

Sir:

Pursuant to your conversation when in the Department today, you are authorized to make whatever arrangements are advisable in connection with the undermentioned repairs and replacements at the Norway House Indian Residential School. The appropriation for the purpose is $3,000 and the Department has already made a $400 grant towards the cost of a boat. If the work cannot be satisfactorily completed for the sum of $2,600, you might let me have an interim report and recommendation.

1. Jacking up and putting in suitable footings where necessary for the main building.

2. Making suitable arrangements for the disposal of seepage water. In this connection I wish to refer you to the rough drawing which is enclosed and to official letter of the 19th ultimo, which authorized an expenditure of $400 for the hospital septic tank and outlet. It may be possible to use the hospital drain in connection with the disposal from the school. This is Mr. Indian Agent Gordon's suggestion. Please see the last paragraph of his letter to you of April 21st, last.

3. The Principal has stated that the generator for the electric plant is beyond repair and should be replaced this year.

4. It is stated that the steam piping should be overhauled with a view to making minor replacements. Rev. T. Ferrier, of Brandon, has promised to send to you information regarding the size of pipe at present in the school, so that a supply can go up with the plumber.

5. The conductors from the eaves of the main building were never completed and it is the water from the roof that has caused some of the difficulty with the foundation. These conductors should be completed.

6. Three hundred lineal feet of 2" planking, 12" wide, for horse stall floors, and four hundred feet of shiplap for lining the cold storage room.

You will remember that you suggested it would be advisable to send with the man who is to supervise the work at least one expert labourer with the materials that would be necessary to carry on.

In the purchase of materials and engagement of labour, please be guided by the instructions in the Deputy Superintendent General's No. 1-1-5 of the 14th instant. The Department will leave this matter entirely in your hands and will ask you to do only that work that is necessary.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Mr. Paget;-

With reference to vouchers Nos. 3509 and 3510, I beg to inform you that these vouchers are correct, and they each represent separate shipments and are not duplicates.

One shipment was made on the 2nd Sept., 1926, and the other on the 9th September.

I am enclosing a wireless from Mr Agent William Gordon, date the 8th September, 1926, and when I received this I immediately phoned the order for the second 50 sacks.

Please return the wireless, I have detached it from my vouchers.

I have been away from my office since the morning of Friday the 9th instant until last evening, I was busy issuing Hay Permits on the St. Peter's Hay Lands, and this entails a lot of driving and walking over the area. This absence will account for delay in this reply.

Note the 100 sacks mentioned in the wireless message went forward in two lots of 50 sacks each.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Mr. W. M. Graham,
Commissioner for Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

This is my report on the condition of the school foundations, and basement walls. The seepage water I can deal with at smaller cost and in a satisfactory manner, by making a seepage well and putting a small pump on it.

I am taking care of all the water from the eaves by running the conductor pipes out as they should have been run in the first case. To deal with the old pipe line for seepage would mean opening this line right to the Lake, as it is choked at many places.

On two sides of the building, large sections of concrete pavement were laid, but for 3 or 4 feet from the walls this was either left out or broken out. The water has washed the earth into holes, and a lot of water gets down into the footings at these places. I propose to lay this concrete.

I believe the method I am adopting is the cheapest and most satisfactory. The foundation walls have perished completely. The cause is poor concrete. These walls are full of building rubbish - pieces of wood, and every kind of dirt. All the spacing pieces between the forms were left in, and with the effect of weather they have broken up the walls. I am trying to get buttresses against some of the worst places. There is no reinforcement in the walls, and the worst possible mixture was used - it is more like a poor sand mortar than good concrete, with the result that the walls are shattered in all directions.

I am going ahead with the septic tank. The sewer line has been laid - it remains to test the flow. I have given a list of material required to Mr. Gordon who is sending it in.

I found that to wire you would cost 10¢ per word for the first stage by wireless, and the message would be a long one.

The lighting plant at the school is not a Delco. There is no name on the generator, and I am told it was either second or third hand when purchased. I am enclosing a note Mr. Blackford has handed me re the lighting plant.

Mr. Gordon has not yet received the check to pay for the labour here.

There are a lot of different makes and sizes of radiators and piping through the school. Repairing this heating plant will require the services of a plumber and steamfitter.

I am going ahead with the work at the school, and the septic tank at the hospital. The pipe and fittings arrived yesterday. I will have to send an order for more material for forms for the septic tank, etc.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) J. Mayoh.

Sir:

In accordance with your request of Aug. 13 I made an inspection of the lighting plant at the Indian Boarding School at this place, & beg leave to report as follows.

Inspection

(A) The Generator

This machine is an obsolete type & insufficient capacity for the job. It is now necessary to charge on two banks in parallel, & the voltage is too low to operate the lamps while this is being done. The rated voltage of this generator is fifty volts. This is only sufficient to charge a 32 volt battery. The total output of the plant is in the neighborhood of 1600 watts. The total possible load is about 6000 watts, the average load being about 3000 watts.

The bearings of this generator are worn out. The shaft is also badly worn.

PLEASE USE BOTH SIDES.
an attempt has been made to adjust these bearings, by sawing the bronze bushings & using shims to take up the play. This has not been entirely successful and there is considerable play and vibration at the present time.

(3) The wiring — the wiring in this building is in a dangerous condition. It was probably not too well done in the beginning and many alterations have been made since. There are many uncovered joints, some of them dangerously close to the metal ceilings. Numbers of these joints are not even protected with tape.

(4) General — the voltage of this plant is fifty seven. This is unusual and inconvenient. The supplies are not of a standard type for this country, in many cases, have to be ordered specially.

For example, the lamps are made in England, and are not ordinarily procurable in Winnipeg. The Hospital, an Indian Dept. building stands 400 feet off, and neither current...
over supplies are interchangeable.

(A) Recommendations

The Generator — This generator is, in my opinion, not worth the cost of repair or the freight to get it from Winnipeg. It cannot be repaired on the spot. It would be hardly practicable to leave the school without lights during the two or three weeks when it would be away for repair. If repaired it would still be of insufficient capacity.

I recommend the installation of a 3 K.W. 110 Volt direct current generator, to be operated by the engine now in use, which is new & good.

(B) The Wiring

I recommend that a qualified electrician be employed to put the wiring throughout the building in a safe & satisfactory condition. This could be done by the man who installs the generator.
a suitable switchboard would be required, as the present one would not be satisfactory for the 110 volt current.

(c) Battery - The present battery has a probable life of from two to three years. It is of 28 cells, furnishing 5.6 volts. To bring the volts to the required 110 volts it will be necessary to add 28 cells of the same capacity as those already in use, 160 amperes hour.

(d) General

In my opinion the school and the hospital should be on a position to furnish current to each other, in the event of the plant at either building being temporarily out of commission. This would only mean the connection of the two buildings by a suitable line and a double pole double throw switch at each end of the line.

It strikes me that the ultimate solution of the power problem at this place will be a central plant which will furnish lights to all the Indian Depot buildings on this point and pump the water as well.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith the copy of a letter that I received this p.m. from Mr. J.T. Blackford the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Norway House, operated under the auspices of the (Methodist formerly) now the United Church of Canada.

This letter has reference to the present condition of lighting plant of this school. This plant is evidently in a very unsatisfactory condition.

I told Mr. Blackford that I would submit a copy of his letter to you with the least possible delay.

The season of navigation closes usually on or about the 10th October, and after that date any communication with Norway House, as to the delivery of freight, is closed until the 1st June the following spring, except at greatly advanced cost for freight charges via The Pas and to Mile 137 on the Hudson's Bay railway, thence by dog train about 120 miles to Norway House.

The condition of the plant indicates unreliability, and if the plant is not replaced, fixing it seems to be out of a possibility, a break down might be reasonably expected during the coming winter. Some provision to meet the situation for furnishing some means of lighting should be arranged. Coal Oil and Lamps should be provided if the plant is not put in shape.

Mr. Maynard's report indicates the condition of the plant, and I understand he has given a pretty correct statement, to put the plant in working shape seems to be very doubtful and the expense to do so seems to mean an excessive cost for the value received.

I have indicated as fully as I can the outlook, for your information, so that you can deal with the matter as you deem best in good time. Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

As navigation on Lake Winnipeg closes five weeks from now, I respectfully write to ask what, if anything, has been done towards putting the Norway House Residential School lighting plant in order. Over a year ago the Department of Indian Affairs was advised of the very unsafe, and inadequate, condition of this plant. To-day it is worse. Last winter we had to carry on our work in semi-darkness. There was much distress, and often danger, in consequence. The worry and responsibility this caused was so great that, as Principal, I absolutely refuse to carry it this coming winter.

Might I press for an immediate consideration and answer, as I cannot return to Norway House until assurance is given that provision will be made in time to meet this very imperative need.

I appreciate very much the consideration you have given us in the past.

A copy of this letter is being sent to Rev. T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools in Canada.

Yours very truly,

Sir:-

Last summer I sent Mr. Mayoh up to Norway House to put in shape the drainage and sewage lines in connection with the Boarding School, Hospital and Doctor's residence, and to install a Septic tank in the hospital. Since his return Mr. Mayoh has reported that the heating system and hot water service in the Boarding School is in very bad shape and requires a thorough overhauling and certain replacements.

In forwarding the Estimates for the Norway House Agency on October 26th., I stated in my covering letter with regard to an item of $10,000 for an addition to the School that I was not sure that this work should be proceeded with, as I had had no report as to the necessity for making this change. I beg to say that since writing that letter I have learned that this building, which is to provide additional kitchen and dining room space, is necessary, and it will serve as a protection to the foundation which has caused us so much trouble in the past. I believe that it will not cost anything like $10,000 to do the work, but I would strongly recommend that this amount be left in the Estimates, as the difference will be required to put the heating system in shape, which should be attended to next summer without fail. I would be glad to have word from you at an early date, stating that this has been allowed, so that preparations can be made the first thing in the Spring to have the work undertaken.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

With reference to my Estimates for the Norway House Indian Residential School for this Fiscal year, may I say that the most pressing work to be done is the painting of the building.

The Department's architect can figure from the plans of this building the exact surfaces to be covered, in case the work were let by contract. I am of opinion that the following quantities of paint would be required. I am giving colors as agreed on between the Principal and myself, and these colors are very nearly the colors now on the building, which would thus require the minimum of paint, two coats:

- 40 gals "Blind Green"
- 8 " Buff
- 10 " Green cement paint, nearly same shade as above
- 25 " Brown roof stain
- 20 gals. Raw Linseed oil
- 8 " Turpentine

A carpenter would be required to go over the building to replace siding boards, etc., would probably require four days' work.

About 400 ft. of clear 8" shiplap would also be required for replacement. This is what was put on originally for siding.

While, with the instruction of a good painter, the boys of the school could do some of the work, provided the work were done in June when the boys are at the school, yet there is so much trimming and sash work to do, and the amount of scaffold work would be so large, that the safest, and probably the most economical way to get the work done would be by contract.

I would strongly recommend that this work be done this season, and as early as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Wm Gordon
Indian Agent.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge your letter, number and date as marginally noted above.

In reply I offer the following in explanation.

On the 30th Sept., 1926, I received the following radiogram from Mr Agent Gordon at Norway House:-

"Duplicate shipment of battery for school.
"School assumes responsibility.
"Writing.
"Bulbs."

This came to hand at 5 p.m. on the 30th Sept., 1926.

Prompt action made it possible to get the last boat of the season, by the radiogram.

I was asked to duplicate a 28-cell battery, covered by Vchr #3834, and which I had shipped by instruction of Commissioner W.M. Graham, for the Indian Residential School at Norway House; this shipment completed a 56-cell new battery, and from what I knew of the conditions I knew that the second 28-cells were required to make a good job.

I had no authority from any source, however as the school assumed the responsibility, knowing that the time to act was limited and the necessity for this unit urgent, I acted and took steps to ship the second 28 cells and received them in due course at the school and the result has been that good service from the school lighting plant has resulted.

As the School had assumed the payment, I left that part with them, what I did was help them out of a corner.

I found that the amount was not paid on the 10th March, so I radiographed Mr Agent Gordon as follows:-

"Have Blackford remit Two hundred and 23/100 dollars for duplicate shipment battery."

I had reply to this dated 11th March, 1927:-

"Blackford forwarding cheque for battery to you next mail."

On the 29th March I received the promised cheque from Mr. J.T. Blackford. I telephoned the Globelite people and I handed them the...
the cheque and two receipts in triplicate from them, these I expected to send to Mr. Blackford after the opening of navigation, so I am able to send them to you now to back up this explanation. Date of receipt is 30th March, 1927.

On the 1st April I received your letter of the 29th Mar., 1927, I was very busy and held over a reply, which probably was a mistake. Now I submit a voucher in favor of Mr. J.T. Blackford for the amount he has paid, and if the cheque comes to me I will deposit it to his credit and thus square him up, all this is subject to your approval.

Sir:

With reference to the matter of re-painting the exterior of the Norway House School, I have had some difficulty in trying to get this work done in an economical way. To send an expert painter from Winnipeg and pay him for his time going and coming and then the standard wage for doing the work would make the cost very great. I took the matter up with Mr. Indian Agent Gordon and asked if he knew of anyone at Norway House who could do the work and he advises me that Mr. Blackford, the Principal, agrees that the school will undertake the work, provided the Department will pay for the labour involved, and also pay a member of the staff to supervise the work. Is it the Department's intention that we should pay members of staff extra for doing work of this kind? In the meantime as the season is getting short I have wired Mr. Blackford to proceed with the work, but stated that I did not consider it should be necessary to pay a member of the staff to supervise the work.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham

Sir:

I beg to inform you that I have just received a report from Mr. J. E. Yates, of Yates, Neal & Co., Sanitary & Heating Engineers, Brandon, whom I sent to Norway House to look into the whole matter of repairs that are required to the plumbing and heating system at the Norway House Indian Boarding School, and according to his report there is a great deal to be done and I have instructed him to proceed to Norway House, taking with him the necessary material, and put the plumbing and heating system in good order.

Mr. Yates reports that additional radiation will have to be supplied throughout the building and some work in connection with changing the radiators from one location to another will have to be carried out. He also reports that the siding on the school is in bad shape and that it is impossible to heat the building properly on that account. I am sending a supply of siding forward by the first boat and making arrangements to have the whole building re-sided.

When the work of overhauling the plumbing is completed, and the building has been re-sided I think the Norway House School can be considered to be in good shape.

Your obedient servant,

REPORT OF WORK DONE AT NORWAY HOUSE SCHOOL.

Mr. W. H. Graham,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir,

Acting on orders I received from you August 9th 1927, I proceeded to Norway House with men, material and tools, to carry out needed repairs to School Building there.

Our staff was supplemented with all the suitable local labor obtainable.

BOILERS:

The front head on No. 1 Boiler, which was badly corroded, was taken out and replaced with a new one. A complete new set of flues was also put in this boiler.

No. 1 boiler is now as good as new.

No. 2 boiler has also been put in good condition, being provided with new hand holes, and given a good cleaning.

WATER COLUMNS:

On both boilers were set at the proper level, connections made with the boiler head and tees provided for cleaning, fitted with brass plugs.

SUSPENSION OF BOILERS:

The brick work had settled, and the boilers were practically hanging on the steam connections. It was necessary that boilers be suspended. This was done by using steel rails, extending from inside concrete wall, to outside concrete wall. 7/8 steel rods were run under the boiler lugs and up through heavy places over the steel rails. Both boilers are thus suspended independently of the brickwork.
BOILER CASTINGS:

New angle and T bars were provided for the back end and the front; fire arches raised and reset. New grates were put in where needed.

BOILER BRICK WORK:

Brick work removed for boiler repairs was replaced and new firebrick linings and bridge walls installed.

BLOW OFFS:

New blow off cocks were put in and blow off pipes were run to drain separately and pipe ends left visible over catch basin.

FEED VALVES:

Boiler feed valves were extended from back to front of boilers.

INSPECTION & PROTECTION:

These boilers now conform to the law. We were fortunate in procuring the services of an ex-provincial boiler inspector to do the boiler work.

VENTILATION:

The ventilation was completely gone over, and where foul air vents were found at the ceiling these were extended to near the floor.

The main vent in attic was tightened up, and covered in the attic, and both fresh air intake and foul air outlet were provided with dampers.

NEW RADIATION:

An additional 709 square feet of new radiation in twelve radiators was installed at points that previously had been cold, chiefly at entrances and in dormitories and sewing room.

STEAM PIPING:

Where new radiators were installed, and at other places where additional radiators had been installed, the steam mains were cut and proper sized Tees put in with flanges and connections made to radiators with a good seam.
in size. Mains were properly graded, and, where necessary, radiator connections were shortened or lengthened as required.

**Radiator Repairs:**

All defective radiator valves were replaced and all valves and flanges packed.

New nipples were fitted in all radiators of the push nipple type, and new gaskets were put in radiators of the screw nipple type.

Floors were repaired under radiators that had rotted, due to leaking radiator nipples.

**Basement Radiators:**

All basement ceiling radiators were lowered from 12 to 15 inches, and six extra radiators installed, two being brought down from the attic, the others being salvaged from the old entrance radiators.

**Air Valves:**

New automatic air valves were put in where old ones were found defective, and each radiator was fitted with an additional air valve of the Hot Water type, to be used if the automatic for any reason refused to operate.

New Trane quick opening air vents were installed on the end of each steam main.

**Hot Water Tank:**

The hot water tank was raised thirty inches and fitted with new supports.

The steam supply increased and raised, and a new steam coil fitted inside and the tank cleaned. The condensed water will now return to the boilers.

**Jacket Heater:**

A No. 908 Gurney Cottage Heater was installed to heat water during the summer.

**Power Pump:**

A complete set of new valves, seats and packing were put in the Gardner twin water pump. New linings and a...
GAS ENGINES:
Repairs and spare parts were supplied for the gasoline engine as well as what belting had worn out.

GAS ENGINE EXHAUST:
The exhaust from gasoline engine was taken out of the laundry chimney, where it had blown out the centre division of chimney, and run to cement pit outside and vented to the roof. Thus exhaust is now silent.

BAKERY:
The pressure tank, after being cleaned, was moved to the opposite side of tank room. The space thus provided was partitioned off and made a much needed baking room, well ventilated and outside of the laundry.

LAUNDRY STOVE:
Being unable to buy a suitable new laundry stove, the old one was repaired, and the brick wall built back of it to protect the wall from fire.

MISCELLANEOUS:
A steam trap was provided for the laundry dryer. The heating in root house was repaired and put in good condition. Tools and material were left so that the resident mechanic could do emergency repairs.

AIR COMPRESSOR:
A new air compressor was installed and connected to the pressure tank. It was found impossible to maintain any safe degree of fire protection without it.

FIRE LINE:
The fire line was overhauled, new washers put on valves, nozzles and hose provided where needed.

DRAINAGE:
The rain water from the whole building is now taken away from the building entirely over the surface of the ground, open cement conductors being provided for the removal of water from the building.
The cement cistern in yard having cracked and become useless, was abandoned, as a cistern, but the pump suction pipe, was connected to new Sump pump, which allows of it being pumped out, and it acts to gather the surface water.

A new Sump Pump was installed in lower back hall connected to Sump Pit, in boiler room pit; this, together with the Sump already provided at front of building and the old cistern, will allow the whole building foundations to be drained.

As the entrances are now properly heated and the foundation drained, no further heaving of walls should occur from this cause.

WATER PIPE:

The cold and hot water pipes were repaired wherever found defective, new valves and taps installed where necessary.

DRINKING FOUNTAINS:

Drinking fountains were provided in boys and girls play rooms.

LAVATORIES:

A lavatory with two closets was reconstructed off the boys play room, and a one closet lavatory provided off the laundry for the girls.

New closets and flush tanks were put in throughout the building where needed and the others repaired wherever possible.

Cleanouts were put in drain in laundry and also at other points to make all drains as accessible as possible.

KITCHEN SINK:

A galvanized steel wash sink was installed in the kitchen, fitted with a grease trap. Considerable drain trouble had developed for the lack of this trap.

KITCHEN RANGE:

New fire brick linings and new dampers were put in
BARN SUPPLY:

The water supply to the barn was dug up and repaired where it leaves the main building, and a weeping drain was put in from this point to boiler room sump pit.

SEPTIC TANK:

The Septic Tank was thoroughly cleaned out, more than six wagon loads of sludge and scum were removed and buried.

A manhole of proper dimensions had to be constructed to do this.

No pipes or septic tank fittings of any kind were found in this tank.

A clear way was open for scum to flow direct into the outlet which had given serious trouble in the past. This was remedied by installing the proper pipes and fittings. No syphon, however, was or could be installed.

CEMENT WORK:

A new cement floor was laid in boys playroom and lavatory adjoining.

A new floor was laid in boiler room and a cement sump pit constructed.

Boiler pit was widened and a railing put up.

Cracks in all concrete walls were filled with cement.

New manhole constructed in septic tank.

The gravel for the cement work had to be hauled a long distance due to high water.

STAIRS:

Where frost and dampness had heaved the stairs and floors in the three entrances, new cement floors were put down and stairways levelled and repaired.

In removing the old boiler room floor, a bad horizontal crack was unearthed in the wall. This was filled and supported with concrete. A weeping drain was laid from this wall to the new sump pit.

SIDING AND STRAPPING:
solidly, then double papered, vertically and horizontally strapped and siding securely nailed on. Wherever siding or paper had been omitted paper and boarding was provided, cold spots were closed up wherever found. Under front veranda where the ends of joists were exposed, double paper and timber was nailed in and the siding and paper extended down over.

**DOOR FRAMES:**

All door framed, except front door, were taken out and replaced with frames made of 3 x 12, loose space behind door frames were filled up and made solid and frost proof. Doors were hung with heavy garage door hinges, heavy latches and self closing springs.

**WINDOWS:**

The worst of the windows were stripped and made as tight as possible; but these windows are still a source of much cold.

**FUEL ROOM:**

A new bulkhead and door were provided for the fuel room, a frame put in and a door made at the foot of outside stairs to boiler room. Lack of this had caused undue freezeups in the boiler room in the past.

**EAVESTROUGHING:**

A new eavestrough with five conductor pipes was put as far around the building as the scaffold was erected; but owing to unfavorable weather, which delayed all outside work, our men were unable to get this all completed before the freeze-up and the leaving of the last boat. We regret this very much, as had the weather been so that the carpenters could have even put up the balance of scaffold we would easily have finished. What was usable of the old eavestrough from the building was put up on the carpenter shop.

**PAINTING:**

No painting was done, all men available being employed.
CASINGS:

Some casings and corner boards are still to be put on.

All of which I have the honour to respectfully submit.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

When in the Department Offices this week the question of the method of constructing the new home for the Principal at Norway House was discussed.

Yours sincerely,

With reference to the building of the residence for the Principal at Norway House Indian Residential school, I understand from Mr. Blackford that the material has been ordered, with the exception of the heating and lighting plants, and the interior plumbing fixtures.

I would recommend that plans be made for each of these systems, and a copy forwarded here, also one to Mr. Inspector J.R. Bunn, and that Mr. Bunn purchase, at as early a date as possible, the necessary fixtures and material, and ship them. Some of the work on these plants should be done before the interior lumber is put on the walls.

I presume that the heating plant will be hot air. Should this be the case, I would recommend a wood furnace, and we have found the Pease "Economy" No. 21 very satisfactory.

The electric plant with which the house will be connected is in the school, and is 110 volt. Four hundred feet of outside wire will be required, besides the interior wiring.

For the water system, besides the interior fittings, 200 ft. of 1" galvanized water pipe will be required.

If Mr. Inspector Bunn is supplied with plans, he can easily secure lists of the material required for the plants, and we can get the work done here.

Gentlemen:

I have to request that you will forward, shipping charges prepaid, addressed to Mr. J. T. Blackford, Principal, Indian Residential School, Norway House, Man., c/o Northern Fish Company, Selkirk, 6 - 5 gallon pump tanks, complete with non-freeze charges.

Ottawa, September 8th, 1928.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, recommending the supplying of 10 fire extinguishers for the Norway House Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that it is considered 6 extinguishers should be sufficient, and an order is, therefore, being placed with the Pyrene Mfg. Company of Canada Ltd., Toronto, Ont., for 6 - 5 gallon pump tanks, complete with non-freeze charges.

This firm have been requested to prepay transportation costs and to forward their account, in duplicate, to Mr. Blackford. When the extinguishers arrive, Mr. Blackford should certify the account and forward it to you, so that you can attach it to a proper voucher form and send it to the Department for payment.

You should notify Mr. Blackford to distribute these extinguishers throughout the building at strategic points where they will be readily accessible in case of fire.

The Pyrene Mfg. Company is being instructed to ship these extinguishers c/o of the Northern Fish Company, Selkirk, Man. I am instructing this firm to have the extinguishers reach Selkirk at the earliest possible date, and it is expected that they will arrive before the navigation season closes.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Holman,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. Gordon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Residential School,
Norway House, Manitoba.

Pursuant to our conversation when I was in Ottawa last week in which we discussed the necessity of making special provision for clearing of land on Hope Island where we are trying to carry on gardening and farming operations, - we have been working on this for some years and a grant of $500.00 will be of great assistance in clearing up further acreage; also a grant of $500.00 will be necessary for new eave trough and fixing all window frames in connection with the main building. I would respectfully request that these amounts be provided for in the Estimates to come before the next session of Parliament.

Your favourable consideration to this will be appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Toronto,
Dec. 11,
1928.

Dear Dr. Scott: Re: Norway House Indian Residential School,

Manitoba.

Pursuant to the conversation we had when I was in your office on Friday last, I now draw your attention to the need of an addition being constructed to the Norway House Boarding School.

I hope to be out to Norway House sometime this summer and will look into what is really required and prepare a sketch of what we think will suit. I may say that the junior class room is held in a small frame building situated on the boarding school property. This building is simply a poor frame structure and not large enough for what we require and accommodation for a class room will be included in the plans that we submit for this addition.

We are not expecting any provision to be made for this in the estimates to be placed before the coming session of Parliament but if it meets with your approval I shall be pleased to submit a pencil sketch to your architect and he can figure out the probable cost. I may say that this request has been strongly endorsed by the Lake Winnipeg Presbytery at its meeting in May last and as the Principal has a waiting list of prospective pupils I am of the opinion that the time has come when some extra accommodation should be provided.

Yours very sincerely,

T. Ferrier

I wish also to acknowledge your letters concerning improvements required at the other Indian residential schools under the auspices of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church. Consideration is being given as our Estimates for the coming fiscal year are being prepared.

January, 9th, 1929.

File 14B.

Dear Mr. Bunn:

We have a "Flu" epidemic, very mild, but meaning plenty of work just the same, as almost every house has it, and there is a heavy call for medicines etc.

You will have my wireless for Aspirin etc., There are no deaths yet which could be called "Flu", but three, which were likely hastened a bit by it, being old T.B. cases.

They have had a bad time at the school, as there were about 80 pupils in bed, and several of the staff. Then the sewers were choked. You know how rags etc. will get in. Then the engine, which pumps the water and runs the generator and other machinery, quit. It has been running for about 5 years I think, on an average of 4 hours per day, so that the cylinder is badly worn and would not hold compression. They (the shibil) are putting the other in for the time being, however they have a lot of wood to cut, heavy poles and the work is too heavy for our engines.

I think they should have a new engine. This would be an International 10 h.p. capacity, and gives about the necessary power.

If one was sent to Mile 137, Wabowden on the H.B.R'y, they (the school) would bring it in from there. Perhaps you may be able to arrange for a new one.

Your obedient servant,

(signed) Wm. Gordon,

John R. Bunn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Indian Office, Winnipeg.

Sir:

I find on examination, that the springs of the beds in use at the Norway House Indian Residential School are in very bad condition, and beyond repair. These have been in use for many years, and have been repaired time and again, until now they are hopeless. Some beds have had to be discarded, with the result that some of the smaller children are sleeping two in a bed, which I consider objectionable.

The beds are hospital or institution beds, 6 ft. 4 in. long, and 3 ft. wide over all. The springs of course are shorter and narrower than this.

I would recommend that 10 complete new beds be supplied, with springs and mattresses. Also that springs be supplied for 100 beds, either diamond link spring, or non sagging link fabric spring.

The paint for the building was supplied in 1927, but the arrangements for repairs to the building with the Yates people delayed the work of painting, as new siding was being put on. This work has not yet been done. It should be done without delay, as the new siding is getting very dry, and will absorb a great deal of oil. I have always recommended the employment of any experienced painter as foreman on this job, a man who would understand how to get about the building to the best advantage, and there is considerable trimming to do, which is very slow work for inexperienced hands.

As regards the eavetroughing, conductor pipe was not put up, except two at the front. The pipe is on hand. Six joints in the eavetroughing were not soldered. Dear Dr. Scott:

In addition to the information which I forwarded to you a few days ago in connection with the Norway House Residential School, I beg to submit the following extract from a letter from Mr. Jas. T. Blackford, the Principal:

"The Indian Department having plans of the Norway House Residential School and also a first-class Architect in Mr. Orr, I feel that he could best meet our present requirements if the following facts are submitted to the Department:

1. That this institution be enlarged to accommodate 130 pupils.
2. That the boys' dormitories be located in the new part of the building and the girls' dormitories would then be in the front of the present building and separated altogether from the boys' floors.
3. Accommodation should be provided for both children's and staff's dining rooms, kitchen and class rooms on the main floor.
4. That the present dining room and kitchen could then be utilized for other purposes as the Architect could determine.

Sir:

With reference to attached Voucher No. 963, I trust this will meet with the approval of the Department.

In explanation, may I say that the man John Wallenius was at Norway House doing some painting for the Royal Canadian Air Force, and did good work and worked fast as well. Someone had mentioned to him that the school might be painted this summer, and he came to me after I had written to the Department and asked for the job, at regular painters wages which I understood were 20¢ per square yd. for two coats, and 35¢ per square yd. for three coats. I told him that I would let him know if the work was to be done. Immediately on receipt of your letter, I spoke to the Principal, and he stated that there would be no boys available for the work, as it was then into haying and harvest time. Under the circumstances, I considered that the work by the yard would be the most satisfactory, as the men would then be lodging and boarding themselves. I telegraphed to John Wallenius, who was in Port Arthur, and he came as quickly as he could, beginning the work August 16th. He brought a man with him to assist in the work.

The painters repaired several places in the walls where the siding was broken, and claim to have repaired the eavestroughing, but as we have had no rain, we cannot tell if it still leaks. The painting was a hard job, as the roof was very dry and soaked in a great deal of paint. The walls were new siding two years ago, but were in bad shape, having gone so long unpainted. Some of the siding was flat grain, and the grain had opened up, leaving it very rough. The job is reasonably well done, as well as could be expected under the circumstances. I considered it advisable to pay for the work on inside of balconies, and for extra windows by the hour, as some was one, some two, and some three coat work.

I am glad this work has been done, the building is much improved in appearance and will certainly last longer.

The Secretary,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The Medical Officer for the Norway House Indian Residential School has drawn attention to the overcrowded conditions in the dormitories. He states that at the present time the smaller boys and girls are sleeping in dormitories which are too small to provide sufficient air space. He also states that both in the boys' and girls' dormitories the pupils sleep together in single beds.

The Department considers that this condition of affairs should not exist and that children should not be required to sleep together in single beds. If there is not sufficient accommodation in the dormitories to provide a single bed for each pupil the only recourse would be to decrease the enrolment until such time as more accommodation can be provided. I may say that it is hoped next year to provide an addition to this school. I shall be pleased to have a report at your earliest convenience regarding the conditions mentioned by the Medical Officer as to the overcrowding in the dormitories.

Sir:

It would appear that our water levels are not going to rise to any considerable extent this season. We have very low water.

For this reason I would ask authority to extend the crib on the water line some 40 feet farther. Last November we had to extend the pipe, as the water was too shallow where it ended, and the pipe would have frozen early in the winter. We also had to build a fire at the end of the crib, thaw the ground in the crib for some distance, and we then covered all with sawdust, then hay, and the whole line where it ran under the ice, with several feet of reeds. We were then favored with a heavy fall of snow, which covered all to a considerable depth. Flank cribbing will not withstand the heavy seas to which the crib is subjected.

I would ask for an allowance of $150.00 in cash, to pay for getting logs, and for labor constructing crib and filling with sawdust and earth. An extension of 40 feet should end our worries so far as this portion of the line is concerned. This could be charged to the allowance for repairs for the Norway House Residential School.

Ottawa, November 21st, 1930.

Sir,

Dr. Cochrane and the Rev. Mr. Beaton of the Home Mission Board, United Church of Canada, have recently visited the Round Lake and Norway House Indian Residential Schools. They are seriously concerned regarding the danger of fire in these frame buildings and have asked the Department to give favourable consideration to the installation of a fire gong in each school. The Department believes that this request is reasonable and I should be grateful if you would make the necessary arrangements. I consider one gong on a central floor, with buttons on the first and top floors, are sufficient for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:-

With reference to Department No. 123-5-5 of the 21st November last, concerning the suggestion to install a fire gong system at the Norway House Indian Residential School, I have to state that I have just received a letter from Mr. Wm. Gordon, Indian Agent, stating that the school has already a very satisfactory system which is just what is now proposed. It would appear that the members of the Home Mission Board who visited Norway House have been mis-informed.

The Agent does make a comment however on the use of the pole fire escapes on the ground that they are not altogether satisfactory for little children. I have written in reply however, stating that these are now generally installed in all our residential schools, and I visited one recently where the small children slid down the poles as confidently as the older children.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: NORWAY HOUSE:

I notice that you are not planning to ask even
for a small grant for minor repairs in connection with
the Residential School there. My impression of that old
building, after going over it very carefully last year,
is that there should be a small sum of a few hundred
dollars available annually for repairs. It would, for
instance, be vastly improved by a serious attempt to
repaint the walls and furniture in the dining-room and
by a relacquering of most of the beds in the dormitories.
When I was there I discussed with Mr. Gordon the possib-
ility of improving the storm windows by stripping them,
and we had Joe Keeper look over the building in order to
get an estimated idea of how much it would cost. I do
not know whether the stripping has actually been done or
not. As I intimated to you in my conversation, I think
the fire alarm arrangements, with only one song in a
building of that size, are entirely inadequate, and that
steps should be taken immediately to install a system
similar to the one provided in Mount Elgin.
Norway House, "an.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, relative to the request of the Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School to be supplied with 50 single mattresses, 3 feet wide. In this connection I have to request that you will inform the Department as to the length of the beds for which the mattresses are required. I may say that institution beds are usually furnished in 2½ feet widths, and it is considered that mattresses in this width would be satisfactory. When we have information as to the sizes required and the number of each size, consideration will be given to placing the order for supplying same.

Relative to the request for a wide carriage for the Remington typewriter on hand, I have to say that it is not the policy of the Department to furnish wide carriages for typewriters. It is found that in using these carriages for ordinary correspondence there is considerable strain on the machine.

Regarding the playground equipment asked for, I have to say that the Department does not provide slides, giant strides and travelling rings.

A book for cash receipts and expenditures has been forwarded to the Principal's address.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Wm. Gordon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

Referring to your letter No. 123-5-5 of April 17th last, received a few days ago, in regard to the mattresses asked for the Norway House Indian Residential School I would say that the beds are all six feet in length. Eight of the beds are 30 inches wide, the remaining are old beds and are the full 36 inches. Of course, 30 inch mattresses would answer the purpose but could not be made to look as neat and tidy as a mattress the full width of the bed.

With regard to the wide carriage for the typewriter I quite agree that the wide carriage is a strain on the machine when there is a considerable amount of correspondence done. In the case of our schools, however, there are some forms that cannot be completed on a narrow carriage typewriter and which require considerable time to make out by hand when three or four copies are necessary. There is also, of course, the greater possibility of making mistakes.

Regarding the playground equipment asked for I am sorry that this cannot be furnished as I am satisfied that the use of such would tend to better health among the children.

Your obedient servant,

Wm Gordon
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. McGill:

I have the honor to report that I visited the Norway House Boarding School on August 9th, 1933.

The children were absent on holidays. A few of the staff were present, and were busily engaged in cleaning and kalsomining the dormitories.

It is difficult to know the exact work being done at such an Institution unless one could visit it when the children are in residence. The Principal's wife is matron and also supervises the sewing room. I understand two Indian girls assist her in connection with the sewing room work. This department in any school I consider one of the most important and should be supervised by a qualified seamstress. Each and every Indian girl, on leaving our boarding schools, should be able to do all sewing necessary for a family, be able to cook properly, and also do well, all laundry work. I am sure the Department grant, if properly used, is sufficient to provide a competent and efficient staff.

The kitchen walls are in bad condition and before long will no doubt need replastering.

The laundry is in the basement, and all equipment appeared in good condition. The question of a laundry stove is urgent and a special letter in regards to it was addressed to the Department immediately on my return.

The furnace room

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.
The furnace room floor needs repairing. The expense in this connection would only entail eight or ten bags of cement. This room was in a very untidy condition and as I pointed out to the Principal, was the most likely source for a fire. Chips and dirt littered the floor, and wood was piled only a few feet from the jacket heater. The room was a duplicate of the one at the MacKay School, and unless more care is exercised, we will be fortunate to escape another fire. I instructed the Principal to have the place swept and to keep the floor clean and free of all rubbish. I do not think any wood should be piled in the furnace room, but should be kept in the wood room provided for that purpose. I advised the Principal to this effect, but he felt it would be too unhandy for the one in charge. I do not think we can emphasize too strongly the need for care in the prevention of fire and I am writing Mr. Gordon asking him to report if my instructions have been carried out.

I found two of the fire hose in poor condition. They were split in several places and new hose should be provided. Fire extinguishers are kept at various points throughout the building. The dormitories all open on the balconies where pole fire escapes are provided. No trouble should be experienced by the children in getting out especially if fire drill is observed. I am also asking Mr. Gordon to attend certain fire drills and report on what takes place.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The outbuildings are in fair repair, and meet quite well all requirements.

The garden this year is excellent and a splendid supply of vegetables will be obtained.

Cows are kept and at present 10 are being milked. The supply of milk meets fairly well with what is required by the school.

Pigs are raised, and at present 17 are being made ready for winter use. This meat, along with fish and beef, gives a varied diet for the children.

The batteries for the lighting plant are in poor condition, sediment has collected in many of the jars, which sediment is from the positive plates. These batteries charge up quickly, but just as quickly lose their charge as the positive plates are practically gone. It may be possible to manage this winter, but on the other hand, new batteries may be necessary at any time. At least, a new set should be provided in estimates for next year.

At some future date I hope to visit this school at a time when the children are in residence, and will then submit a more detailed report.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector,
Manitoba Inspectorate.
Ottawa, August 30, 1933.

Sir:

I have your report of the 24th instant on your inspection of the Norway House Indian Residential School.

You were authorized, by official letter of the 22nd instant, to arrange for the purchase and forwarding of a laundry stove.

You may arrange for the purchase of ten bags of cement to repair the furnace room floor. This material should be obtained from a firm on the approved list and forwarded to the school. It is to be understood that the work will be carried out by the staff, without expense to the Department.

It is noted that you found two of the fire hose in poor condition. No doubt, you are aware of the length and size of the hose. I would request that you arrange for the purchase of two lengths of hose and the nozzles and couplings that may be required.

All the above named materials should be forwarded before navigation closes. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost, with receipts for freight charges. You should certify and forward the accounts for payment.

Your remarks regarding the condition of the furnace room have been noted, and the Department is pleased that you have instructed the Principal to have the room kept free from all rubbish. It is noted, further, that you have written Mr. Agent Gordon in this connection. The Principal should see that every precaution is taken to overcome fire hazard. The Department notes that fire extinguishers are kept at various points throughout the building. It is hoped that these are in serviceable condition. It is noted that you have given instructions to the Agent to see that fire drill is carried out.

The need for new batteries for the lighting plant has been noted. The Department will have no funds to provide this equipment this year and it is hoped that the present batteries will stand up during the coming winter. This requirement will be kept in mind when next year's Estimates are being prepared.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Sir:

Referring to your letter 123-5-5, of April 30th last, re a new set of storage batteries for the Norway House Residential School, would say:

The last set of batteries were supplied in Sept. 1930, and have done duty for almost four years, as the summer months of June, July and August call for very little light.

Our batteries in this district, for at least eight months of the year, require a daily charge, and about alternate days for the other four months. This means approximately 300 charges per year. The batteries now in use have thus received approximately 1140 charges. Is not that rather more than batteries are guaranteed to stand?

The present engineer at the school is a good man, and I consider quite competent to care for the batteries properly, and he is also conscientious and painstaking.

Sir:

Just before the departure of Doctor McGill, Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs, from this agency, I received a note from the Rev. K.J. Beaton, of which the following is a copy:

Dear Mr. Gordon:

I have spent all day on the matter of repairs and equipment for the Residential School. I submit as a result the following minimum requirements if the new Principal is to have any kind of a chance:

1. Materials and labor for scraping furniture and rooms, and re-decorating residence, including rebuilding chimney, $200.00.

2. Jacket heater—twice capacity of present one, for hot water.

3. Dryer for laundry. $90.00

4. Mangle for laundry. (Flat work.) No supply

5. Engine parts list is available. $50.00

6. Labor repairing furnace fire boxes, and putting asbestos above furnace—$75.00.

7. Kalsomine, $50.00

8. Paint for interior decorating. $100.00

9. 10 desks for junior class room. No. 4, double.

The School budget will assume responsibility for the labor in repairing engine, save troughs, painting, decorating, and general repairs, though this cannot be done by the present staff, and additional help must be secured. The budget will also be made to cover additional horses, kitchen equipment, living room furniture, and a host of other needs.

There are a good many other things which might be listed, as you know, but they can wait for another year. I would suggest that as the buying of these things must be done immediately, that Dr. McGill give us a grant of $1000.00, and let Mr. Chapin, in consultation with you, get the purchasing and work under way next week.

Thanking you for your cooperation, which I deeply appreciate,

I am

Yours sincerely

Signed

K.J. Beaton

I handed a copy of this note to Dr. McGill, and he stated that he would write the Department.

May I say that the school building and equipment has been allowed to run down a great deal during the past few years. Too much economy has been practised for the good of the institution. Repairs which should have been made, and with little cost, could have been made, have been neglected. I should like to see the place put in as good condition as possible. I am of the opinion that the new Principal will take good care.
of the buildings and equipment under his charge.

With regard to the residence, I think it is a shame that a new house, and a good house, should have been allowed to get into the condition that this one has. With the wife of the Principal as matron of the school, and with a number of children, and with the Indian girls allowed more or less the run of the house, it certainly is in need of redecorating. Added to this, the chimney from the furnace smokes, and the fireplace cannot be used. It appears that the chimney will have to be torn down to the floor of the house, and rebuilt, as the outlet from the fireplace is too direct, and the bend in the furnace flue is too short, being a very abrupt double bend. It will mean that the fireplace must take up more room on the floor, and the mantle must be higher, to allow for a more moderate bend in the flue. The estimate for this work is $200.00 for material and labor.

The jacket heater at present in use is not large enough to provide the necessary hot water for the laundry. The boiler is 8 ft. by 30 inches in diameter. The heater is "Cottage Boiler," Gurney Foundry Co., coil, 21" wide, 42" high, 40" long. Something about twice the capacity would be satisfactory.

The Dryer for the laundry, also the Mangle,- I do not know just what is desired, but the Department will be fully informed as to what is being installed in the newer schools, and what should be satisfactory for a school of this size, with the capacity of our power and lighting plant.

I am enclosing a list of the engine parts required. Also sewetroughing, conductor pipe, elbows, with some bakum, and also fire cement for setting fire brick in furnaces.

I enclose also a list of paint, and Alabastine required for redecorating the walls of the building, (interior). This is badly needed.

I have been putting in the Estimates each year for emergency repairs for this institution. A sum of $1000. If this amount were allowed us, we could cover most of the items as outlined. Or if purchases were made by the Department, we could probably get started to build in the fire brick and repair the chimney. It will be noted that the suggestion is that the school budget will take care of the labor, with the probable exception of the rebuilding of the residence chimney.

I am anxious to see the new Principal get a chance to make good on the school work. He is a capable, hard working, conscientious man, who will surround himself with a good staff, and with proper equipment, should make the institution more of a success than it has been for some years. He was Asst. Principal in this school, under Mr. Daws, some years ago, so has experience to fall back on, also he has been in Indian Missionary work where he has had to do all kinds of work, for some thirteen years.

I hope the Department may be able to make a suitable grant for this work.

Your obedient servant

Wm. Gordon,
Indian Agent.

July 28th, 1934.

Dear Mr. Phelan;-

RE: NORWAY HOUSE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I have just returned from spending a month among our missionaries and teachers in Northern Manitoba, and there are a good many things that I want to talk over with you some time before the end of next week.

I want this morning, however, to call your attention to the necessity of immediate action in regard to letters already received by the Department from Dr. McCall and Mr. Gordon, concerning the serious condition of the Norway House school building. We were fortunate in having Dr. McCall there during his recent tour and he very kindly gave us half a day to look over the building and discuss the minimum requirements in the way of additional machinery and repairs. It would be quite easy to provide a list of repairs and equipment running into five or six thousand dollars. I am enclosing a copy of the letter which I wrote to Mr. Gordon at Dr. McCall's request, after we had gone over the building with Mr. Chapin, the new principal. You will find this elaborated in a little more detail in Mr. Gordon's letter to the Department, which I have not seen, but which I am confident carries a true picture of the situation.

I write to impress upon the Department the great necessity of urgency. I was in Winnipeg on Monday and Tuesday, and made several attempts to get in touch with Mr. A. G. Hamilton, the Inspector. There was no one in the office, so I presume the stenographer must be on holidays and Mr. Hamilton out on a tour of inspection. As the children will be coming back August 15th, I took the responsibility for going to Ashdown's and ordering the alabastine. This was shipped on the boat last Monday, and will arrive at Norway House today. Even at that, since the staff have agreed to do the work it will be a very difficult matter to get the dormitories, class-rooms, dining-room, &c., finished before school opens. I asked the manager at Ashdown's to send the bill to Mr. Chapin, who will be in Winnipeg for another week, and he will establish contact with Mr. Hamilton before he leaves.

I am taking it for granted that, as in previous years, the purchase of the laundry machinery will probably be done directly from the Department and that all the other matters will be attended to through Mr. Hamilton's office.

I wish to emphasize the great importance of having
Mr. Philip Phelan.

A competent man sent up to re-build the fire boxes in the furnaces of the school, and re-build the chimney in the principal's residence. The risk from fire which has been run in that wooden building during the last two years is incalculable. I complained about the necessity of re-building these furnace fire boxes when I came back from Norway House three years ago, in a lengthy conversation which I had with Mr. Russell Ferrier. At the same time we discussed the necessity of the Department giving a grant for a night-watchman for all of these industrial schools using frame buildings. I was greatly surprised to find on returning to Norway House this time that the grant for night-watchman there had never gone through. I think you will find Dr. McGill sufficiently impressed, when he returns to the office, with the urgency of this matter that there will be no difficulty in securing the comparatively small sum, say $500.00 a year, which will be necessary to hire a competent man.

In the meantime, I am anxious that the materials and equipment asked for in connection with Norway House shall be purchased at the earliest possible date. The season up there is very short and fires are necessary by the first of September. One cannot count on boat transportation from Winnipeg after September 15th.

Thanking you for your personal attention to this important matter, which I greatly appreciate,

I am,

Yours cordially,

Dear Sir:

I have just had a visit from the Rev. Mr. Chapin, newly appointed Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School, and he presented me with a letter, which is dated July 13th and addressed to William Gordon, Indian Agent, Norway House.

The letter sets forth repairs and equipment required for this school and I understand was forwarded by Mr. Gordon with his recommendation. Mr. Chapin is returning on August 6th and is very anxious that the Department have a suitable man ready at that time who can do the necessary repair work to the furnace and also rebuild the chimney in connection with the principal's residence.

In reply I have to confirm the following radio-telegraph message to you of yesterday's date:

"May purchase ten desks for Norway House School from firm on approved list. Have firm prepay freight. Forward certified accounts and freight receipt."

You should arrange for the purchase of 10 desks of the size and type required, from a school supply house or firm on the approved list, and arrange to have the desks forwarded to Norway House before navigation closes. A receipt for the freight charges should be obtained and forwarded with the account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the desks and including the freighting.

Mr. BUSKARD,-

I have your memorandum of the 19th instant, with attached correspondence between the Canada Seating Company, Winnipeg, and Mr. Inspector Hamilton's office, regarding an order which was placed by the latter for the supplying of ten double school desks, required for use at the Norway House Indian Residential School.

He was authorized, by wire, to arrange the purchase, from a firm on the approved list. He obtained quotations as follows:-

Currie School Equipment, Limited, Winnipeg - $10.40 each
Canada Seating Company, Winnipeg - 10.65 "

These prices were f.o.b. Winnipeg. Both firms quoted on a similar type of desk. Mr. Hamilton placed the order with the Currie School Equipment, Limited, 604 McIntyre Block, Winnipeg - this firm having quoted the lowest price.

Norway House Residential School, Man.:

Remodel and refurnish kitchen, with the exception of the stoves.

Recover dining room tables and provide new benches.

Install a steam-pressure plant for hot water and laundry purposes.

New roof for school verandah; present roof leaking badly in all directions.

Fill all cracks on outside with oakum or putty, and paint the whole exterior, including roof.

Refurnish staff bedrooms with proper beds; at present using same type of cots provided for children.

19th December 1934.

Sir,

I beg to report that yesterday I inspected the Norway House Indian Residential School.

On the day of my visit there were 22 pupils present in the Primary Room, and 12 present in the Senior Room. I was informed that these numbers were much below the usual attendance, owing to the pupils practicing in preparation for the annual Christmas Tree Concert.

The registers in both class rooms were not entered up to date. The importance of marking these registers each day was impressed upon both teachers, and they promised to see that this was done in the future.

During the past two months, considerable painting, kalsomining and repair work has been done in the kitchen, pupils' dining room, dormitories &c; and a great improvement has been made.

I would respectfully draw the attention of the Department to the dining tables in the pupils' dining room. These are not only very poorly constructed affairs, but I consider them highly unsanitary. The tops of these tables are nothing but old boards, covered with table oilcloth which also is in very worn condition, and certainly cannot be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. I would strongly recommend that new tables be supplied to replace those now in use; also new seating benches, as the benches now in use are also in very bad shape. I would suggest that dining tables and benches built according to the same specifications as those supplied -

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.;
supplied to the new Indian Residential School at Birtle when it was furnished in 1931, would be most suitable. No doubt the Department's Architect, Mr R.G. Orr, will have the construction details of these on hand. I would urge that the Department give favorable consideration to this matter, in order that arrangements might be made to have the necessary materials shipped to Norway House as soon as navigation opens.

The pit in front of the furnaces had about eighteen inches of water in it this morning, but the cause of this, a broken water pipe below the ground, has already been located and repaired.

The meals served at the time of my visit were of good wholesome food, and of good variety.

I found the discipline both in the school main building, and in the class rooms to be good.

The boys' playroom is in very poor shape, but I do not see that anything can be done with it at the present time, to improve it very much. It would require cement work and plastering. This room is, for some reason, very difficult to keep warm.

The toilets in the boys' basement were not as clean and tidy as they might have been. I would suggest that if one of the women members of the staff were to be put in charge of the boys, there might possibly be some improvement effected in this direction, as a woman would be more careful to insist on cleanliness in such matters.

I consider that the school has a very efficient staff.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 22nd instant,
I inspected the Norway House Indian Residential School,
in the afternoon.

At the time of my visit, there were 26 pupils present in the junior class-room, comprising grades 1 and 2. The reading aloud, especially of the grade 2 pupils, was very good, and it was quite noticeable that these pupils were beginning to get a little expression into their reading, and getting away from the characteristic monotone, in which Indian pupils usually do their reading. The pupils' writing was also very creditable.

In the senior class-room there were 10 pupils present, of grades 5 and 6, and a few of grade 4. The reading and book work of these pupils were also good.

On the occasion of my previous inspection in December last, both class-room teachers and the Principal were impressed with the importance of keeping the registers marked daily, and on this visit, I found both class-room registers marked up to date and in good order.

I made a second visit to the junior class-room the following morning, the 23rd instant, to see the beginners at their work, and was impressed with the interest shown by both teacher and pupils in their work. Lessons in reading, writing, spelling, as well as singing were gone through while I was there, and both teacher and pupils acquitted themselves well.

In the pupils' dining room, the tables had

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.,
had been recovered with new table oilcloth since my last visit, which improved them somewhat, but even in the short time these new coverings had been on, they were showing holes through the corners. The matter of new tables and benches, however, for the dining room, is about to be settled, according to Departmental letter No; 123-5-5 of the 17th January, to which I have replied, giving the definite requirements, to-day. Good wholesome meals are always served. The bread is baked of half white flour and half Graham flour, which makes a very nourishing food.

With reference to the boys' playroom in the basement; as stated in my last report, this is in poor condition, and, having reference to the above mentioned Departmental letter of the 17th instant, and the paragraph therein making special mention of this room, I beg to say that I do not consider that any expense should be incurred in repairs, until some arrangement can be devised for heating the room. At present, the radiators for the heating of this room are of the hanging type, and are close to the ceiling, with the result that the room, especially in very cold weather, is too cold for the boys to be in. The Principal and I considered the possibility of having the radiators put down on the floor, but the difficulty then, would be to get drainage from them back to the boilers, which are practically at the same level. There is, however access to the sewer in one corner of the floor in this room, if that could be used for the drainage of the radiators. The radiators themselves were quite warm, but the room itself was almost as cold as outdoors; a portion of pipe on one wall, about five feet from the floor being thickly covered with frost. The toilets in this basement were much cleaner than on my last inspection. The Principal had arranged to have a pipe connection with the boiler made, leading into this place, and with a hose and nozzle, these toilets are now cleaned with steam and hot water from the boilers.

In all the dormitories, as well as in many other places in the building, I found that there was much water on the floors, due to the air valves on the radiators leaking. There are 95 radiators in the building, with 77 of these valves, and I believe that not more than one third of these valves are working properly. They are, I think, of an old-fashioned type. I would recommend that 70 new valves of a reliable and efficient type, be provided for the radiators.
radiators, to eliminate the constant flooding of the floors.

May I draw the attention of the Department through you to the needs of our laundry, and ask that the new steam pressure plant advocated last year, including drier and mangle, be installed this coming summer.
