Sir,

I beg to report that today I inspected the Norway House Indian Residential School, and found everything about the institution to be clean and orderly, with the exception of the boys' playroom, which, as I have mentioned in previous reports, is in poor shape.

There were 24 pupils present in the Junior Classroom, and 12 in the Senior Classroom, at the time of my visit, and the registers in both rooms were marked up to date.

With reference to Departmental letter 123-5-5 of the 13th instant; the second paragraph; in connection with the radiators in the boys' playroom, I beg to say that I find that there is a radiator in the toilet just off this playroom, and on the same floor level, a radiator which is fastened to the wall, about two feet above the floor. This radiator is equipped with a special type of valve attached to the pipe at the bottom of the radiator, through which the water, but not the steam, drains directly into the sewage system below the floor. There are two radiators thus equipped, on the same floor level, and if the radiators which now hang from the ceiling in the playroom, could be brought down to the same level as these, and equipped with the same type of valve, the playroom would be much more efficiently heated I think. I could not make out the name of the valve mentioned, & the time, but I will try and have one of them disconnected and examined, and will further advise you. The Principal informed me that now the weather is not so cold, he intends doing considerable work in the way of repairing, and painting in this playroom in the month of March.

On going into the sewing room, I found a large

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No; 123-5-5 of the 13th instant, with reference to the proposed high pressure boiler for the Norway House Residential School laundry.

I have been carefully over this matter with the Rev; R.T.Chapin, the Principal of the school, and I am submitting herewith two rough sketches in connection therewith.

Sheet No; 1 shows the lay-out of the laundry, and the positions of the various machines &c;

With regard to a location for the proposed high pressure boiler; we find it impossible to set this in the boiler room - presuming the boiler would be of the same, or similar type to the one at the Birtle Residential School - and there are several objections to having it located in the laundry itself; chief of which are the additional heat it would cause, and the carrying in of the wood fuel; the ashes &c;

Sheet No; 2 shows the only location for the boiler that is available, and which I think would prove very satisfactory. The red circle shows the proposed location of the boiler, with the smoke pipes from it leading into the main chimney. This room, with the exception of that small part of it used for the batteries, is not used for anything in particular, and the batteries could be moved into the engine room and the temporary partition taken down -

The Secretary
Department of India Affairs
Ottawa Ont;,
down. The small outside shed shown, is not in use, and this could be taken down, and the doorway leading into it could be made into an opening through which fuel for the boiler could be taken in from outside the building. Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Residential School,
Norway House

You will remember that the last time I was in Ottawa I had with me a list of furnishings required in the Norway House Indian Residential School and, at your request, I took it away to secure more definite information as to the size of the beds. I am now in receipt of a communication from the Principal, Rev. R. T. Chapin, from which I have compiled a list which I think is fully explanatory.

I understand from Mr. Chapin that the information concerning the valves for the radiators has gone forward from Mr. Lazenby, the Indian Agent, and that what I am enclosing may be entirely unnecessary. I am sending it merely because I promised to do so when we discussed the matter.

The letters we are receiving from the North seem to indicate an early break-up and I should think that navigation on Lake Winnipeg would likely begin some time about the third week in May.

I also have from Mr. Chapin a copy of the drawings which he has forwarded to the Department concerning the alterations in the kitchen, pantry and children's dining-room. The tables for the dining-room have already been ordered, according to the information you gave me previously, through Mr. A. G. Hamilton, the Inspector in Winnipeg, and are being built according to these specifications.

I hope you will be able to tell from these drawings what the kitchen and dining-room will look like after the alterations are completed. I understand from Mr. Orr that the plan of the Norway House School was not drawn in his Department. Sometimes I wonder if it were drawn by anybody who knew the first principles of residential school construction. Personally, I cannot conceive of a more awkward layout than the one which has been in use and which it is now proposed to change. It will not be a very large item of expense to make the alterations in the kitchen, pantry, &c., as the work can be done by the school staff and all that will be needed is hardware and materials. I cannot see how even a beginning can be made on the re-arrangement of the kitchen until after the children are dismissed for summer holidays in June. I hope to see you in the meantime, as I have
promised Captain Scott, of Coqualeetza, to go to Ottawa with him on the 27th or 28th April.

With very kind regards,

I am

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

EJB.MLT

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

"Re boiler. Need hood, smokepipe with damper and chimney collar. Thirty four inches boiler top to ceiling. Eight feet four center boiler to inside chimney. Chimney nine inch wall. Sir:

I beg to submit the following short report on the United Church Indian Residential School at Norway House, inspected August 5th, 1935.

The children were all on holiday, consequently I will confine my remarks largely to the buildings.

Since my last visit a year ago, the Principal, the Rev. R. T. Chapin, has effected many changes. The building has been thoroughly cleaned and a large amount of rubbish removed.

School will open August 15th and by that time practically the entire interior of the school will have been painted or kalsomined.

Mr. Chapin is most grateful for the assistance rendered by the Department. The new tables were badly needed - in fact, indispensable. The tables and benches have been well put together and are now being painted.

The new boiler and drytex tumbler are installed, but not yet in use as certain necessary changes to the drive shaft have yet to be made. Mr. Stevens, the engineer, will carry out the work.

The new cupboards and tables, authorized for the kitchen, have not yet arrived, but will perhaps be on the next boat. These improvements, when installed, will be a great help to the kitchen matron.

The new beds and mattresses for the staff were needed and will be greatly appreciated. The mattresses supplied.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
supplied for the boys arrived in good condition.

Mr. Chapin has secured cement and expects, before winter, to have a new floor laid in the boys' playroom. This room is in the basement of the school and the present floor is in a disgraceful condition. The walls and ceiling will also be cleaned and painted.

The toilets throughout the building were all in good working order. Those in the boys' basement, which were filthy on the occasion of my last visit, were clean, and the offensive odor almost entirely eliminated.

The outbuildings are in good repair.

The milk cows number 12 head. They are not a good type and I doubt if any are heavy producers. A few good shorthorn cattle would be a worthwhile investment. They would no doubt produce more milk than the inferior type of cattle carried and the steers would greatly reduce the meat bill.

A start is being made, both in keeping poultry and pigs, but as the grain necessary for feed must all be shipped in by boat, I doubt if the undertaking will be profitable and this line of work for any graduates who remain in the north is of little, if any, value.

The school garden is good, although some of the potato crop is suffering from too much moisture.

The yards about the school are tidy and show a big improvement over last year. The fences and gates are all in good repair.

The school building is badly in need of exterior painting. However, the balconies should be levelled before this work is undertaken. If there is no money obtainable now for these improvements, I trust it will be provided.

Mr. Chapin took over a big task when he became Principal of this school. After Mr. Montgomery's visit to Norway House, I received a letter from P.G. Lazenby, the Indian Agent, pointing out that the electric wiring in the Norway House Indian Residential School was reported by Mr. Montgomery, the electrician, to be in very poor condition and that the building should be re-wired.

I have since discussed this matter with Mr. Montgomery and he points out that there is always a grave danger from fire in old exposed electric wiring. The wire often becomes exposed at the joints and other places where it passes through partitions. Mr. Montgomery stated that this was not work which their Company (Mumford Medland Ltd.) would care to undertake, but suggested that it might be advisable next year to secure the services of a competent electrician and have new wiring installed and the same enclosed in conduit pipe. I have been unable to get any estimate in connection with the work, but Mr. Montgomery is of the opinion that it would cost in the neighbourhood of three or four hundred dollars.

On account of the isolated position of the school, I think every precaution should be taken and I would recommend, if it is not too late, that provision be made in next year's Estimates for this work.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to report that I inspected the Norway House United Church Indian Residential School, with the exception of the class rooms, on the 4th instant, and the class rooms to-day.

On the 4th instant, the Principal reported to me that the gasoline engine, which has been in use for driving all the machinery; electric light generator, water pump, laundry machinery &c; had broken while running. I went to the school, and found that the crank shaft of this engine had broken in two, while it was running, and had caused considerable other breakage, besides the shaft itself. As they had another engine of similar type and horse power which was in use outside the building for work such as filling the silo etc., it was decided to install this one. The school engineer happened to be away on two days leave of absence at the time the above accident happened, and it was necessary to loan them the engineer from the agency staff to put things right.

I found the dormitories clean and well aired; the beds and bed clothing also clean and in good condition.

The laundry was in good working order in every way. The newly installed high pressure boiler, and Drytex Tumbler are working perfectly.

The sewing room was in good shape. The recently installed heavy type sewing machine is very much appreciated and has eliminated a great deal of heavy sewing by hand on the overalls etc.; The Principal took the heads of two of the other sewing machines with him to Winnipeg this summer and had them put in first class condition also.

The kitchen has been recently equipped with a series of new cupboards and tilting bins, which has vastly improved this department of the school. Food stuffs and the kitchen equipment is now properly and efficiently cared for.

The pupils' dining room has also been greatly improved with the installation this summer of new tables and benches. The meals served to the pupils consist of good wholesome food, of good variety.

The heating radiators have been equipped

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.,
with new valves, and this has eliminated the former nuisance of water leaking over the floors.

A considerable amount of painting has been done about the interior of the building, which has also greatly improved the appearance and cleanliness of the place.

Several changes were made in the staff personnel after the summer vacation, and the new members appear to be getting into the work very well. The staff as a whole are efficient, keenly interested in the work, and are all working together in harmonious fashion.

When I visited the senior class room on the 12th instant, there were 29 pupils present. Grades 2, 3, and 7 are taught in the mornings, and grades 4, 5, 6, and 8 in the afternoons. The register was marked up to date. The reading of the pupils was but fair. They do not speak English; which, however, is a very common fault among Indian pupils. The book work was also fair as a whole. The writing was good, but figure work was poor and somewhat untidy, though the work was good as far as correctness was concerned. I discussed this room and its teacher, with the Principal afterwards, and suggested that the teacher might work up a little more enthusiasm in his work, and so endeavour to infuse a little enthusiasm into the pupils. Both teacher and pupils appeared to be rather inclined to be 'easy-going'.

I visited the Junior class room and the Rossville Day School this afternoon. Since the close of summer vacation, the Rossville Day School and the Junior classes of the Residential School are being taught as one, in the Rossville school building. At the time of my visit, there were 32 pupils present, 13 of these being pupils of the Rossville Day School, and 19 being pupils from the residential school. There are 44 pupils on the residential school on the roll, and 17 day school pupils, two separate rolls being kept. There had been 41 pupils of the residential school in class today, out of an enrollment of 44. The registers were both marked up to date. The teacher of this room is Miss Edythe Smith-Windsor, new to the work since the holidays. The teacher is efficient, and the work of the pupils is creditable. Both teacher and pupils show considerable interest in their work.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Building on Forestry Island,
Norway House

Immediately across from the Reserve at Norway House is a small Island, known in the past as Forestry Island. It is separated from the mainland by perhaps 600 yards of water. The buildings on it belong to the Department of the Interior. They housed the members of the Forestry staff before the Natural Resources were taken over by the Province of Manitoba. With the exception of one residence, the buildings are now unoccupied and falling into decay. Among them is a bunk-house, 20 by 48 feet, originally used by members of the Air Force.

Our people have written, asking whether or not the Department of the Interior would be willing to transfer this building to the Department of Indian Affairs. The members of the church and the boys in the residential school would assume responsibility for taking it down, transporting it across to Rossville, and putting it up somewhere on the school site, to be used as a community centre. There is no auditorium in connection with the School at Norway House and no adequate gymnasium or play-room. The latter is a very great lack in a country which has such long winters as Norway House. All expenses in connection with the moving and reconstruction of the building would be borne by the Indian people and the missionaries.

If it is impossible to transfer this building from one Department to another in this way, will you please enquire from the Department of the Interior whether or not they would be willing to sell it to The United Church of Canada for a nominal sum. I think our local church at Norway House would probably be willing to pay a small sum of $50 or $50 for the building and move it on to the church site. That would provide the community centre, but it would put the senior pupils of the Residential School at a decided disadvantage in getting the use of the building.

I would very greatly appreciate your good offices in finding out at the earliest possible date what can be done about this matter.

Yours very sincerely,

KJB.MT

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith Voucher No; 652, amounting to $43.50, in favour of the Winnipeg Paint & Glass Co: Ltd of Winnipeg, Man: for paint as per invoice attached to the voucher, for painting the Norway House Indian Residential School.

The original authority for the purchase of paint &c; for the painting of this school, is contained in Departmental letter No; 123-5-5, dated 23rd July 1936, and addressed to Mr Inspector A.G.Hamilton. On this authority, Mr Hamilton purchased paint &c; to the value of $212.33 from the Winnipeg Paint & Glass Co; covered by this agency voucher No; 637 of the 24th August.

On Friday evening, August 21st the painters at work at the school, sent me word that they would be short of paint, as the building, not having been painted for so long, was soaking up the paint very rapidly, and asked for a further quantity. I therefore wired Inspector Hamilton to send the quantities stated on the attached invoice on the following Monday's boat from Winnipeg, in order to avoid a delay of a whole week. Mr Hamilton purchased the paint, and later wrote advising me that it had been shipped, and stated that he was taking it for granted that I had received Departmental authority for the purchase, as the first purchase came within about $17.00 of the amount appropriated for this purpose.

I had no specific authority from the Department

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont;,
for the purchase of this paint, but I would point out that the work could not have been completed without it, and that if it had not been requisitioned for to Mr Inspector Hamilton by wire, the painters would have been idle for a week, waiting for the paint to be delivered by the following week's boat.

I trust that the Department will approve of the action I took in this matter.

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 23rd October, I inspected the Norway House Indian Residential School, including the senior class room, but not the junior class room, which is conducted in conjunction with the Rossville Indian Day School.

Since my last inspection of this school, before the summer vacation, the outside of the building has been given one coat of paint, which has considerably improved the appearance of the place. The building, being frame construction, and not having been painted for a considerable number of years, was so dried out, that one coat of paint scarcely made any impression in some places. It should have at least two more coats of paint to properly preserve it and protect it from the weather. The old system of electric wiring has been removed, and a new system, in flexible conduit installed, including a fire alarm signal system. This has considerably reduced the fire hazard. Several items of new furniture have also been provided for the various staff rooms, such as chairs, dressers &c.

The dormitories were clean and tidy, and well aired, with ample room for their occupants.

The sewing room was orderly, and clean, with a number of the girl pupils present, taking instruction in sewing.

The bathrooms and toilets were all clean, and in good working condition.

The kitchen was clean, tidy, and in good order, with a number of the senior girls at work under the direct supervision of the dietician. The food served to the pupils is good, wholesome, and of good variety.

In the basement, I found that the high pressure boiler, which was newly installed a year ago, was being dismantled. On making inquiry as to what the trouble was, I was informed that the water had been allowed to get too low while the boiler was in operation, resulting in leaking flues. On making further investigation a day or two later, I found that it has been the practice lately, to leave one or other of the Indian boys in charge of this boiler, and it is my opinion that the lower end of the guage glass had been allowed to get plugged up, which would result in the water remaining in the glass, when the water in the boiler itself was very much lower than the bottom of the glass, thus whatever inexperienced boy was in charge, would think by looking at the glass, that there was plenty of water in the boiler when there was not. I discussed this matter

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.,
with the Principal, and strongly advised him to see that the school engineer was in direct charge of this boiler when it was in operation in the future, in order to avoid any possibility of accident. This boiler operates at a pressure of from 50 to 70 lbs., and it is very unwise, in my opinion, to leave an inexperienced Indian boy in charge of it while it is in operation.

The laundry was busy at the time of my visit, and the various machines were all operating well. The bakery is badly in need of a new oven, and this has been requisitioned for through the estimates for next year.

In the senior class room, there were 18 pupils present; 9 boys and 9 girls. There are 45 pupils on the roll, 26 of whom attend in the afternoons, and 19 in the mornings. The teacher of this class, Mr Harry Meadows, and the pupils, show keen interest in their work. The discipline was very good, and the pupils were attentive, and prompt in their answers to questions.

The fire equipment is good, having been much improved by the recent installation of the new alarm signal system. The fire escapes consist of two sliding poles of metal. Fire drill is carried out at intervals of about one month, and at these drills, the building is usually emptied in from three to four minutes.

A copy of this report is being forwarded to Mr Inspector A.G. Hamilton for his information.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Mr. Agent Lazenby's letter of October 28th, reporting on his inspection of the Norway House Indian Residential School on October 23rd, reached the Department on the first instant.

Part of his report reads, as follows:

"In the basement, I found that the high pressure boiler, which was newly installed a year ago, was being dismantled. On making inquiry as to what the trouble was, I was informed that the water had been allowed to get too low while the boiler was in operation, resulting in leaking flues. On making further investigation a day or two later, I found that it has been the practice lately, to leave one or other of the Indian boys in charge of this boiler, and it is my opinion that the lower end of the gauge glass had been allowed to get plugged up, which would result in the water remaining in the glass, when the water in the boiler itself was very much lower than the bottom of the glass, thus whatever inexperienced boy was in charge, would think by looking at the glass, that there was plenty of water in the boiler when there was not. I discussed this matter with the Principal and strongly advised him to see that the school engineer was in direct charge of this boiler when it was in operation in the future, in order to avoid any possibility of accident. The boiler operates at a pressure of from 60 to 70 lbs., and it is very unwise, in my opinion, to leave an inexperienced Indian boy in charge of it while it is in operation."

My dear Mr. Sutherland:

I am sending you a copy of the estimate of needs for the fiscal year beginning April 1st, 1937, which I am sure you have already received through Mr. Indian Agent Lazenby, concerning the Norway House Indian Residential School.

I have deliberately refrained from putting prices opposite the first three items, because I presume the Government has a fixed price with the manufacturers of this equipment.

I went over this list very carefully with the Principal of the School and can assure you that there is nothing asked for which is not absolutely necessary. In connection with the first item - Storage Batteries, - I would like to renew a suggestion that I have already made on at least two previous occasions, namely, that it would pay the Government to install one electric light plant, with a Diesel engine, to care for the hospital, the agency, the school, and the Government residences at Norway House. The initial cost might seem large, but the Diesel fuel is so much cheaper than gasoline and the engines have three or four times the length of life that a gasoline engine has, so that over a period of ten years it would be an economy measure. If the plant were equipped with two Diesel engines, as our hospital at Port Simpson is and as the new hospital at Bella Bella is, the batteries would be eliminated altogether. Their renewal every three or four years is a very expensive item.

While I am talking about the Norway House School, may I return once again to the question of the enormous risk which the Government is running by having 105 children and a staff in that old frame building without a night watchman. It certainly would be a sad day for the Department of Indian Affairs and the Church, if a fire broke out there in the depth of winter and the public were made aware of the fact that the small grant necessary to keep a night watchman on the job from October to May had been refused.

We very deeply appreciate the grants that have been made towards this School since Mr. Chapin became Principal and we are grateful for Dr. McGill's letter in which he expresses satisfaction at the improvement in conditions, as evidenced by the Inspector's reports, since the occasion of his last visit.

Yours very sincerely,

KJB.MLT

Ottawa, December 10, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of November 4th, the Department will make an allowance at the rate of $40. a month for the period November 1, 1937, to April 30, 1938, in order to assist the Principal of the Norway House Residential School in engaging a night watchman.

Voucher covering the allowance made by the Department can be forwarded at the end of each month. You should use a similar voucher to that used last year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

P.G. Lazenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.
When I visited the school a second time, on the 12th instant, I went downstairs to see the high pressure boiler, which had not been operating when I visited the school on the 9th instant. I found that this boiler was carrying a pressure of 60 lbs per square inch, and two Indian boys were in charge of it. One of these boys was probably 20 years of age; a graduate of the school, and employed there, named Hedley Ross. This boy, while no doubt a handy sort of boy in many ways, is not a qualified engineer, and in my opinion, should not be left in charge of this boiler. In connection with this matter, I beg to refer you to my inspection report regarding this school dated 28th October 1936, and the official letter of the Department, No: 123-5-5, dated 3rd December 1936 addressed to the Principal of the school, regarding the operation of this boiler. Mr. R.L. Stevenson, a member of the school staff, has a 3rd class engineer's certificate, and should, in my opinion, as I previously said, always be in direct charge of this boiler when it is in operation."
Ottawa, December 15, 1937.

EX'D.

Reverend Sir:

In official letter of December 3, 1936, the Department pointed out to you that it is very undesirable to leave the boiler at the Norway House Indian Residential School in charge of an inexperienced Indian boy. I further understand that the Provincial laws of Manitoba require that a high pressure boiler be operated by an engineer holding a certificate.

When Indian Agent Lazenby visited the school on the 9th instant, he found that the boiler was carrying a pressure of 60 pounds per square inch and that two Indian boys were in charge of it, although Mr. R.L. Stevenson, a member of the school staff has an engineer's certificate.

In future, the Department will expect that this boiler will not be operated unless under the supervision of Mr. Stevenson or some other qualified person.

I would appreciate receiving from you an acknowledgement of this letter, indicating that the Department's instructions will be carried out.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Sir,

I beg to report that at about 3 p.m. yesterday afternoon, a member of the Norway House Residential School staff ran to this office and told me that the school was on fire.

I immediately went over to the school, and found that the roof had taken fire inside, where the roof joins the big chimney. The Principal, Rev. R.T. Chapin, and some of the men of the staff, were already on the roof when I got there, and with two fire extinguishers, had extinguished the blaze; one inside the attic, and the other outside on the roof. Very little damage was done, and this can be repaired with a board or two. The fire was discovered by the Matron, Mrs Carefoot, who happened to look up the inside of the dumb waiter, which runs up from the kitchen, alongside the chimney, and she saw smoke at the top. She immediately started the fire alarm, and all the pupils were quickly evacuated from the building without any trouble or panic.

The Principal and I made a careful examination of the chimney, but could not find any crack or hole in it through which a spark could get out. The walls of the chimney are two bricks thick. There is a sheet metal 'saddle' on the roof where the chimney comes through, to run the rain water off at each side of the chimney, but this 'saddle' is not grouted into the wall of the chimney, but simply placed against it on the outside. It is thought that a spark from the top of the chimney must have been whirled by the wind, down between the chimney wall and the metal saddle, on to the shingle roof below, and with possibly a draft blowing in as well, this spark has set fire to the roof, (see sketch).

This metal saddle should have been set into the wall of the chimney properly, but this was not done when it was built. It cannot be done now, owing to the sub-zero weather, but will be done as soon as possible in the spring. As a temporary measure, the metal saddle is being replaced, with a packing of asbestos between it and the chimney, so that there will be no orifice through which any more sparks can get in.

It was fortunate that the fire took place in the daytime, and that it was so promptly discovered and dealt with, as the building is entirely of frame construction, and if a fire were to get any sort of start, it would burn like tinder.

The water pipe which serves the fire hose, and which runs up inside the building, projects right through into the attic, where the pipe is capped at the top. I would strongly recommend

Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont:

recommend that a valve and fire hose be provided in two separate places in the school attic. This would involve the purchase of the following:

1 - Galv. Iron Tee. 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)"  
2 - Fire Hose Valves, to fit 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" stand pipe  
1 - Fire Hose. 20 Feet long, fitted with brass coupling and brass nozzles.

2 - Hangers, to carry the fire hose when not in use.

Part of Mr. Lazenby's report reads as follows:

"The water pipe which serves the fire hose, and which runs up inside the building, projects right through into the attic, where the pipe is capped at the top. I would strongly recommend that a valve and fire hose be provided in two separate places in the school attic. This would involve the purchase of the following:

2 - Fire Hose Valves, to fit 1½" stand pipe

1 - Ditto. 30 Feet long, with brass coupling and nozzle.

A special report has been forwarded to the department in this matter, with certain recommendations regarding measures for better protection against fire in the attic of the school. Very little damage was done, and this was repaired the next day.

P. G. Lazenby,

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 22nd May, I inspected the Norway House Indian Residential School, with the following findings:

In the store room in the attic, new fire hoses and stand pipes were installed in February, and there are also two hand fire extinguishers in addition. This room was clean and tidy, and well kept.

All the dormitories were clean and in good order. There are a few minor repairs to be made this summer to the plaster of the walls of the junior boys' dormitory. The blankets on the beds in this dormitory are getting quite shabby, but the Principal advised me that he had a new stock of blankets on order, which would arrive on the opening of navigation. Some of the bed springs in all the dormitories were in poor shape.

The sewing room; laundry; and bakery were all in good order in every way, and efficiently managed.

The kitchen was clean and orderly, and well managed in every way. The only defect in the kitchen is the metal sink, which is in very poor shape, and which I brought to the attention on the Department in my letter of the 24th February last.

All the pupils were fairly well clothed, and clean.

In the class room, there were 29 girls present, there being 58 pupils on the roll, the balance of the pupils being taught at the Rossville Day School. The register was well kept, and marked up to date. Several of the boy pupils were at manual training in the carpenter shop. The class room work of the pupils present, was creditable; their book work being neat, clean, and well done.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.:
Sir,

I beg to be advised if there is on file at the Department's offices, a plan of the Norway House Indian Residential School, which, I understand, was built in 1914.

What is actually desired, is that part of the plan which shows the lay-out of the school sewage system.

The principal of this school called at the office this morning, and advised me that the sewer pipes are apparently getting badly worn out. A block in one of the pipes occurred a few days ago, and when a cleaning rod was pushed down the pipe for about 40 or 50 feet, the end of the rod went through the side of the pipe. The broken pipe was located, and found to be badly corroded and so worn that the cleaning rod went right through the side of it.

The principal stated that they had had much more trouble with the sewage system this winter than ever before, and it would appear that at no distant date, the system will need to be renewed, and if a plan were available, showing the lay-out of the pipes, it would facilitate matters when occasion arose to dig any of them up. At present, no one knows where or how the pipes are laid.

The principal also advised me that their septic tank had been giving a great deal of trouble too, and from the description given to me by the school engineer, of the construction of this tank, I imagine that it is not properly constructed. However, they are going to clean this tank out shortly, and I have asked to be supplied with a sketch of a cross section of the tank, and when I have this, I will again take the matter up with the Department.

In the meantime, it will be appreciated if a plan of the sewage system can be forwarded.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

DIRECTOR,
SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH

Re: Plan of Norway House Indian Residential School

This Branch is in receipt of a letter from Mr. P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Manitoba, in which he states:

"I beg to be advised if there is on file at the Department a plan of the Norway House Indian Residential School, which I understand was built in 1914. What is actually desired is that part of the plan which shows the lay-out of the school sewage system".

Mr. Lazenby's request has been discussed with Mr. Dudley and it is my understanding that you have on file a plan of the Norway House School. If such is the case, it would be appreciated if you sent forward a copy to Indian Agent Lazenby.

Director.
Sir,

I beg to request that the installation of the Chlorinator and Water Pressure Pump in the Norway House Indian Residential School might be proceeded with as soon as possible after the opening of navigation, about 1st June next.

When in Ottawa, I discussed the matter with Mr Philip Phelan, who advised me that the sum of $800.00 had been included in the Estimates for the new chlorinating plant.

As the Chlorinator itself should not cost more than about $350.00, it was suggested that with the balance a new pressure pump might be provided, to replace the present one, which is very old, and obsolete. The present pump is a Gardner-Denver, and when it operates, it vibrates the whole building, although many methods have been tried to reduce this. In addition, whenever repairs are required for this pump, there is always considerable difficulty in procuring them, as the pump has no serial number, or other mark of identification, apart from the name of the makers.

When I was in Ottawa, a gentleman from the engineering branch, (whose name I omitted to note, but would probably be known by Miss Walton), came to the office on two occasions to discuss the matter of this pump with me. On his second visit, he brought a quotation of $925.00, F.O.B. Montreal, for a Fairbanks Morse Pump of 5,000 gallons per hour capacity, plus $35.00 for automatic control.

The pressure tank at the school is a very large one, being six feet in diameter, and 20 feet long, and therefore a pump with a good capacity is required. This pump could be operated with the motor that operates the present one, so that there would be no change in that respect.

Mr Phelan advised me to bring this matter to the attention of the Department immediately after the beginning of the new fiscal year.

I may say that all particulars regarding the chlorinators were left with Dr Stone when I was there.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Norway House, Man:
5th July 1939.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that in conversation with the Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School, the matter of the school engineer's house was brought up.

Mr R.L. Stevenson, the engineer, has for many years past lived in a small log building, which is now in very bad shape, and just about ready to fall. Mr Stevenson is a married man, with wife and one girl, and as he purposes staying on at the school as engineer for another ten years at least, some new provision will need to be made for a dwelling house for him.

The present house in which Mr Stevenson lives, is of course a part of the school property, and is located in the school grounds.

It is considered that a small dwelling, somewhat similar to the enclosed cut, would be adequate.

Would you please advise me if provision may be made in the Estimates for the next fiscal year, for the construction of such a house for the purpose mentioned. If so, steps will be taken to find out the approximate cost.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby,

Sir,

I beg to report that today I inspected the Norway House Indian Residential School.

This school building, being of frame construction, and old, is of course showing signs of wear and tear, being out of line in several places, and so on. The interior, however, during the past summer, has been practically entirely re-decorated; walls, ceilings, floors etc., having been painted, kalsomined, or varnished as requirements indicated. A new hot water storage tank; jacket heater; and kitchen sink were purchased for the school. The tank and the kitchen sink were received on the last boat of the season, but the jacket heater did not arrive, although I was advised by Mr. Inspector A.G. Hamilton, that all these things were to be shipped together, from the one firm from whom they were purchased. The kitchen sink has been installed, but the hot water storage tank has not been installed as yet, and the Principal advises me that they will continue with the old tank, until the jacket heater is received and install both at the same time. Provided of course, the old tank does not again develop leaks in the meantime. The outside of the building is badly in need of painting, for which purpose an item was included in the Estimates for the next fiscal year. The dormitories were all clean and tidy, and well aired. The wash rooms also were very clean and neat, as also were all the other departments, kitchen; laundry, bake-room etc.

The class room register was marked up to date, and there are 58 pupils on the roll, 30 of them being present at the morning session; the other 28 attend the class room in the afternoons. The 58 pupils are divided into the following grades:

| Grade | Pupils |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 7      |
| II    | 6      |
| III   | 17     |
| IV    | 8      |
| V     | 10     |
| VI    | 4      |
| VII   | 2      |
| VIII  | 1      |
| IX    | 1      |
| X     | 1      |

There are no Grade 8 pupils on the roll, and at the time of my visit, pupils of grades 1, 2, 4, and 5 were present in the class room. The book work of these pupils was good, being neat, clean, and accurate. Their reading - however -

The Secretary

Ottawa, Ont.;
however, was only fair. I suggested to both the teacher and the Principal, that more attention could well be given to this aspect of the class-room work.

There are two fire escapes, both of the sliding pole type, and both are easily accessible, and the fire alarm system is electric, recently new, and in good condition. Fire drill has been carried out weekly until the winter set in, and since that time, at least once a month, and sometimes oftener. The usual night watchman has been employed since November 1st. In connection with the employing of the night watchman, I may say that I wrote to the Department on October 13th last, requesting authority to employ the night watchman at the usual allowance of $40.00 per month, but our mail service was suspended the following day, so that no reply has been received, and I do not know as yet if my letter was received at the Department. However, as the employing of a night watchman is absolutely necessary at this school, and there has been one for some years past, the same man as usual was given the duty beginning November 1st.

Dear Sir,

We would appreciate your advice as to the following refund -

On May 31st, Mr. Lazenby requested that we obtain refund on twenty empties which he had that date returned to the British American Oil Company for the credit of the Norway House Indian Residential School. On July 17th we received their cheque #19161 for $48.00 covering six empties with the advice that only six were received and they were tracing the remaining fourteen. However, on Nov. 13/39 we received their cheque #19125 in the amount of $160.00 for twenty empties.

Both these cheques went forward to the Receiver General - see our Form 527, Numbers 9 and 15, dated August 15th and November 15th.

On investigation of the extra six empties for which credit was received, it was found that these had been taken over by the principal of the school from Forestry Island, on instructions of the salvage officer, and had been instructed to return the empty drums to the B.A. Oil company for the credit of the Royal Air Force, to whom they had belonged. The British American Oil Company now state-

"The credit was apparently put into the Indian Affairs Branch account in error and payment of these six drums has apparently also been made to your Dept. in error." In order to adjust this matter, therefore, it would appear that we should receive a cheque from your Dept. for $48.00. We would then credit this amount to the account of the R.C.A.F. in order to straighten out the matter."

Ottawa, July 15, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to certain materials required for the Norway House Indian Residential School.

From the amount provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements and purchase of new equipment for the Norway House Residential School, it has been found necessary to use $1,000 as part of the cost of the new water installation. The remainder of the cost of this work is being paid partly from the Administration Vote and partly from the Medical Vote.

As a result of the above payment, there is only about $275.00 still available for repairs and improvements, and new equipment at the Norway House School during the current fiscal year. I am, therefore, arranging to have the Purchasing Branch secure the following articles:

1 Iron Post Hollow for Laundry 5" - 106½" high with 11 inch caps,
10 Dormitory Beds, 30" x 72", fitted with shoes,
15 Bed Springs, without frames, for Beds 36" x 72"

Dear Mr. Lazenby:

Yours of the 23rd to hand re the Department's letter concerning Alex Duncan's wages and repairs for power plant engines.

We are quite ready to assume our share of costs but may I ask why repairs for the engine should be charged against per capita grant? I should think this should be charged against the grant made to the school annually for building and repairs. Repair parts for our school engines when we were running our own separate plant were always included in this grant.

Regarding the payment of part of Alex Duncan's wages, again we want to pay our share. But if we pay 60% of his wages should we not be required to pay only the same proportion of the wages of the second man in the power house? It would be hardly fair for us to pay him his full wages, value of $40. per month, and also 60% of Alex Duncan's wages. We have been working on the assumption that we supply one man and the Department the other. The man we had went into the hospital and from the first of January this year we have had one of the senior boys on the job, giving him a small allowance. However from now on again we will be paying regular wages as this boy has graduated from the school, and we expect the other man to be ready for work again very shortly.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) R. T. Chapin
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Chapin, the Principal of the Norway House School in regard to different matters, and in the course of it he refers to a communication from Ottawa in regard to the payment of the wages of the man who looks after the power plant and repairs to the engines. I think the best thing to do is to quote what he has to say:

"When the new power plant was established it meant that two men had to be employed to look after it—a day and night man. We started off with the School employing and paying one man and the Department employing and paying the other. Of course we do not pay as high a wage as they do; we have a young fellow and they have a married man with large family. The Auditor General has been going into things; he overlooks the fact that we are hiring one man, and orders that, as from April 1st, 1939, the school shall pay 60% of the salary of the powerhouse attendant, also 60% of the cost of repairs and parts for engines in that time. This amount, $31.90 for repairs and $455.06 for wages, is to be deducted from our September quarter per capita allowance. I am enclosing copy of my reply to the Agent. The 60% basis was worked out when the power plant was installed—that was about the proportion of power the School used."

If there was an agreement that the School should pay one man and the Department should pay the other, do you think it quite fair to make any change without consulting us or the Principal about the matter? I confess that it seems neither businesslike, courteous nor fair for the Government to vary an arrangement which has been made without consulting the other party concerned. This happened in connection with the reduction in the per capita grant to the residential schools, and also in connection with the decision to reduce the period of teaching in the day schools by one month. Now, for a third time, we have an instance of the variation of a working agreement without any consultation with us at all.

I want once more to protest against this kind
of treatment. It would appear in this case that it was the Auditor General who had the change made. Are we to understand that the Auditor General has power to vary an agreement into which your Department has entered with the Church or an individual? If this sort of thing is to become the practice at Ottawa, then I think our protest will have to go further.

You will also note in Mr. Chapin's letter to the Agent (copy of which is enclosed) his query as to why the School's share of the cost of repairs to the power plant engines should not be charged against the annual grant to the School for building and repairs instead of against the per capita grant. Will you be good enough to look into this matter, also, and let us know whether Mr. Chapin's wishes in this matter can be met.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Re - Refund of Oil Barrels - Norway House

You will probably remember that there were barrels of oil sent to Norway House School in 1938. The School was charged with $974.40 to cover the cost of the barrels, which amount was to be refunded to the School when the barrels were returned. The only refund we have had to date is an amount of $152.00, received on March 26th, 1939. However, there was deducted from the grant for the June quarter, 1939, an amount of $12.00 for freight on barrels which were returned. We are informed that in May, 1939, 42 barrels were returned by the Agent, for which the School was to receive a credit of $336.00. From the September (1939) quarter grant $58.94 was deducted for freight on these barrels, but we never received the refund. (Mr. Chapin points out that the freight on 42 barrels would be only $27.30.)

In May, 1940, the Agent returned another 19 barrels, for which the School was to have been credited with $144.00. We have had no refund of this amount either. In June, 1940, the Agent returned 41 barrels, for which the School should have received a credit of $322.00. The freight on these was charged back direct to the School, but there has been no credit given us for the returned barrels.

Will you be good enough to look into this matter and see that Norway House School gets the refunds which are due. It does not seem quite right to charge us freight for barrels that were returned and not give us credit for the barrels themselves.

As far as the grant for the June quarter, 1940, is concerned, - on the basis of 92.24 per cent, of a pupilage of 105, we figure the grant should be $4237.27. In addition, for special nursing care an amount of $232.75 was due, figured on the basis of 931 days at 25 cents. This made a total due, according to our figuring, of $4470.02, whereas the amount sent for the quarter was only $4094.76. This may be the result of charging the School with further amounts for freight on oil barrels and not crediting the refunds on the barrels. Will you please look into this, too, and let us know what the explanation is.

It would help us very much in understanding the amounts sent by the Government for residential schools from quarter
Indian Affairs Branch

to quarter, if the form which accompanies the cheque were to specify exactly what the amount covers.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

RBC.MLT

October 11, 1940.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

In memorandum of October 8, the Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, in reporting on the alterations to Norway House light and power plant, states that the 1500 gallon pump at the hospital and the 5000 gallon pump at the school have both been installed in the power plant building and connected to a common delivery pipe.

He states, further, that the 1500 gallon pump has sufficient capacity to meet normal requirements at the Agency, but that additional pumping capacity would be required in case of fire.

He advises that the 5000 gallon pump formerly in the school only operates at 25% efficiency and that to re-condition this old pump, including shop work, freight and cartage, would cost at least $135.00.

In view of the fact that the cost of a new pump would be little more than the cost of repairing the old one, the engineer looking after the Norway House plant obtained prices from the Power and Mine Supply Company and the Canadian Fairbanks Morse. Power and Mine Supply offer a new centrifugal pump of some 4500 gallons per hour, directly connected to the present motor, for $145.60 f.o.b. Winnipeg. Canadian Fairbanks Morse offer a 3500 gallon per hour centrifugal pump with a new 5 H.P. motor for $163.95. Canadian Fairbanks Morse place a salvage value on the present 5 H.P. motor of $60.00 but this they would not accept as part payment on the new unit.
The Director further advises that there are sufficient funds available in the amount transferred to his Branch this summer to purchase the pump and motor from the Canadian Fairbanks Company for $163.95.

It would appear advisable to instruct the Surveys and Engineering Branch to arrange for the purchase from the aforesaid funds, although delivery and installation could probably not be made until navigation opens in the spring. I should like, however, to have your views before issuing instructions to the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

M.W. Director.

CANADA
Ottawa, November 5th, 1940.

Dear Doctor Cochrane:

I desire to refer to your letter of September 5th, in connection with the operation of the lighting plant at the Norway House Indian Residential School. I regret that my reply to your letter has been so delayed but, due to circumstances beyond our control, it was not possible to reply sooner as the whole question of expenditure in connection with light and power at Norway House has been the subject of correspondence with our officials.

When the new lighting plant was installed at Norway House it was understood that 60% of the cost would be charged against the Norway House Residential School. I was under the impression that Rev. Mr. Chapin was aware of this arrangement, and that it included both the cost of the oil and wages of the men employed to handle the plant. However, certain payments were made and a percentage of them was not charged against the school and, as a consequence, the Auditor General has drawn our attention to the fact that we were not carrying out the arrangement originally made by ourselves. He, therefore, directed that we should carry out our own agreement. This necessitated charging against the per capita grant certain amounts which should have been deducted in 1939.

The point that was raised in your letter in connection with the Department charging the school with repairs to the electric plant is, I feel, well taken and, consequently, it has been decided to make no such deduction.

In order to adjust the matter, certain deductions have been made from the September quarter per capita allowance of the Norway House School. For your information, I enclose a statement of these deductions, also a statement showing amounts refunded to the school for empty barrels which have been returned. In addition, a detailed report regarding the method of arriving

Rev. R. B. Cochrane, D.D.,
Secretary, Board of Home Missions,
The United Church of Canada,
299 Queen St. W.,
Toronto (2), Ont.
at the amount due the school for the September quarter is also attached.

During the past summer the Department has made a complete re-arrangement of the light and power plants installed at Norway House in 1938. This means that all machinery for lighting the various buildings, driving electrical equipment and pumping water are now installed in one central building. Arrangements are now proceeding for the purchase and installation of a new pressure pump.

The above installation will be operated by the same persons and our officials have found that the annual operating costs, including labour, oil, etc., will be approximately $4,000 a year. This would involve the employment and payment by the Department of Mr. Stevenson and Mr. Ross, both of whom are now on the staff of the Norway House School.

As shown by our auditor's reports, the amount expended by the Norway House School for light, water and power over a period of years has averaged approximately $2,000. It is, therefore, felt that a fair charge against the school in future for supplying light, power and water would be the amount mentioned in the preceding sentence, which is 50% of the total operating costs. The new system should, of course, give much better service than the school has received in the past. I trust that the proposed arrangement meets with your approval, and it would be appreciated if you would advise me to that effect.

The deduction of the annual payment from the Norway House School could be made from the per capita allowance at the rate of $500 a quarter.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Sewage Disposal, Norway House, Manitoba.

While Mr. Snelson was at Norway House last summer he made a careful inspection of the sewage disposal system there and has now submitted his report, two copies of which are attached for your information.

The following points will be noted:

(1) The septic tank for the school is poorly designed and is too small.

(2) The septic tank for the Hospital, while small, will give satisfactory service so long as the hospital population is not increased and the depth of sludge in the tank is not allowed to exceed six or eight inches. This will require careful maintenance.

(3) The kitchen and laundry wastes from the school should be by-passed around the septic tank.

(4) The main sewer line outlet should be extended as the recent lowering of the level of Little Playgreen Lake has left the outlet about 100 feet from the present shore line.

To improve these conditions Mr. Snelson has offered two suggestions:

(1) That the present concrete tank at the school be enlarged to handle the sewage from both school and hospital at an estimated cost of from $1,200 to $1,500 or that a new steel tank of similar capacity be installed at an estimated cost of from $900 to $1,100.

(2) That a 4-inch line be laid a distance of 700 feet to bypass kitchen and laundry wastes from the school around the septic tank and that the main sewer line be extended about 300 feet, the estimated cost of both being from $1,200 to $1,500.

We concur fully in these suggestions but would strongly recommend the concrete septic tank as being more lasting although slightly more expensive. The estimated cost of the above work with 10% for engineering and contingencies is $5,300. This matter might be referred to the Indian Affairs Branch as if it is decided to proceed with the work next year it should be carried out during July and August when the school is not in operation.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

REPORT ON - NORWAY HOUSE SEWAGE SYSTEM.
NORWAY HOUSE, MANITOBA.

I beg to submit the following report covering the condition of the septic tanks and sewage lines at Norway House, as inspected August 26th, 1940. Before inspection, both the septic tank for the school and that for the hospital were thoroughly cleaned.

SEPTIC TANK FOR RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The main septic, or liquefying chamber of this tank measured 5' x 6' x 5' deep. The total contents below the water surface of the overflow pipe is therefore 150 cubic feet. Assume that the sludge would be removed when it had attained an average depth of one foot over the bottom. This would give a total liquefying volume of 150 - 30 = 120 cubic feet. Three cubic feet of liquefying volume should be allowed for each person served. The total service capacity of the liquefying chamber on this basis would be 120 ÷ 3 = 40 persons. This is the present carrying capacity of the septic tank. Removing a concrete wall which separates the two chambers of the tank will increase the liquefying volume to 306 cubic feet or sufficient for sixty-eight (68) persons. The flow across the liquefying chamber of this tank from the inflow to the outflow pipe is but 5 feet, as the inflow enters along the side of the tank instead of at the end opposite the outflow. The flow is thus short circuited. The tank is not only too small but is ineffective. It should have a capacity, for the school and Principal's residence, of at least 120 x 5 = 360 cubic feet. I would recommend therefore that this concrete tank be enlarged to such size as will care for both the hospital and the main school, or large enough to provide for 200 persons, or replaced with a new steel tank.

(A) Estimated cost to enlarge present concrete tank $1500., to $1500.
Estimated cost to install a new steel tank .... 900., to 1100.

SEPTIC TANK FOR HOSPITAL.

This tank consists of two chambers, one (A) receiving sewage from the hospital, the other (B) receiving laundry waste from the hospital. The cubical contents of the liquefying chamber below the high water or outflow elevation is:

For chamber (A) 1.5' x 6.4' x 8.6' = 60.64 Cubic Feet
" " (B) 2.5' x 6.4' x 7.8' = 109.68 "

Total liquid capacity A. plus B. = 190.32 Cubic Feet

Chamber (A) ..................
Chamber (A), receiving sewage only, with a total fluid content of 80.64 cu. ft., less 37.0 cu. ft., which would be occupied by sludge at a depth of not to exceed six (6) inches, would accommodate \(\frac{80.64 - 37.0}{12} = 4.47\) approximately eighteen (18) persons.

Chamber (B), receives the overflow from chamber (A) and also the laundry water through a separate inflow pipe. The fluid content of this chamber below its outflow elevation is 109.38 cu. ft. Assuming a depth of sludge not exceeding 6 inches would give a liquid volume in this chamber of \(109.38 - 37.45 = 71.93\) cu. ft., or sufficient to care for twenty-seven (27) persons if no laundry waste entered the chamber. The total carrying capacity of the two chambers would therefore be between eighteen (18) and forty-five (45) persons depending upon the chemical contents of the laundry wastes.

I consider that with cleaning often enough to keep sludge depth less than 6 or 8 inches, this tank will give satisfactory service so long as the hospital population is not increased by enlargement of the building or the addition of more beds.

**MAIN SEWER LINE:**

On August 26th the water surface of Little Playgreen Lake had receded so that the outlet of the main sewer was over 100 feet from the water's edge. According to advice recently received in connection with the extension of the intake of the water system further out into the lake—it may be possible that the distance between the end of the sewer and the water surface is much more than the distance noted on August 26th, 1940. Pipe will be required to extend the sewer to the lake. I will advise you—in more detail—of the estimated cost of this item as soon as I have more definite information as to position of lake high water level.

A four inch diameter sewer line some 700 feet long, should be laid from the main school building to point just below the outlet of the main septic tank, for the purpose of by-passing laundry and kitchen waste.

This line, and the extension of the main sewer an estimated 500 feet is estimated to cost approximately $1,200.00, made up as follows:

Dear Sir,

In presenting the enclosed estimate of our needs for 1941 I have tried to keep within the actual needs of the year. If repairs are not kept up year by year the building soon goes hopelessly back and requires twice the expense to put in shape again.

The building is now in bad need of paint. When it was painted in 1936 it had stood I do not know how many years since its last painting. The one coat of paint, which was all that was put on in 1936, made little protective coating as it so went into the wood. It ought to have been done this year but had to be held over. If it is left longer than next year even a two coat job will not put it in proper shape again.

Plumbing equipment and repair parts are an essential to be kept on hand. After navigation stops there is no way of getting in such except by plane at 20¢ per pound. So we must have enough parts on hand to meet all needs that might arise during the year.

The laundry is one place the Doctor is constantly checking to watch the health of the girls working there. An electric ironer would lighten their burden immensely.

The fire equipment speaks for itself.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th ultimo enclosing requisition for additional items requested by the Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School.

When Mr. Lazenby forwarded the estimates for the fiscal year 1941-42 for the Norway House Residential School he requested that an amount of $2000.00 be included in this year's appropriation for labour and material for painting the school and other buildings. At the same time he forwarded a letter from Rev. Mr. Chapin stating that the building was badly in need of paint as it had been last painted in 1936.

In the current year's appropriation it was found possible to provide an amount of $2150.00 for painting the building and any other repairs and new equipment that might be urgently required.

Before ordering the supplies requested on the requisition forwarded with your recent letter it would be appreciated if you would discuss with the present Principal of the Norway House School how he considers the money provided in the current year's appropriation should be expended. As you are aware, the price of paint has increased considerably in the last few months and as a result the amount provided for painting may not be sufficient to do the whole building. It is felt, however, that the buildings at the Norway House School requiring paint most urgently should receive attention this year.

Memorandum: The Director
Surveys and Engineering
Branch.

With reference to Mr. Snellson's report of December 3rd last and Mr. Miller's memorandum on the subject of the sewage disposal system at Norway House, Man., it would appear to be advisable to give consideration to the carrying out of whatever work the engineers of your branch deem advisable at the present time, having in mind the existing conditions with respect to the low level of the water in Playgreen Lake and the Jack River.

I should, therefore, appreciate it if you would place the matter before the Minister's office with a view to having the necessary work carried out at the same time that the blasting of the channel for the water intake pipe is undertaken.

I understand that it has been decided, more or less definitely, to blast a channel into which to lower the water intake pipe and that your branch is, at present, trying to locate a man familiar with this kind of work. I also understand that this channel will only be wide enough for the pipe line and will not serve for purposes of navigation.

You are aware, I believe, of the difficulty that this branch is experiencing in finding funds for the work and I would suggest that you recommend to the Minister's office the carrying out of such work as is considered advisable and necessary to ensure the pipe line against freezing and the school, hospital and agency against the nuisance of exposed sewage and possible contamination of the water.

If you will advise me the total amount of funds required to carry out the work to be done in connection with both the water supply and sewage disposal, I shall arrange the transfer of the funds.

Director.

July 17th 1941.

Mr. R.A. Hoey
Supt., of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I have been advised in a letter from Mr. Phelin, through the Norway House Indian Agency, of the complete withdrawal of the current year's appropriation for the repair of this school, and the diversion of the funds to the repair of the water intake to the sum of $1500.00 and the installation of a refrigerator plant (mainly for the benefit of the hospital) to the sum of $800.00.

I have replied to Mr. Phelin's letter direct, protesting against this complete withdrawal of funds from the school to purposes which could and should have been estimated for separately by the Agency. It is impossible to provide repairs to the school out of current revenue, curtailed as it is at a time when commodity prices are considerably increased. There is every indication of a lack of economy in thus foregoing the necessary upkeep of the school buildings.

As to the levy on the school of the major part of the refrigeration plant: I have already planned to co-operate with the hospital as much as lies in the power of the school with a view to the better and more economic operations of the hospital. To this end, I am now supplying all the milk that the hospital requires for between thirty and forty patients and I have arranged to pasture and stall-feed sufficient beef to provide the hospital with meat. I also plan, when sufficient labour can be obtained, to provide poultry and eggs. To assist in this co-operation, I fully agree that a refrigerating plant was an asset to the hospital, but certainly the cost of the plant should be charged to the Medical Services and not react as a penalty against the school, when the school is making unusual effort to assist the hospital.

It would seem that in any attempt at co-operation between the school and the other units of Indian Administration, the school is placed in a position of disadvantage. I am fully in accord with every form of co-operation, but I feel that there should be more of equity in the arrangements. The matter of the cost of pipe line repairs and the refrigerator is a case in point. I feel it may be opportune at this time to refer to other matters that are obviously inequitable. There is the matter of the proportionate cost of electric power as between the school, the hospital, and the Agency and Doctor's residences.

As the proportion is now, the school is charged with 60% of the cost of operation of the plant, the Hospital 25% and the Agency and Drs Residence 15%. I understand that some adjustment was in process of being made whereby the Department would take over our engineer and assess us one half of the operating cost, presumably $2000.00 a year. However, no indication has been given that this new arrangement will soon be put into effect.

As matters stand now, in addition to the school being charged 60% of the operating cost, the services of Mr. Stevenson, engineer under school salary, have been required in the care of the lighting plant and repair of the water line to the extent of 46 full days between September and the 1st March. He has been occupied similarly since. All this the school has paid for. Also the school is paying the full salary of one of the engineers in charge of the plant.

This situation was acceptable as a temporary arrangement pending the proposed adjustment, but the inequality of the situation does not rest there. I do not know what the relative consumption of electric power between the different units was at the time of the change being suggested, but the present situation is that the Hospital has electrical apparatus using a capacity of some 18000 watts, the school machinery capacity is only about 4000 watts. Included in the hospital amount is a dryer, using 8000 watts, which has not yet been in use. Further, the lighting units in the hospital and the Agency and Drs residence consist of lamps of 100 watts and more, whereas the lamps in the school range from 25 to 60 watts.

Obviously it is impossible to determine the relative consumption of power by the capacity of the machinery installed, as none of the machinery is in regular use, but it is quite evident that the hospital uses at least as much power as the school and yet the hospital is charged with 25% of the cost and the school 60%.

I would suggest that the only equitable way of determining the consumption would be to install meters indicating the consumption of each unit; the school, the hospital and the residences. The installation of the meters would not be expensive, and on their reading the proportionate rate could be struck. I think this would only be fair.

I trust that this matter will be given consideration and that action will be soon taken to remove this considerable burden from the school.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Re: 1941 Appropriation.

Dear Sir,

Your letter to the Acting Indian Agent at Norway House, dated July 10th, referring to the proposed withdrawal of the whole of the amount already appropriated for repairs to this school during the current year, has been handed to me. I note that $1500.00 of our appropriation is to be diverted to the repair of the water intake, and $800.00 towards the installation of a refrigerating plant to be used jointly by the school and the hospital.

May I request that this matter be reconsidered by the Department officials, primarily on the grounds that the granting of the funds for the repair and upkeep of the school buildings is a matter of Department economy. Neglect to repair and upkeep may well mean the deterioration of the buildings and equipment to a point where repair may be no longer feasible, or, at least, much more expensive. Being well aware of the necessity for stringent economy during our war effort, the estimates were kept strictly within the bounds of absolute necessity.

I wish it further noted that no amounts were placed in the estimates of the school for the purposes to which it is now proposed to divert our whole appropriation. The matter of the repair to the water intake is recognised as a necessity, and, in fact, was so recognised in plenty of time to have had the item included in the estimates for the current year. However, this matter has been considered one for Agency estimate only, particularly when applied to pipeline construction on Agency property and before it comes on school property. Had it been recognised that the expense of this repair, or any part of it, was chargeable to school appropriation, provision could have been made for this in the school estimates over and above the repairs to the school. As it appears to me, this diversion of such a large amount from our school appropriation, given precedence over all the items in our school estimate, entirely without the previous knowledge or consent of the school, to a purpose for which the school had not the privilege of estimating, would seem to be quite unfair.

It would also appear that this diversion of appropriation falls more heavily on the school, by reason of the withdrawal of all estimate funds, than it does on the other Department units making equal use of the water supply. It should be considered further that the school has been undertaking much more than its rightful share in the upkeep of the water system. In addition to the payment of 60% of the operating cost, we are paying the entire wages of one on the engineers at the plant, and Mr. Stevenson, the school...
Mr. Phelin, (2)

[Redacted] has been giving a great deal of his time (while on school salary) to the repair and upkeep of the water and light plant. The total extent of his labour may be estimated from the fact that, from September last until March, he spent 46 full days working entirely on the plant and water intake. More of his time has been spent similarly since then. No consideration has been given the school for this contribution.

As to the installation of a refrigerating plant. It is conceded that this plant would be a decided asset and economy to the hospital. When the matter was first mentioned to me, I consumed in the appreciation of its value, especially as it had been suggested that the school undertake the supply of meat and milk to the hospital. This I am making plans to do, and, in fact, the milk is already being supplied. Obviously the refrigerating plant would be an asset here.

May I point out however, that the benefit of the plant would accrue almost entirely to the hospital. The school has its own ice house and cooler and much of our summer meat is put up in sealers in the Spring. It was certainly never anticipated in by me, or ever anticipated, that a sum of $800.00 would be arbitrarily taken from our approved repair appropriation for the purpose of building a refrigerator for the main use of the hospital. If this refrigerator is considered a necessity to the hospital, as it is in my opinion, then the full cost of the plant should be charged to the Medical Services. I wish to protest strongly against any part of the expenditure being so diverted from school appropriation.

I trust that the whole matter of the withdrawal of the whole of the school appropriation be reconsidered in view of the above aspect of the matter, and that the pared estimates submitted by the school, in conformity with the amount of appropriation approved, will be available for school purposes.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, July 31, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of July 17. Mr. Phelan has also received your letter of the same date to him.

I have carefully noted the contents of your letter, and I can assure you that every endeavour is being made to properly adjust the cost of electric power as between the school, the hospital and the agency and doctor's residence.

It has further been decided not to proceed with the proposed plans for new refrigeration installation.

It is only fair to departmental officials for me to point out that even though funds are provided for a specific purpose at a residential school, it is often found necessary to divert them to other more pressing matters. For instance, at the time the estimates for the current fiscal year were prepared we had no information indicating that heavy expenditures would be necessary in order to secure good water and sewage facilities. I know you will agree with me that when either water or sewage systems go out of order it is absolutely necessary to make repairs that are required. On the other hand, the amount of money available at the present time is strictly limited, and we cannot expend at any one school more than is actually provided for that school. I fully realize that principals of Indian residential schools have many serious problems to deal with at this time. I can assure you that departmental officials have these problems too, and we endeavour to handle them in the best interests of all parties concerned.

She was a child of the valley,
An innocent maiden was she;
He was a desperate Desmond,
Who owned all the town property,
He would pursue her through hills and through dells,
But she was wise to his game
Each time he threatened "You'll wed me or else"
These were the words she'd exclaim.

Chorus. No! No! a thousand times No!
You cannot buy my caress.
No! No! a thousand times No!
I'd rather die than say Yes.

Ah! but this poisonous villain,
He wouldn't leave her alone;
Said "Either join me in wedlock
Or I'll kick you out of your home."
She knew her people so feeble and old
Needed a roof o'er their head,
Winter would soon bring the snow and the cold,
Yet she defied him and said:

Cho. No! No! a thousand times No! etc.

That night he crept up to her window,
And Oh! how that villain could creep.
He stole her out of her boudoir,
And kidnapped her while fast asleep,
He tied the gal to the old railroad track,
The milk-train was rushing down hill,
She cried to him: "Though my future looks black,
Your buzzard, my answer is still:

Cho. No! No! a thousand times No!

Now she loved the young villager,
A muscled "He" man was he,
He rescued her from the clutches of death,
And they lived happily ever after.
