Dear Doctor Cochrane:

I desire to refer to your letter of September 5, 1940, and my reply of November 5 of the same year with reference to the Norway House Indian Residential School.

Owing to conditions of which you are no doubt aware it has been found necessary, within the last year, to install what we consider is a very modern power plant furnishing light and power to all Departmental buildings at Norway House.

As you are aware, we have been deducting a portion of the cost of the gasoline and oil from the per capita grant but at a conference of Departmental officials yesterday it was decided that a new proposition should be submitted to you. Our proposal is as follows:

1. The Department will be responsible for the cost of all the operation of the new power plant and in addition will pay Mr. Stevenson a salary of $1500.00 a year to superintend the plant. His employment is on the distinct understanding that he will devote his full time to the supervision of the plant.

2. As its share of the cost of the operation of this plant we request the Norway House Indian Residential School to pay the salaries of Mr. Ross and Mr. Duncan. I understand that this

We have carefully considered the above proposals and as far as this Branch is concerned the acceptance of them by you would facilitate our bookkeeping and, what is more important, would, we believe, supply the Norway House Residential School with water and light at a reasonable cost.

My dear Dr. McGill:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of January 14th, submitting a new proposition in regard to the cost of the power plant furnishing light and heat at Norway House.

Before giving you a final answer to your proposition, I should like, of course, to have the opportunity of consulting the Principal in regard to the matter. I am sending him an air mail letter today and ought to have his reply very shortly. On its receipt, I will write you again.

However, there is one part of the proposal to which I should like to refer now: Clause 2 suggests that the Norway House Indian School should pay the salaries of Mr. Ross and Mr. Duncan. My colleagues and I feel that the suggestion should be - not that we pay the salaries of two particular men, but that the School pay the salaries of the two men required to assist Mr. Stevenson - whoever they may be. Perhaps this is what you meant; but as the suggestion is worded now, it seems to tie us up to the two men who are at present doing the work. I should be glad if you would make this point clear.

Believe me,

There are, however, some things in connection with this new proposal which will require adjustment. First, there is the financial adjustment. The school has already paid for its share of the fuel and lubricating oils now on hand, a quantity sufficient to run the plant for several months. Obviously, the school should be credited with the money which it has invested in the fuel stock on hand at the time of the coming into effect of the new arrangement.

Second: Mr. Stevenson's appointment is from December 1st, 1941. I take it, therefore, that the school is expected to assume the wages of the engineer assistants from the same date. The 'cut-off' of the old agreement, then, would be December 1st. I am attaching the figures connected with this 'cut-off', showing the school to have the sum of $424.27 invested in the fuel stock on hand for the operation of the power plant at December 1st. In addition to this, there is the refund on empty drums, for which $354.00 was deducted from our June, 1941, grant, and $115.00 was (presumably) deducted from our September, 1941, grant, making a total refund on drums of $499.20. The total sum due the school for fuel on hand and empty drums is thus $923.47.

Third: There is need for further definite arrangement regarding the engagement of the two assistant engineers. I have discussed the proposed new terms with Mr. Lazenby, the Indian Agent, and I agree with him that employer authority over these two men should be vested in the Indian Agent. It would seem that the new proposal made by the Department arose out of either Government reluctance, or inability, to establish Civil Service positions for the two assistant engineers. Nevertheless, the time of these men should be entirely at the disposal of the power plant. I do not want them as school employees, as this would afford us no advantage, but it would be a decided advantage to the Indian Agency to have authority over these two employees. This need not necessarily indicate any change in the arrangement now proposed by the Department. All that would be necessary is for the Department to advise the Indian Agent that these two men would be under his authority (or Mr. Stevenson's, if preferable). I would pay the wages of these two men to the Agent and he would pay the men; there would be no need for them to be designated as Department employees and their wages need not be entered in the Agency books. Can this be arranged with the Department?

Lastly: There is the matter of the engineer's residence. It is conceded that a new residence is necessary. It was agreed that the school would give what assistance it could in the building of a new house, on school property. Thus we have on hand a supply of sawn lumber, about 4000 feet, sawn by Mr. Stevenson at the school, during school time. Also we can supply most of the labour, without expense to the school. Further than this I have made no agreement. Mr. Stevenson has been making plans to get
the residence started next spring. I had placed in the 1942 estimates a sum of $1000.00 for assistance in building this engineer's residence. All this was feasible under the last agreement with the Department, where the services of the engineer would be available for the school. Now the situation has changed. Mr. Stevenson has been given a salary of $1500.00 a year instead of the expected $1200.00. He is an exclusive employee of the Department. (It is intimated in Dr. McGill's letter that the school would have to engage another man in Mr. Stevenson's place). Any residence built for the engineer should now be built on Government property (Agency), and with an 'administration' appropriation - not 'educational', - particularly as the letter notifying the Indian Agent of Mr. Stevenson's appointment states that the remuneration for the position of engineer had been set at $1500.00 a year with house, power and water. No mention is made in this letter of any obligation assumed, or to be assumed, by the school, in the matter of the supply of a residence.

Just what is the position now? I am still willing to use the material which has been accumulated for the purpose of building this residence, and also to supply our own labour, but this could only be on condition that the building be built on school property and become the property of the school. In these circumstances, also, as is at present understood, the school could not undertake the building of this residence unless appropriation was made by the Department for such material for the house as the school could not provide without expense.

Some suggestion was made last year by the Secretary of the Department that the school should provide the residence. What would we provide it with? The school is not obligated to provide buildings, equipment or repairs out of the per capita grant. All this expense is normally the responsibility of the Department. The per capita grant is, I understand, simply for operating expense. The suggestion that the school build the residence, therefore, just does not make sense. As I have said, I see no objection to the school providing labour and home-produced material for the building, but we certainly cannot undertake any money expense in connection with it.

However, if the position of engineer has been created and the terms of the appointment are that the engineer should receive a salary with a house provided, surely that obligates the Department to providing the house. According to the previous plans, the Department was evidently looking to the school to at least give assistance in the building of the residence, and this the school was prepared to do. Does the Department regard this arrangement as continuing under the new plan for payment of power costs? This point might be cleared up, and Mr. Stevenson advised of the Department's definite intention regarding the providing of a residence. Mr. Stevenson states that it will be impossible to use his present house another winter. Although, as a business matter, I feel that this now does not concern the school, yet this fact should be known and appreciated by the Department, in the interests of the comfort of their engineer."

Dear Dr. Gaskins,

Re: Norway House Indian Residential School.

I have your letter of the 9th of February and extract from Mr. Caldwell's letter to you regarding the light and power plant at Norway House, and particularly the construction of the residence required for Mr. Stevenson, who has been appointed as Electric Power Plant Operator.

With regard to the question of paying the school for the investment made in fuel, oil, etc., on hand as of December 1st, I agree that the department should refund to the school the amount of their investment, and I intend having the figures shown on the statement attached to Mr. Caldwell's letter checked after which a refund will be made.

The suggestion that the Day and Night Operators of the Plant be placed under the control of the Indian Agent and be made directly responsible to the Plant Operator, their time to be entirely at our disposal and payment of their salary made to the Indian Agent, meets with approval, and I shall make the necessary arrangements with the Indian Agent to this effect.

The only point on which I am not in complete agreement with Mr. Caldwell is the question of the residence for Mr. Stevenson. The school indicated on several occasions either directly or through the Indian Agent its willingness to co-operate in the construction of the residence by furnishing home-produced materials, providing the department would appropriate a sufficient sum for the purchase of materials and equipment which could not be obtained at Norway House. An official of the department is to visit Norway House during the month of March, and I am asking him to discuss the question more fully with
the Principal and the Indian Agent, as it would not appear to be desirable to have the residence erected on school property and become the property of the school, when the department has a certain investment in the building.

We have, I might add, met the school's request to provide a sum of $1,000 for the finishing of the residence, on the understanding that the school would fulfil its agreement, but we were not able to make provision for the complete construction of a new building owing to the need for economy and for the reason that we expected the school's co-operation.

I shall write you at a later date when I receive the report of the official of this branch upon his return from Norway House.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Lumber costs.

Dear Sir,

When Mr. Atkinson, Government engineer, was here repairing the water pipe line, he required a quantity of lumber. The school had lumber on hand which had been sawn from logs and which was seasoning for school building purposes. Mr. Atkinson was permitted to use some of this lumber with the proviso that an equal quantity be returned to the school next spring. This Mr. Atkinson agreed to recognizing that lumber which we might saw this winter to replace that which he had taken would not be sufficiently dry for use before next fall.

I was surprised therefore to receive a letter from Mr. Atkinson dated Dec. 2nd, in which he said that he had issued account to the Department for the lumber, 1119 feet, at a price of $20.00 per thousand feet. In the same mail, also, I received a cheque from the Department for $22.38 in payment for the lumber.

To replace this lumber with dry lumber from the City would cost the school in the neighbourhood of $50.00 per thousand, plus $12.50 freight. I doubt whether the school could produce this lumber for $20.00 per thousand, considering permits, labour and other costs. However, our particular grievance is that we had sawn this lumber so that we would have it on hand, dry, next spring, and ready to use. It is true that the lumber supplied to Mr. Atkinson was not edged, but the measurement was liberally figured as though it had been edged.

Could I trouble you to refer this to the official to which it pertains, with a request for adjustment? As you know, the school took its share in the work of repair of the pipe line in the withdrawal of its appropriation.

Thanking you,

Yours sincerely,

You will recall the decision made to have the light and power plant expenses provided for under one vote, and have an engineer appointed to have complete charge of the plant, direct the men employed as Day and Night Operators, and be responsible for everything in connection with the operation, maintenance and repair of the plant as well as other machinery at Norway House.

You will also recall that it was decided to assess the Residential School $2,000.00 a year for the light and power used, based on the assumption that the school used 60% of the power generated by the plant, this sum to be deducted from the school's per capita grant.

As you know Mr. Stevenson was appointed to the position of Light and Power Plant Operator on December 1st, 1941, and the proper time, therefore, to commence the new arrangements regarding the operation of the plant was, therefore, December 1st. In discussing the question with you, I understand, you pointed out that the vote bearing the expenses of the plant could not be credited with the sum paid by the school, and it was therefore decided to secure approval for a change in the proposed arrangement and ask the school to pay the expenses of the Day and Night Operators' salaries. Approval for this has been secured, and the school authorities have agreed to the arrangement.

If the expenses of the plant are to be assumed by the department, as of December 1st, 1941, the date of Mr. Stevenson's appointment, it would appear necessary to reimburse the school for any expenditures they have made for purchase of fuel oil, etc., and I would ask for your opinion of the statement attached to letter of February 9th from Rev. I believe that it is only fair and reasonable that we should refund to the school the sum of $424.27 for the 60% of the cost of the fuel oil, etc., but I am doubtful as to how much refund on the empty drums they should be credited with, and would appreciate your advice.

Memorandum:

The Director
Surveys and Engineering Branch

You will recall that last fall Engineer Atkinson went to Norway House and blasted a channel in which the pipeline was placed in order to ensure protection from frost and a satisfactory supply of the water for the buildings. I understand that the blasted trench was 5' deep and extended from the shoreline to a deep channel on a length of about 1800' and that at the shoreline he drove in sheath piling in a semi-circle for a distance of about 10', which piling projected out of the water a little over a foot.

I understand also that from this sheath piling to the powerhouse on a distance of 200' he built a fill of earth approximately 6' deep and 12' wide and that mid-way in this fill he inserted a 4 foot square man hole.

This spring the water rose 4' and extended in on the sides of the fill and washed the fill away so that at the present time the sheath piling is covered with water and water now lies where the fill was. I also understand that our Engineer, Mr. Stevenson, was of the opinion at the time the work was being carried out that the sides of the fill should have been cribbed. This could not have been done in the spring when the water started to rise as the frost was still in the ground. It would appear that the possibility of a change in the water level was not realized when the job was carried out with the above results.

Our Engineer, Mr. Stevenson, proposes to tongue and groove 2" planks at the Agency saw-mill and drive these in, in the form of a sheath piling along the sides and end of the old fill, then fill this cribbing with dirt. He then proposes to tie the tops of the piles with squared logs thus making a water tight box into which no muskrats can get. The estimated cost of carrying
out the work is $400, and as the season at Norway House is short we propose to authorize the carrying out of the work under the supervision of Mr. Stevenson and as outlined by him. We will, however, be very glad to receive any suggestions or recommendations your Branch wishes to make in the matter.

Director.
July 21, 1942.

Dear Sirs,

I have your letter of the 17th of June advising me that the temporary cribbing and filling covering the water intake pipe at Norway House which was put in place last fall by Engineer Atkinson has washed away owing to the higher water level.

I also understand that in order to remedy this condition Mr. Stevenson recommends driving in tongued and grooved 2" planks in the form of a sheath piling along the sides and end of the old fill, filling the cribbing with dirt and tying the piles together with squared logs in order to make a watertight box.

We have advised the Surveys and Engineering Branch of the work Mr. Stevenson proposes to carry out to correct the present condition and have informed them that we intend to authorize this work, but will welcome their suggestions and recommendations if they wish to make any. I note from your letter of June 17 that the estimated cost of the work is $400. This sum is being set aside and advanced to you in order that Mr. Stevenson may proceed with the work.

In order to keep the cost as low as possible it is thought that the school should furnish teams and men for the job. This would cut the cost of labour considerably, also that the Interpreter or one of the labourers on your staff should assist Mr. Stevenson in any team or saw-mill work and thus do away with the wages of one man. It should be possible for you to arrange with the Principal of the school to furnish teams and men for this job without cost to the Department and I should very much appreciate it if you would discuss the matter with Mr. Caldwell pointing out that the expenditure was unforeseen and consequently not provided for and the Department would be very grateful for their co-operation and assistance.

It should also be possible for you to assign the Interpreter to assist Mr. Stevenson in carrying out this very important work for the length of time that Mr. Stevenson will require his services.

Yours very truly,

P. G. Lasenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House.

T. R. MacInnes,
Secretary.
July 21, 1943.

Dear Sir:

We have received a report that the work carried out last fall by Engineer Atkinson in connection with the laying of the water pipeline at Norway House in a channel has largely been destroyed owing to the raising of the water level.

I am informed that it is necessary to have sheath piling built along the sides and end of the old fill in order to make a sort of watertight box.

This expenditure was not contemplated and therefore not provided for and owing to the very limited funds available it would be appreciated if the school could furnish teams and men to assist Mr. Stevenson in carrying out the necessary work. We are, I might add, arranging with Indian Agent Lazenny, to have one of the members of our staff, preferably the Interpreter give as much assistance to Mr. Stevenson as possible in order to save the wages of one man.

We would appreciate very much your co-operation in this matter in order to keep down the labour costs.

Yours very truly,

Notes on construction details & labour.

Dear Sir;

On checking over ground level of basement of engineers residence to be built, I find the sewer will be only 2 feet below the surface of the ground where it enters the house. The basement will have to go down four feet to be below frost line. The sewer will leave the building two feet above the basement floor. These measurements are based on a fall of 1 foot in 100 feet, for the sewer between my residence and Mr. Caldwell's residence.

Mr. Caldwell does not wish to have his lawn dug up to put the sewer in, and would rather have it connected in his basement. This is quite feasible but the sewer pipe is so close to the surface of his basement floor that the use of vitrified tile would make a lump on the floor at each joint. To overcome this I would suggest a length of 4 inch pipe (about 22 feet) carry the sewage across that floor.

When you were here March 11th last Mr. Caldwell suggested a lath and plaster finish. I doubt if the house can be finished in time to get the plasterer home on the last boat. The cost of bringing in a plasterer will be high. And will it be possible to secure the services of a plasterer at this time? Failing a plasterer I would suggest returning these lath and getting pli-board or one of the better wallboards. I can put this on myself. It would require 104 pieces of 4 ft. by 8 ft. board.

With regard to the toilet for this house. If you will recall, the school was to supply the toilet out of its stock. At the present time they have used all their stock, and I understand the school requisition has not yet been handed into the Indian Dept. This means a toilet will have to be purchased either by the School or Indian department.

The labor situation, - I have built foundation and skidway for sawmill, moved sawmill building about fifty feet, set up sawmill, made temporary set-up of planer and edged all the lumber for engineers residence with but little help from one of the powerhouse operators. Occasionally help from the agency staff when there was an extra heavy log to put up. Is it not possible for me to have more help to push along the work?
There is gravel to be hauled for the foundation of the refrigerator.

Foundation for same dug out & concrete run.
Refrigerator constructed.
Repairs to hospital roof.
Rebuilding of Agency root house.
Rebuilding of Agency dock.
Cribbing water intake.
Construction of engineer's residence.
Digging out and relaying 50 ft. of sewer pipe between doctor's house and Agency residence (someone in the past layed 6 in. sewer from the doctor's residence, then contracted it to 4 inches half way to the Agency house. This has plugged and backed into the doctors basement over a period of time)

With these projects before us I would point out that the Indians leave for their winter trapline in the latter part of September. We must act quickly to get our work in hand by that date. I would suggest an immediate start on gravel for the refrigerator foundation.

Yours very truly,

R.L.Stevenson
Engineer.

P.S. Two men left this morning to get logs to rebuild roothouse.

R.L.S.

Dear Sir;-

Mr. Lazenby has gone on an extended Treaty trip inland. Mr. Caldwell has been absent from Norway House nearly three weeks and no work has been done on the engineers residence.

Time flies. - I do not wish to remain in Norway House another winter and have to live in this old house.

To put on record what has transpired to date.

In the past money earned by me at odd jobs about this settlement together with that received from the Indian Affairs Branch for lumber used last fall by engineer Atkinson, was put into a trust fund in the School. To date the sum of some sixty eight dollars stands to this credit. This was to be used for the buying of necessities in the completion of the engineers house.

We were short of inch lumber to complete the engineers residence. On a co-operative basis I assisted the School farm manager for five days, June 23rd - to 26th, in getting out logs for school class rooms, and twenty logs I required. I also gave this time to instruct the farm operator in the operation of the boat engine and barge work. Mr. Caldwell was absent at this time but before leaving he instructed me to hire whatever men were necessary to get in the logs. One man was required. I turned this man's time in to Mr. Caldwell on his return June 26th. He informed me this man's wages would be charged against the above mentioned $8 dollars. Since the man was getting out school logs Caldwell finally paid the man. The gist of the conversation which followed was that I had $68. to pay for labor to build the engineers residence. I immediately took the matter up with Mr. Lazenby. Mr. Caldwell shortly followed to the Agent's office and after much talk declared he would resign before he would put a dollar into labor for building the house. He stamped out of the office at that but returned in a minute and said he had three men working for the school, who would work on the house July and August when they were not carrying out their routine duties.

He talked continuously of getting his classrooms built this summer. I pointed out that he could not build out of green lumber not yet sawn. Also that there were more projects up than
we were likely to get finished this fall. I mentioned also that if he would co-operate with us a bit we would get the engineers residence built, and his lumber sawn, planed and seasoned to build next spring. Mr. Caldwell seemed to think this a good idea. He left for Winnipeg shortly after, and although I have asked repeatedly for help the acting principal, Mr. King, always states that the men are fully occupied at the school.

We require, boat, barge, gasoline and help to get gravel for foundation.

Basement excavated.
Sewer trench excavated.
Lumber moved to planer & from planer to site of building.
Erection of framework.

Following erection of framework I can do most of the constructing providing I can get time from the numerous other projects that will be going forward.

I am taking the liberty of addressing you on this subject, you being the only member of the Indian Affairs Branch that I have the honor of being acquainted with. Also because you are cognizant with what has gone before.

I beg to enclose herewith a few notes on details.

Thanking you for your co-operation and interest in the past,

I am

Yours very truly,

R.L. Stevenson.
Engineer.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, enclosing the statement of materials requested by the Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School. This list has been reviewed and it is difficult for us to understand why so many items, which are ordinarily replaced immediately, have been allowed to accumulate. I feel that both the Principal and yourself should realize that, in view of the many demands occasioned by the war, this is a very difficult year to secure many of the items mentioned on the Principal's list. Besides, the information given in the majority of cases is insufficient for us to place the matter before the Purchasing Branch. For instance, the Principal requests 12 single beds but does not state the size he needs.

We do not supply electric light bulbs. Such replacements are made by the school management from their own funds.

We are interested in knowing how many of the items mentioned on the list are intended for the new classroom building. With regard to the request for a furnace for this building, is it intended to heat it by hot water or by hot air? If the latter, the cubic air space should be stated, as this information is necessary before deciding on the size of the furnace required.

The Department is not prepared to consider purchasing the hay scythes, "fittings", faucets or bath connections. All of these are in the same class with the electric light bulbs, namely, minor replacements, and should be provided by the school management from their own funds.

I enclose the list, in order that you may furnish more specific information regarding the necessity

Dear Sir,

I have your copy of letter received from Mr. Lazenby dated August 11th, returning the list of requirements for this school for more specific information. I have revised the list and cut it down to the lowest possible quantities to ensure operation of the plumbing and heating facilities during the coming winter months. I note that the plumbing fittings should be provided for out of the school funds. May I point out that these items have always been estimated for and have always been supplied by the Department. Many of the items in this connection are replacements of parts taken from the school stock for the plumbing and fixtures for the engineer's residence and thus our stock is depleted much beyond the safety margin for necessary winter repairs.

I trust that the Department will reconsider the suggestion that such items be no longer supplied.

With the exception of the desks and the furnace no item in the requisition is to be used in the construction of the new class-rooms. The desks are necessary, as we are now employing two teachers in the residential school, keeping the junior grades in full time class-room work. Under the late arrangement whereby our junior children attended the day schools when this was first instituted years ago, some of the desks from the residential school were transferred to the day school. Only three or four of these desks in the day school are now available to the residential school.

The extra beds are made necessary for replacement of beds beyond repair and to offset the beds now used on the balconies for resting patients (preventorium), accommodation given by the school at the request of Dr. Moore.

Some of the steam registers requisitioned are also designed for the heating of these balconies and also to replace some cracked registers in the school.

The furnace designed for the class-rooms is a hot air furnace, as, on the advice of the engineer, it is impossible to convey heating to the class-rooms from the steam system in the school.

I trust that this gives you the information you require,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

The enclosed letter has just been received from Mr. Anderson of the Vulcan Iron Works Limited.

Mr. Anderson stated the rate of pay is $1.50 per hour, with time and a half for overtime. There is also a definite agreement with the boiler welders that they will be paid for a ten hour day while travelling. ACCEPTANCE OF SHIPMENT AND BREAKAGE

The goods covered by the attached invoice were receipted for by the Railroad Company as having been received by them in good condition and properly packed. It is necessary to accept the shipment from the Railroad Company as is your duty to assure yourself that all articles enumerated on the bill of lading are included in the shipment and in good condition. To protect yourself against loss or damage in transit, check the shipment carefully with your bill of lading, noting the number of crates or packages and their condition. Any parts broken by the Railroad Company will be duplicated free of charge by us on the following conditions only:

First—The consignee must not give the Railroad Company a clear receipt for the complete shipment if there is any shortage, breakage or damage of any kind. In the event there is any shortage, or if any part of the shipment is damaged, the consignee can give a receipt for the goods if the railroad agent will make a notation on the freight bill indicating the amount of the shortage or the extent and nature of the damage. This freight bill must be mailed to us.

If the breakage or damage is concealed and not discovered until the goods are unpacked, notify the Agent of the Railroad Company by letter or telephone to call immediately and examine the shipment. The carrier is equally responsible for "Concealed Damage" as for visible damage and when notified as suggested it places the burden of proof upon the carrier. When you have given the Railroad Company notice in the manner suggested, mail us your bill of lading and paid freight bill.

Second—When there is shortage, breakage or damage in an express shipment, request your Express Agent to furnish you receipt showing the condition in which the shipment was delivered to you.

Third—When you report shortage or breakage to us, enumerate fully and describe clearly the parts you desire replaced. In ordering standards for School Desks specify size and whether right or left, which is always determined as you sit at the desk. It is well to supplement your order by mentioning the pattern mark you will find on the piece. If several styles of desks, be sure to specify the style for which the parts are desired, particularly if wooden parts are being ordered. Care in making your order clear and complete will permit us to give you immediate service.

Fourth—All claims for shortage, breakage or damage must be made within Thirty Days and you must provide us with the necessary papers to enable us to file claim against the Railroad or Express Company, as explained in Paragraphs No. 1 and No. 2. Otherwise claim will not be allowed.

Fifth—We are not responsible for parts broken through carelessness of drayman hauling the goods or your workmen in assembling and installing.

STORAGE

The desks manufactured under this contract were constructed from thoroughly air seasoned and properly kiln-dried material and were in perfect condition when shipment left our factory. This does not mean that parts will remain perfect regardless of local atmospheric conditions. Under no condition should the crates containing the wood be stored in a damp or basement nor in a partly completed structure where building material, such as plaster, calcimine, paint, etc., may be thrown over the crates. Store in a dry, well ventilated room of normal uniform temperature. The crates containing woods should rest on their ends and all crates and boxes be elevated above floor a few inches to allow free air circulation under and around them.

CLEANING AND POLISHING

Do not attempt to clean or polish the woodwork with linseed oil, turpentine, unadulterated benzine, gasoline, alcohol, or anything of that kind. These materials are dangerous solvents which soften the varnish and spoil the finish; nor do we recommend any one of the various furniture polishes on the market. Dear Sir,-

The bricklayer will arrive on the next boat. He will need two or three good workers and you should arrange to have these men ready to start. You know the usual rate of pay allowed there for laborers and you can voucher for payment, showing the number of days and the rate per day. Show this as helpers required for assisting bricklayer.

The Department will expect the bricklayer and boiler-welder to be supplied with board and room by the institution in which he is working.

This is an expensive repair job, both as to material and labour, and you should see to it that every minute counts, and allow no delays that can possibly be avoided.

Attached is correspondence re arrangement with the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel for bricklayer, also a copy of a letter to Vulcan Iron Works re the boiler-welder.

The extra labour required to assist the bricklayer and boiler-welder was not mentioned to Ottawa, but we must provide helpers and I have explained to both companies that good men could be secured at Norway House and it would not be necessary to take men from Winnipeg and thus incur extra travelling expenses and higher wages.

Yours very truly,

ENCLS.
Dear Sir,

Re: Boiler-welders at Norway House.

The boiler-welder from the Vulcan Iron Works and the bricklayer from the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel are leaving today by boat for Norway House.

Mr. Anderson of the Vulcan Iron Works said it was advisable to have these men on the job at the same time, so he delayed other work in order that the welder might leave today; which is a week ahead of his promised date. However, in view of the weather I am glad the men are getting away.

I enclose, for your information, copy of a letter sent to Mr. Lazenby, the Indian Agent. If these men are working in the school I see no reason why the institution cannot supply board and room. Helpers will be needed and to avoid the extra expense of taking men from Winnipeg, I have instructed Mr. Lazenby to supply Indian help and voucher for payment.

I feel certain the work will be well done and I trust the arrangements meet with the Department's approval.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have your letter of Sept. 12th, received on my return from Winnipeg.

The Welder and Bricklayer came on the boat leaving Winnipeg Sept. 21st. I had arranged for two good men to attend them, mixing mortar, etc. Gravel and sand was hauled for the work. Board and room was made available in the school.

The welder finished his work and left on the boat of the 30th Sept. The bricklayer had a much longer job, but finished last night and is leaving on the boat today, which, we understand, is the last boat of the season.

Some overtime has been worked by these men, but, in both cases, it would have meant remaining over another boat if they had not worked overtime. I am satisfied that a good job has been done, the boilers and pressure tanks are now in good condition and should, with the proper care, be good for many more years.

Ottawa, December 24th, 1942.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Man.

The Department was surprised to receive your telegram of the 23rd instant in which you stated that the high pressure boiler at the Norway House Residential School was so corroded that a replacement was immediately necessary. However, in view of your statement that there was a boiler surplus to requirements at the Norway House hospital, we wired you today authorizing its use.

In your letter of 25th August you requested repairs to the two heating boilers and the high pressure boiler. Recently we received an account amounting to approximately $1,500 for repairs to the boilers at this school, and we presume that this account included repairs to the high pressure boiler. In view of this, you can understand why we could not believe that a new boiler was necessary at this school.

I would appreciate having your comments.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I acknowledge your letter 123-5-5 dated December 23rd, 1942, and am returning the account submitted as requested.

It was around September 1st before I received word to proceed with this work. I tried for a week to secure a bricklayer with boiler experience without success. In view of the fact that I was strongly advised not to accept anyone except an experienced boiler bricklayer, I consulted Mr. Anderson, of the Vulcan Iron Works. He explained that only competent men should be sent in to these outlying points and stated that their Company worked with the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel and he thought they might supply a man.

I went to this Company and Mr. Thrifall said it was short notice and all his men were out of the city, but he would let me know what he could do. He also agreed to interview the boiler inspector and find out just what was required. A few days later Mr. Thrifall agreed to bring in a man providing the arrangements suggested were agreeable, namely, that his Company was to have ten per cent over all cost. I outlined all this in my letter 207-11 A.U., dated September 11th, and this arrangement was approved in a wire dated September 14th.

I did, however, secure a quotation over the telephone from the Alasip Brick and Tile Company and this was slightly higher. Had it been the same I could hardly have done otherwise than give it to the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel, because they were the only ones willing to supply a suitable man and guarantee his work.

We are in a War and skilled labor is difficult to get. This Company, at considerable inconvenience to themselves, accepted the work - brought in a man off another job, where work stood still till his return. They have, I understand given us a splendid piece of work; and I am confident I made no mistake when I accepted Mr. Anderson's suggestion and gave the work to the Winnipeg Supply and Fuel. The Company has been out considerable money and I hope the account will be passed for payment without further delay.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

It is herewith recommended that a wooden stairway type fire escape equipped with balconies and handrail be installed on the rear wall of the building, and to extend from the third floor to the ground level.

It is also recommended that a wooden stairway type fire escape equipped with handrail be installed in the front balconies from the third floor at a point where an easy exit may be made from the junior boys' dormitory on the third floor and the senior girls' dormitory on the second floor, and to extend to the ground floor, in this way making all balconies communicating.

It is also recommended that a wooden stairway equipped with handrail be installed in the front balcony from the third floor at a point where easy exit may be made from the senior boys' dormitory on the third floor and the junior girls' dormitory on the second floor, and to extend to the ground floor, in this way making all balconies communicating.

While making his inspection, the inspector noted that smokepipes from the kitchen stove were in close proximity to a combustible wall or partition. It is herewith recommended that the smokepipes be kept at least twelve inches from any combustible wall or ceiling, or that the combustible wall or ceiling be insulated with at least 3/8" asbestos covered with metal.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.:

In reply to Mr. R.A. Hoey's letter No; 123-5-5 of the 24th December, regarding the replacing of the high pressure boiler at the Norway House Residential School with one not in use at the Hospital, I beg to say that when the boiler welder was here repairing the heating boilers at the school last fall, he opened up and cleaned out the high pressure boiler, and found that there was a very considerable amount of corrosion inside it; so much so, that he could not get it thoroughly cleaned out in the one operation. Successive washing out have brought to light the fact that the corrosion had eaten right through the boiler in some places, so that it was not considered safe to use. The boiler welder stated that this had been the result of the boiler not having been regularly washed out and properly cared for during some years past, but the corrosion had been allowed to continue without attention, instead of being washed out at least once every three months.

This boiler, I may say, was installed new at the school in 1935, just a little over seven years ago.

Since the receipt of Mr Hoey's letter, we have made some attempts to figure out the materials and the best way of constructing these fire escapes, but without much success, and there was no one at Norway House with any experience in this kind of work. However, recently a Mr Joe Keeper, an employee of the Hudson's Bay Company, who is a carpenter, returned to Norway House from some building work he had been doing for the Company, and I got him to give us some assistance.

In figuring out the escapes recommended by the Manitoba Provincial Fire Commissioner for the School, one only was figured on, for the rear of the building, as shown on the estimate attached hereto. The fire commissioner recommended two of these stairway escapes for the front of the building, but discussing this with the Principal and Mr Keeper, we were all of the opinion that this would be of no advantage at all over the four fire escape poles now in use, and by means of which, the Principal informs me, the whole of the school pupils and staff can be evacuated in less than two minutes. This, could certainly not be improved upon with stairway type fire escapes, - in fact it is thought that the substitution of stairway escapes would be a move in the wrong direction.

I may mention, that the concrete foundations of this school are in very bad shape, and getting worse each year. They are badly cracked in several places, and during the winters they heave with the frost and they are getting more and more out of shape and position.

August 24th 1943.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have been expecting to hear through the Agency about the appropriation granted on our 1943 estimates, but to date no information has been received. I am anxious to hear before the end of navigation, which, by the way, may be considerably earlier this year on account of shortage of wood put up on Lake Winnipeg for fuel for the passenger and freight boat.

Unless I can find some means of providing more stabling accommodation for our stock here at Norway House, it is almost a necessity that I dispose of at least some of the stock before winter sets in. I have been keeping some of the stock at the farm at Hope Island during the winter, necessitating the extra employment of a family there. In the present necessity for economy, I find that keeping this extra help will not be possible, even if it were not for the fact that the stable buildings at Hope Island, which are logs, are so deteriorated that they are not suitable for winter care of stock. It would be very regrettable to have to dispose of the stock. When I came here two years ago there were only 7 head of milk cattle here and the Principal had determined to go out of cattle altogether, as being too much expense. I saw some opportunity of overcoming this by undertaking the supply of milk and meat to the Hospital. Since that time I have increased our stock so that I have now some nine or ten head of cattle to kill each fall, and plenty of milk for the hospital and the school. Just at present my stock stands as follows:

- 40 head cattle, of all ages,
- 23 pigs, including brood sows and boar.
- 27 Goats, 12 milking.
- 5 Horses.

My plan is to winter all this stock (some 9 head of cattle and 20 pigs will be butchered at Freeze-up) here at the school, eliminating Hope Island expense. I will require additional space for about ten head of cattle and the goats. Until such time as we can get either a new barn or a proper addition to the old one, lean-to buildings could be used. These could be built with lumber sawed from logs obtained locally, with the addition of shingles. The cost of getting the logs and the building would be approximately $500.00

The cattle are a really fine herd. Whether it would be better to go to the expense of adequately stabling them cannot be doubted.
It would be almost impossible to build up such a herd again under present conditions. Further, the expense of shipping cattle in the fall to supply the Hospital and the school with meat would be almost prohibitive. However, in the present financial situation, where the school is actually operating, or trying to operate, on a 30% increase cost of operation (figuring supplies and wages) with a revenue of 21% less than pre-war, is manifestly impossible, without the most rigid economy. Even with this economy, a deficit is bound to accumulate.

To complicate matters, the hay supply is most inadequate this year. The water is very high and has covered most of our hay grounds, which are located along the banks of the river and lakes. Where I should have normally at least 100 tons of hay put up, I will be fortunate this year to get 50. This has had to be cut mainly on islands in Playgreen Lake and has to be hauled in some cases 20 miles. Formerly, during seasons of high water, the Indians were accustomed to cut the hay in the water, spreading it out to dry. This was not uncommon. Under present conditions however, with so much work being available in the harvest fields (over 100 men have left this reserve along for the harvest) it is impossible to get men to cut hay. However, I am fortunate in having a good crop of oats which will be cut green and stacked. In this way, I may be able to manage, with careful feeding, through the winter. The stabling room, however, is most necessary.

We have a really fine herd of goats. They have been a distinct liability thus far. I could make some revenue selling the goats milk to the hospital, but the Doctor expects to get the goat's milk at the same price as cows milk (until recently we were supplying cows milk to the Hospital at 5¢ per quart, this has now been increased to 10¢). Goats milk sells normally at about 35¢ per quart, and I would rather use it at the school than sell it at such a low cost.

We have been unfortunate in our kid production during the last two years. This year, out of 15 kids, only 3 are nannies. The Billies are useless, of course, except for the small supply of goat meat which they provide. It is impossible to account for this adverse production of kids. I am changing the Billy this year. I have even suggested to Dr. Corrigan that there might be a chance to get some real results with his Vitamins in our goat herd.......but he does not seem to take kindly to the idea.

Our pigs are a real asset. I have a very fine type of Yorkshire and they have done remarkably well considering the very meagre and primitive accommodation we have for them. I wish we could have even a little of the fine accommodation and housing some other schools have.

I wish to make a note of the labour and staff problem. As you know, I received material to erect new outside class-rooms, we to supply all the material and labour that could be obtained here.
wing to the shortage of labour (for logging, hauling and building) I have been as yet unable to build this building. In fact, were the labour available, finances would not permit at present of the expenditure entailed. I have the material supplied stored in the warehouse where it will not deteriorate, and this work will be proceeded with as soon as opportunity affords. In the meantime, I am using the old outside class-room for the senior pupils.

I have also gone into egg and poultry production, which has not been introduced here. I have had some 40 chickens for over a year, and this year I purchased 200 day old chicks, out of which 170 have matured. Some of these will provide poultry for the hospital, but I will have about 150 in egg production during the winter. It was necessary to build a chicken house, which is partially complete and needs to be lined and insulated for the winter.

This gives an outline of our live stock situation. There can be no doubt that our stock has contributed very greatly to the economical operation of the school. I do not know what we would have done during these difficult times had we not built up our live stock during the past two years. I feel that more land, (if it were obtainable within convenient reach of the school) and adequate stabling, is necessary to the continued better operation. What can be done under the present circumstances I do not know, but I am putting the situation before you.

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd) A.E.Caddwell.

I don't know whether Mr. Lazenby has taken up with the Department the matter of the construction of a barge to haul wood and hay. I have discussed it with him and he agrees to the necessity. The old barge is useless. I tried to use it this summer in the hauling of wood, but the hull is so rotten that it cannot be kept bailed out. In hauling our hay I purchased two old lake fishing boats (about 30 feet long) these are tied together and a rack put over them on which the hay is piled for hauling, then towed with a gas boat. The whole thing is very primitive but it is necessary expedient.

I beg to advice that I have received a letter from Mr. R. A. Stuart, Deputy Minister of the Manitoba Provincial Department of Labour, in which he states that their Inspector Mr. M. Del Begio made the following recommendations after making his inspection of the boilers etc. at the Norway House Indian Residential School:

**Dumb Waiter.**

1. The installation of a proper counterbalance weight to run on guide rails in replacement of the present weight.

2. Shaftway to be lined with a fire-resisting material, metal, if possible, but if not, gyprock board.

**Laundry.**

1. Install cover on laundry extractor. The present condition is dangerous as machine should not be operated without cover.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been expecting to hear through the Agency about the appropriation granted on our 1943 estimates, but to date no information has been received. I am anxious to hear before the end of navigation, which, by the way, may be considerably earlier this year on account of shortage of wood put up on Lake Winnipeg for fuel for the passenger and freight boat.

Unless I can find some means of providing more stabling accommodation for our stock here at Norway House, it is almost a necessity that I dispose of at least some of the stock before winter sets in. I have been keeping some of the stock at the farm at Hope Island during the winter, necessitating the extra employment of a family there. In the present necessity for economy, I find that keeping this extra help will not be possible, even if it were not for the fact that the stable buildings at Hope Island, which are log, are so deteriorated that they are not suitable for winter care of stock. It would be very regrettable to have to dispose of the stock. When I came here two years ago there were only 7 head of milk cattle here and the Principal had determined to go out of cattle altogether, as being too much expense. I saw some opportunity of overcoming this by undertaking the supply of milk and meat to the hospital. Since that time I have increased our stock so that I have now some nine or ten head of cattle to kill each fall, and plenty of milk for the hospital and the school. Just at present my stock stands as follows:

- 40 head cattle, of all ages
- 23 pigs, including brood sows and boar
- 27 goats, 12 milking
- 5 horses

My plan is to winter all this stock (some 9 head of cattle and 20 pigs will be butchered at freeze-up) here at the school, eliminating Hope Island expense. I will require additional space for about ten head of cattle and the goats. Until such time as we can get either a new barn or a proper addition to the old one, lean-to buildings could be used. These could be built with lumber sawed from logs obtained locally, with the addition of shingles. The cost of getting the logs and the building would be approximately $500.00.
The cattle are a really fine herd. Whether it would be better to go to the expense of adequately stabling them cannot be doubted.

It would be almost impossible to build up such a herd again under present conditions. Further, the expense of shipping cattle in the fall to supply the hospital and the school with meat would be almost prohibitive. However, in the present financial situation, where the school is actually operating, or trying to operate, on a 30% increase cost of operation (figuring supplies and wages) with a revenue of 2½ less than pre-war, is manifestly impossible, without the most rigid economy. Even with this economy, a deficit is bound to accumulate.

To complicate matters, the hay supply is most inadequate this year. The water is very high and has covered most of our hay grounds, which are located along the banks of the river and lakes. Where I should have normally at least 100 tons of hay put up, I will be fortunate this year to get 50. This has had to be cut mainly on islands in Playgreen Lake and has to be hauled in some cases 20 miles. Formerly, during seasons of high water, the Indians were accustomed to cut the hay in the water, spreading it out to dry. This was not uncommon. Under present conditions, however, with so much work being available in the harvest fields (over 100 men have left this reserve along for the harvest) it is impossible to get men to cut hay. However, I am fortunate in having a good crop of oats which will be cut green and stacked. In this way I may be able to manage, with careful feeding through the winter. The stabling room, however, is most necessary.

We have a really find herd of goats. They have been a distinct liability thus far. I could make some revenue selling the goats' milk to the hospital, but the Doctor expects to get the goat's milk at the same price as cow's milk (until recently we were supplying cow's milk to the hospital at 5¢ per quart, this has now been increased to 10¢). Goat's milk sells normally at about 35¢ per quart, and I would rather use it at the school than sell it at such a low cost.

We have been unfortunate in our kid production during the last two years. This year, out of 15 kids, only 3 are nannies. The billies are useless, of course, except for the small supply of goat meat which they provide. It is impossible to account for this adverse production of kids. I am changing the billy this year. I have even suggested to Dr. Corrigan that there might be a chance to get some real results with his vitamins in our goat herd --- but he does not seem to take kindly to the idea.
Our pigs are a real asset. I have a very fine type of Yorkshire and they have done remarkably well considering the very meagre and primitive accommodation we have for them. I wish we could have even a little of the fine accommodation and housing some other schools have.

I wish to make a note of the labour and staff problem. As you know, I received material to erect new outside class-rooms, we to supply all the material and labour that could be obtained here.

Owing to the shortage of labour (for logging, hauling and building) I have been as yet unable to build this building. In fact, were the labour available, finances would not permit at present of the expenditure entailed. I have the material supplied stored in the warehouse where it will not deteriorate, and this work will be proceeded with as soon as opportunity affords. In the meantime, I am using the old outside class-room for the senior pupils.

I have also gone into egg and poultry production, which has not been introduced here. I have had some 40 chickens for over a year, and this year I purchased 200 day old chicks, out of which 170 have matured. Some of these will provide poultry for the hospital, but I will have about 150 in egg production during the winter. It was necessary to build a chicken house, which is partially complete and needs to be lined and insulated for the winter.

This gives an outline of our live stock situation. There can be no doubt that our stock has contributed very greatly to the economical operation of the school. I do not know what we would have done during these difficult times had we not built up our live stock during the past two years. I feel that more land, (if it were obtainable within convenient reach of the school) and adequate stabling, is necessary to the continued better operation. What can be done under the present circumstances I do not know, but I am putting the situation before you.

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd.) A.E. Caldwell.
Ottawa,

NORWAY HOUSE, MAN.

15th July, 1944.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

About one year ago some lumber was shipped here to the school for the erection of an additional building. I understand that Mr. Caldwell proposed to make this building into a classroom, and convert the present classroom into a boys' recreation room.

Up to the present no work has been done on this proposed building and before commencing work I would like to change the plan for the following reason. The present classroom is well lighted and comfortable and if converted into a recreation room it would receive considerable hard usage as Indian boys are usually very destructive. We have already one outside classroom which we use for the junior pupils, and this classroom in the building is used for senior pupils, and I consider it quite satisfactory to use them for these purposes. But what we do need in a suitable recreation room for the boys. The present basement playroom is quite cold in winter and unsuitable for the boys' recreation room. It was evidently Mr. Caldwell's intention to provide a more comfortable room for the boys and I would like to carry out this part of the plan. I am sure that I can make a good recreation hall that will meet our requirements.

I shall be glad to know if you endorse this plan.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

(Rev. J. Jones) Principal,
Ottawa,
August 9, 1944.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Man.

I enclose, for your information, copy of a letter just received from Reverend Joseph Jones, Principal of the Norway House Residential School. You are in a better position than we are to decide if Mr. Jones' suggestion is practicable and necessary. You should discuss the matter with him and use the lumber that has been received at the school to the best possible advantage.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

In reply to Mr R.A.Hoey's letter 123-5-5 of July 26th, I beg to say that our engineer, Mr R.L.Stevenson has examined the jacketed hot water boiler in the Norway House Residential School, and finds that although the front of the boiler shows the same number and designations as shown in Ashdown's catalogue, it is not the same boiler.

Mr Stevenson states that the following repair parts should be supplied for the present boiler:

5 - New Sections, with the necessary gaskets, nipples and stove cement for assembling them.

1 - New door. To replace the second door from the bottom in front of the boiler. Size 6" X 16" (including the hinges)

The fire box in the present boiler takes a 22" stick of fuel wood.

P.G.Lazenby,

Dear Mr Hamilton,

Owing to the lack of adequate power for towing the barge for hauling wood and hay for our school, I am hiring this work to be done by Mr Folster who has a higher powered boat. This is costing me a considerable sum. The stronger engine that formerly belonged to the school has been transferred to the hospital and is no longer available for our use. I understand that the engine has been put into a boat owned by the Game Guardian. If the Department will supply the material and the engine, I will build the boat. This will be an excellent programme of manual training for the boys this Winter. I am already fitting up a workshop for this purpose. I have taught boatbuilding to Indian boys before. I believe the Department is aware of this as the boat I built is now being used by the Alberni School, the boat was named "DANN" but I think it has now a new name "HELVIN - SWARTHOUT LL". I propose to build a boat of 36 feet length and 8' beam. I have secured prices on materials in Winnipeg; the total cost for all materials except the Engine will not exceed $750.00 seven hundred and fifty dollars. The cost of a hull of the quality I shall build is $1400.00 in Winnipeg.

The engine for the boat will not be required until next Spring. I understand that the United States Government are releasing some small Diesel Engines that are suitable for this size boat and the price is very reasonable.

I shall be glad if you will present to the Department a request that this material be supplied before the close of navigation.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources

RE: Boat for Norway House School

I enclose a letter just received from Mr. Jones. I understand the school has no boat. Mr. Jones explains the material will cost $750 and when the hull is made, it will be worth at least $1400. I have no doubt a boat is needed, but apart from this, I feel that in building the boat the boys will receive a worthwhile training. Later if a fishing boat is needed or a boat for the hospital, perhaps this also could be built at the school. I believe such a training will be a delight to many of the boys and will prove useful in later life.

Mr. Jones has the material located at various places in Winnipeg and he claims it can be assembled in time for the last boat, if the authority is granted at once. Please advise by wire if Mr. Jones can make the necessary purchases.

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba

A.G. Hamilton, Esq., Insp. of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, Man.

I beg to refer to your letter, file 207-11 A.U. of June 21st last, regarding Rev. Mr. Jones, Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School attending to the building of the proposed fire escape at this school.

On receipt of your letter, I took this matter up with Mr. Jones, and discussed with him the building of the fire escape, and told him how we had planned the building of it. He proposed a different way to what we had planned, attaching the escape to the building on brackets. I spoke to him again just before leaving on the treaty trip, and he said he would give the matter further thought while I was away. Nothing had been done when I got back. I have mentioned the matter a number of times since, and he said he wanted to get Joe Keeper, an employee of the H.E.Co., to do the work. I again took the matter up with Mr. Jones yesterday, and he said he was unable to get Joe Keeper to do the work, and that he would just have to put away the materials. Nothing at all has been done to date, and it looks now as if nothing is going to be done, as practically all the local Indians have gone away to their winter camps, or are about to go, and competent help will not be available for the job during the winter, and besides, the job can hardly be done during the cold weather.

Dear Sir,

The first mail came in today and I hasten to reply to you question about the proposed Fire Escape.

Mr Hamilton asked me if I could secure someone at Norway House to erect the fire escapes as it was too expensive to send a carpenter from Winnipeg. I said if I could secure Joe Keeper who I had trained at Brandon and who has done considerable carpenter work for the Department and the Hudson's Bay Co I would get the work done. However I found that "The Bay" had him engaged under contract so was not available. There is no other man here who could undertake this work, I discussed with the Indian Agent about engaging Sandy Lauffer who is a rough carpenter for the work, he could not have done it without my help and I was prepared to work with him but he was engaged at the agency for work there and was not available.

I was not aware that the school was expected to pay for the labour of erecting the fire escape these arrangements must have been made before I came.

For your information I may say that I have completed the erection of the Gymnasium and have converted another building into a boatbuilding shop. I had to do this work personally as there is no capable man available, of course the school boys were working under my direction as I consider this kind of work valuable training.

Going back to the question of fire escape. I understand that this wing of the building was used as a sick room at the time it was decided to erect the escape. This wing is not being used for that purpose now.

The work will be done when the weather is mild enough to permit cutting the openings in the wall.

Yours sincerely

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept' of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr Philip Phelan's letter, File 123-5-5, dated 7th February, regarding certain accounts forwarded to the Department by the Principal of the Norway House Residential School, covering materials purchased for the construction of a boat. I have asked Mr Jones to procure from John Leckie L'td the express receipt required.

With reference to the engine, dealt with in the last two paragraphs of Mr Phelan's letter, I beg to say that this engine had been lying around for some years at the school, not being in use, and Dr Corrigan procured it from the then Principal, who was Rev: R.T. Chapin. Dr Corrigan informs me that the taking over of this engine from the school was discussed by him with both Mr Hoey and Mr Phelan when he was in Ottawa a few years ago, but that nothing 'official' was done about the transfer of the engine.

When Dr Corrigan got the engine, the Game Guardian had a large fishing boat without an engine in it, and they made an agreement whereby the doctor would put the engine in the boat and both would have the use of boat and engine when needed. There is no question of this engine being 'Transferred to the Game Guardian'. It is still the property of the Indian Affairs Branch, and may be taken out of the boat at any time. This is an old engine, and the doctor states that considerably over $100.00 has been spent on it since he got it, keeping it in repair.

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr Lazenby,

The main drain leading from the school has given us considerable trouble this year; it has been blocked no less than thirty times. I am sure there is a broken tile either under the foundation of the school or just outside, probably caused by the settling of the foundation. This should be attended to during the Summer holidays.

The boys' toilets in the basement freeze up during the severe weather, so we should locate them in another place where there will be no danger from frost.

Now that we have a gymnasium, the part of the old playroom could be used for the purpose of wash room and toilet. I propose to partition this part off from the main room on the West side.

Three toilets and five wash basins would be installed. I can supply the wash basins but cannot supply the toilets or the fittings. I will give you an estimate of the materials required.

One hundred dollars should cover the labour cost of excavation and installing the fittings. May I ask if you would submit this request to the Department for consideration.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

I wish to submit the following report on the Norway House Indian Residential School inspected in June, 1945.

Rev. Joseph Jones is the Principal in charge. There are 55 girls and 47 boys enrolled - a total of 102.

The building was quite clean; some repair was needed to the plaster walls, and the kitchen ceiling badly needed painting. The classroom also needed interior decorating.

The school is operated on a half day system and there were 52 pupils in the senior room - 25 in the morning and 27 in the afternoon. The pupils appear to be making fair progress. The book work seen was neat and the writing good.

The girls receive a good training in cooking, sewing, housekeeping and laundry work. All the departments appeared to be well supervised and the children seemed to enjoy their work. The children were friendly and appeared happy.

The dormitories were clean and all the beds neatly made. The bedding was plentiful and in good condition. The plumbing showed care and was in good operating condition.

The northwest corner of the foundation has moved out and is in bad condition. The north foundation wall is badly cracked. I consider the condition serious and I think the Department should obtain expert advice from a qualified engineer as to how the condition can best be remedied.

The fire escape requested by the Fire Inspector has not been erected. I understand a wooden stairway was recommended in 1942 and material provided. Mr. Jones thinks a pole type escape would serve equally as well, especially if used to come down one flight onto a landing and from there on by the proposed stairway. However, the Fire Inspector, Mr. Del Begio, does not agree. This Inspector was at the School since my visit and stated Mr. Jones promised to have the escape erected at once. I would request the Department write Mr. Jones insisting that the Inspector's recommendations be carried out immediately. If Mr. Jones needs assistance other than that he has on his staff, I would suggest that he be authorized to hire it and instructed to submit a voucher through the Indian Agent, showing the time and rate per hour paid.

The new building erected for a gymnasium is well built and I am sure serves a very useful purpose. If a man interested in sports is kept on the staff then during the winter months I am sure the building will be kept in use.

I was impressed with the boat being built for use at the school. It is 36' long and the frame is well constructed.
Mr. Jones states he will require a fairly large engine and later will submit a requisition to the Department giving full details regarding the size and type of engine needed.

The garden had all been planted but the season was late and most things were just beginning to show through the ground.

A few pigs are kept and all surplus butchered for meat. Poultry is also kept. Mr. Jones was making alterations to the barn so that he could increase his flock of poultry.

This school is of frame construction and in my opinion is a real fire trap. The children observe fire drill and are not afraid to use the pole fire escape. Fire extinguishers are kept in prominent places throughout the building, but I am sure that if a fire ever got started, it could not be stopped. If a school is to be kept at this point I feel that in view of the foundation and fire hazard a new fireproof building should be erected.

A.O. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa, 29th August, 1945.

Re: Boilers - Norway House Agency.

Mr. M. Del Regio, Chief Inspector, Department of Labour in the Provincial Government, inspected the boilers at the Norway School and Hospital and made the following recommendations:

"School - Norway House: I wish to draw your attention to the boilers at the school, which are in the following conditions:

"#1 Boiler -- tubes are leaking very badly at both ends and if this is allowed to continue much longer, it will be necessary to re-tube this boiler. Recommend that these tubes be rerolled as soon as possible or before the heating season commences, also replace broken try-cocks on water column.

"#2 Boiler -- replace the missing water glass. The back hand hold in combustion chamber is now leaking and is badly reduced by corrosion. A new gasket could be replaced to make this join tight. I, however, would recommend that this hole be sealed by welding as this leak seems to prevail at every inspection. Both return pipes of boilers have pitting through and are now leaking, same should be replaced at once.

"Also recommend that a larger sump hole with an automatic pump be installed in boiler pit to remove water which is leaking through the walls and if this condition is allowed to continue, it will destroy the boiler foundation.

"Hospital - Norway House: The cast section of the boiler which was installed new, a couple of years ago, has a cracked section at the back which is leaking badly and should be replaced as soon as possible before the heating season starts.

"Also replace broken try-cock in the vertical boiler."

I took this up with Mr. Anderson of the Vulcan Iron Works and enclose a copy of his letter. To carry the plan out would cost at least $425.00 plus material.

Mr. Stevenson, the Engineer at Norway House, was in to get the Diesel Tractor and I talked this over with him. He stated that since the erection of the sawmill at Island Lake was to be left over he would have time to do this work. In the case of Boiler #2 he would use a new gasket for lack of welding equipment.

Re: Fire Escapes - Norway House School.

Mr. DelBegio, Inspector for the Bureau of Labour and Fire Prevention Branch of the Provincial Government, has again inspected the Norway House Residential School. He pointed out that the proposed fire escape recommended in 1943 had not been erected; but that Mr. Jones promised to proceed with the work. I immediately wrote the Agent as follows:

"Mr. M. DelBegio, Inspector for the Bureau of Labour and Fire Prevention Branch, Provincial government, expressed disappointment that the fire escape recommended in 1943 for the Norway House School had not yet been erected. He stated, however, that Mr. Jones promised to have the escape built at once. Kindly discuss this with Mr. Jones and advise if the work has started. I might just add that consent to use 'poles' will not be granted.

"The Provincial Authorities wish a plan of each floor of the school - showing all the rooms - what they are used for, also all stairways. Kindly submit this plan, in duplicate, by return mail, as the season is now getting late and any proposed changes necessitating material must be attended to at once."

Now Mr. Goodman writes as follows:

"I have for acknowledgement your letter of August 15th, 1945, regarding the fire escape recommended in 1943 for the Norway House Indian Residential School.

"I have, as you request, discussed this matter with Mr. Jones. No work has been started to date. He has drawn up plans in accordance with those we agreed upon when you inspected the school building last June; i.e.: using slides instead of stairways.

"A requisition for the materials necessary has gone forward to Ottawa, and the work will be proceeded with as soon as possible.

"I have asked Mr. Jones to have a plan of each floor drawn as per the request of the Provincial Authorities, and the same will be forwarded when complete.

"It seems to me that the original Blue Prints of this building must be on file in Ottawa, and that copies of these, which would be more accurate and satisfactory, could be obtained from there."

I might say while I was at Norway House the pole idea was discussed; but I made it clear I would not issue instructions contrary to the Fire Inspector, but would discuss the matter with him and this I did. You will note I made it clear in my letter that pole fire escapes will not be approved. I might add that the Fire Inspector objects to the pole escapes, on the verandah, and...
the reason he wants a floor plan is to decide if we may retain them or if stairways are to be erected. You will find we were obliged to do away with the pole system at the Portage School and build stairways on the rear verandahs.

Mr. Jones and Mr. Goodman should, I think, receive definite instructions from Ottawa concerning this matter. I understand material for the recommended fire escapes was supplied in 1943 and surely when warehouses, residences and boats can be built, these fire escapes can be erected as per instructions. An air mail letter which will catch the next boat will be the quickest means of communication.

Please also see the eighth paragraph of my report on the Norway House Residential School, dated August 23rd.
