In reply to the notation dated August 31st last, requesting our views regarding stability of foundation walls at the above school building as covered in Mr. Hays' memorandum to you dated August 29th, 1945 we are now in receipt of a letter from Mr. D.B. Gow, enclosing a report prepared by Mr. J.T. Rose. It is explained that transportation difficulties delayed an inspection of the building, but eventually our officer was able to secure accommodation on a Manitoba Forestry Branch aeroplane, which allowed only a brief time at the site.

In his letter Mr. Gow requests that this office recommend which of the methods of repairing the foundation walls outlined in the report is considered the most suitable under the conditions involved.

We have examined the report and although the information submitted is not as complete as could be desired, a summary has been prepared and the result of our analysis follows:

GENERAL DATA

The basement foundation walls are 12" thick and appear to be of medium grade concrete. No steel reinforcement is apparent and was not called for on Indian Affairs drawings or in specifications on file in this office. The walls are 12 feet in height, 6 feet being below present grade. The footings, as closely as can be ascertained by scale from the original drawings are of plain concrete 2 feet wide by 8 inches deep. The interior bearing walls are of concrete 8 inches thick. All foundation walls support a 3 storey and roof timber structure.

We calculate the load applied to the soil by the footings as approximately 2000 lbs. per sq. ft. Under ordinary soil conditions the footings should be adequate to support this load without settlement. The report, however, states that surface or other water finds its way to the clay sub-soil on which the footings bear, thus reducing the clay to a slumberous consistency, which is unsuitable as a supporting soil. No evidence is available that sub-soil drainage has been provided. No information as to the construction of the basement floor slab is given in the report, whereas original Indian Affairs drawings and specification conflict in thickness of slab and base. These details are noted in view of the reported damaged conditions of basement floors which appears later in this summary.

A report received by Mr. Gow subsequent to the inspection by Mr. Rose, indicates rock formation at 11 feet below grade line. This depth to rock was obtained at a sump located in the furnace room ashpit. It may be assumed, therefore, that rock strata as a

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

CANADA
bearing material is present below the N.W. foundation walls, although without further investigation we can offer no opinion regarding variations in depth below grade for the portions of walls affected.

EXISTING CONDITIONS

(a) Defective Foundation Walls:-
Both exterior and interior bearing walls at the N.W. side of the building are reported to show cracks to a considerable extent. Exterior walls are as much as 4 inches out of plumb, with consequent bulging of frame walls above. Eleven major cracks are evident at openings and at intermediate points in the foundation walls, and spalling of concrete around cracks indicates progressive movement. Some of these cracks show larger widths at the bottom of the walls than at the top, indicating typical sliding and settlement of footings apparent in soil that has become saturated to gumbo consistency. Surface water enters the basement through these cracks and cold air from outside causes difficulty in heating area adjacent to cracks.

Our conclusion is that the damaged walls are unstable and dangerous to the safety of the structure.

(b) Damage to Interior Bearing Walls and Basement Floor:-
It is evident from the data furnished that some interior basement walls are also defective. Movement is indicated by visible fractures, and it is our opinion that this movement will continue as long as the variable sub-soil moisture conditions exist. The basement floor slab shows cracks and surface deterioration to the extent that floor drainage is difficult. The furnace room and ash pit are reported to be in a particularly bad condition.

(c) Damage to Verandah:-
The settlement of verandah piers has caused damage to beams, floors and columns. The verandah is three storeys in height.

REMEDIAL MEASURES

(a) Drainage of sub-soil and Diversion of Rainwater:-
The report suggests installation of eavestroughing and leaders as a means of protecting the foundations from roof water, as well as tile drainage to rectify subsurface moisture conditions. It is felt that in lieu of eavestroughing and leaders a concrete channel of adequate proportions, draining away from the building should be constructed along the north and west walls, with a 4" thick concrete apron laid for a width of 4 feet shutting the foundation walls. This would serve to divert seasonal water from the immediate vicinity of the foundation walls and footings.

It is also recommended that a tile drain be laid along the outside of the north and west foundation walls at a proper depth so that the sub-soil in the vicinity of the northwest portion of the building may be stabilized. In the absence of a site plan giving locations, distances and contours, a definite estimate for sub-soil drainage cannot be made. From a sketch plan in this office dated 1910, however, a general idea may be gained on which to base an approximate estimate of $2,300.00 for sub-soil drainage.
channel and concrete apron is roughly estimated to cost $150.00.

At a later date, after the sub-soil has attained a sufficient moisture stability, the damaged basement floors could be renewed or repaired as required.

(b) Verandah:-

It appears to be necessary to carry piers to rock and renew and repair damaged superstructure. The extent of damage is not reported, but from an examination of the original drawings an approximate estimate of $600.00 seems reasonable.

(c) Paved Concrete Playground:-

It will be necessary when excavating along a portion of the length of the damaged foundation walls to remove some concrete pavement. For removing and relaying this pavement a sum of approximately $90.00 should be allotted.

(d) Foundation Walls:-

Three methods of repairing the foundation walls are suggested in the report. First - To construct a new 30 inch wide by 12 inch deep reinforced concrete footing under the existing footing and replace existing walls with 6 inches of reinforced concrete dowelled to the walls. Second - To remove and replace the two damaged walls with new reinforced concrete walls supported on concrete caissons carried down to rock; for this the estimated cost is given as $2,500.00. Third - To place tie-rods the length of the existing walls to prevent movement, then construct caissons to rock with reinforced concrete beams under the existing footings. The estimated cost for this method is given as $1,500.00.

We recommend that the third method be adopted. By this method the walls would be tied and plumbed, with cracks well grouted and rendered watertight. As the depth of rock below grade is not definitely known, a unit price for excavation, concrete caissons and reinforced concrete work should be stated in any tender so that deductions or additions to cost of the work may be made.

We may summarize the cost of work considered necessary to stabilize the damaged walls and to rectify sub-surface moisture conditions at the northwest portion of the building, as follows:-

| Item                                                                 | Cost   |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|
| (1) Construct caissons and beams under two damaged foundation walls and tie walls with tie-rods | $2,000.00 |
| (2) Lay sub-surface drainage pipe                                    | $2,300.00 |
| (3) Remove and relay concrete pavement                               | $90.00  |
| (4) Construct concrete channel and apron                             | $150.00 |
| (5) Repair verandah                                                   | $600.00 |
| (6) Transportation, Workmen's Comp. etc.                             | $100.00 |
| (7) Contingencies and Supervision                                     | $760.00 |
| (8) Total                                                             | $5,900.00 |

In view of the location of the building and the transportation and labour problems which may be encountered this approximate estimate can only be considered a minimum.

The condition of the foundations is hazardous and immediate consideration should be given by the Indian Affairs Branch to the repairs outlined herein.

Dear Mr Hamilton,

The boat we have been building is just about complete as far as we can go until we receive the shaft propeller, clutch, stern bearing, and intermediate bearings. On another sheet I will give the details of these requirements.

In the school Estimates for the present year there are items to cover the cost of Engine and the fittings.

It is possible that the Department could procure a Deisel engine from the War Assets Corporation that would be ideal for our boat.

It will be much easier for me to transfer the boat from the shop to the lake before the ice goes out, then I can put the engine in when navigation opens.

I would like to get the fittings as early as possible as these will have to be installed before the boat is in the water.

The boys have taken a great interest in the construction of the boat and are becoming quite clever in handling tools. The Indians of the reserve are pleased to see their boys receiving this type of training.

Our pupils are well and happy and I trust they will maintain this high standard of health right through the year.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

MEMO.

May 16th, 1946.

The following remittance has been received from Indian Agent E. B. Goodman at Norway House Agency and recorded in the Official Cash Book.

Amount $110.00

Agency Receipt No. 35233

Payer Indian Residential School, on account of electric light and power, Rev. Jos. Jones.

April 1946 - Revenue 114.

For Treasury Branch.
R.A. Hoey, Director Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa

Would you please advise me as to ownership of Residential School property. It seems to me the interests of the Indian Affairs Branch should be taken care of. Already 300 cords of wood have been sold by the Principal, Reverend Joseph Jones, to the Selkirk Navigation company. This wood, which I believe was paid for by Government money could have been used by us and saved time, money and labor next winter.

I understand there is still a considerable amount of wood on hand not yet sold. There are several buildings that are of value to the Indian Affairs Branch. There is also livestock, such as horses, pigs and poultry. I do not know what interest or say in this matter the United Church has and would be glad of your advice. All the buildings on Hope Island, which were part of the school have been disposed of and removed by Mr. Jones since he took over as Principal. I would like to be given the opportunity to have some say in the disposition of this property on behalf of the Indian Affairs Branch. Mr. Jones was away at the time of the fire and I have no definite information as to when he will return, but should he return on the next boat, I would be leaving almost immediately for Oxford House.

Please advise me as to what line of action I should take in this matter.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 19, 1946.

Mr. E. B. Goodman, Indian Agent,
Norway House, Manitoba.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the Norway House Indian Residential School.

We have been expecting to receive a complete report from you regarding the fire. The only information that we have received in this connection is your telegram of May 29. Your letter was discussed with the Director yesterday and he was very anxious to receive a very complete report, indicating the buildings that were saved and the equipment that is still available.

The wood to which you refer was purchased by the school management from school funds and, consequently, they are at liberty to sell to whom they please. I regret that the Principal has evidently not shown any spirit of co-operation with you, in view of the fact that you could have used the wood for other agency purposes.

What has been said regarding the wood applies also to the live stock, such as horses, pigs and poultry. The expenditure for their purchase was made from school funds.

The main building and all the outbuildings are the property of the Department and should not be sold or torn down without receiving our permission. You should so inform Reverend Mr. Jones.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
I propose that the old hospital building be turned into a two room day school. The entire first floor could be cleaned out and made into classrooms and the second floor could be used as living quarters for the two teachers. The basement could be cleared out and used as a gymnasium and a workshop for manual training. If the hospital is built on the proposed site this will involve a new Doctor's residence. The present Doctor's residence could be used as Clerk's quarters.

I understand that no building is to be done in this locality until 1947. With the burning of the Residential School, 50 children from Norway House had to be returned to their homes, which means that another year that there are an extra 50 children who will have to attend day schools. If no building is proposed before next summer, I believe there are enough buildings around the Residential School to provide accommodation for these children this winter. There is a new gymnasium, which could be converted into a classroom, and there is a very good store building which the school used as a warehouse. Both these buildings would make excellent classrooms for the winter.

The turning of the Residential School certainly complicates the picture, but I believe in the long run, it is all for the good. We have got rid of an old fire trap of a building, which was going to cost a lot of money to repair the foundations. There was no loss of life and no particular loss of other property. With the building of a new hospital, that leaves the old hospital building as a large day school, which should take care of all the educational needs of this reserve together with the day schools at the Catholic Mission and the Anglican Mission. I see no reason to rebuild boarding schools in this Agency.

At about 3:30 A.M. on the 29th instant I was awakened by an Indian from the Reserve who told me the United Church Indian Residential School was on fire. I immediately dressed and proceeded to the scene by canoe, after having aroused the prisoners and escort and instructed them to follow. On arrival I found the whole building enveloped in flames.

On arrival I was informed by a member of the staff that all children had been evacuated and that no one had been injured or burned. Numerous Indians were on hand and patrols were established to guard against the Hospital and other buildings in proximity to the school catching fire. At one time it was feared the principal's residence would ignite and the household furnishings were removed, but the building was saved and things were later moved back in.

When the danger of the fire spreading was overcome I made enquiries as to the possible origin of the blaze. I was informed by Mr. Organ, acting principal in the absence of Rev. Joseph Jones who left on the 28th instant on a business trip to Winnipeg, that he was roused by one of the older boys at approximately 2:00 A.M. He found that the woodshed, which is an addition of the kitchen wing, was ablaze. He stated the services of a night watchman had been dispensed with Apr. 15th and that there had been no furnace fire on, the only fire being one in the small water heater in the furnace room. He stated he had made a round of the entire building at 10:30 P.M. and found everything in order. At the time of the fire there was approximately one cord of 4 foot wood in the woodshed, which opened into the furnace room, and there was quite an accumulation of chips and bark on the floor. Mr. Organ and some of the boys immediately got out firehoses, after having rang the alarm, but they found the hoses were inadequate and that the water pressure was not sufficient to reach the heart of the blaze, although they were able to restrict it to the woodshed for sometime before the kitchen above caught fire. Once the kitchen caught the fire spread rapidly throughout the whole building.

They were able to hold the fire in check long enough that with the help of numerous Indians most of the furnishings of the building and all records were salvaged. Some of the members of the staff lost their personal belongings.

Donald BEARDY, 15 years, the Indian lad who gave the alarm, was questioned and he stated he awake and smelled smoke, on looking out the window he saw flames coming out of the woodshed and immediately woke up the other boys and reported to Mr. Organ who gave the general alarm. He and other boys were questioned as to whether they had seen anyone in the vicinity of that part of the building after dark or if any of them had been smoking in the woodshed. As far as can be ascertained...
Re: Indian Residential School, Norway House, Man.

Destruction by Fire:

5. (Continued) CAN BE ASCERTAINED no one was seen around that part of the building after dark nor have any of the boys admitted smoking in the vicinity of the woodshed. It is possible someone dropped a cigarette butt in the chips and bark on the floor of the shed and it smoldered and eventually ignited the refuse on the floor. During the enquiries Mr. D.H. Learmonth, Manager of the Hudson's Bay Co. store at Rossville, which is approximately 200 yards west of the school, stated he retired at about 11:00 P.M. and left the windows open. Sometime after he smelled smoke and twice got up and checked the Company buildings for possible fire but could not locate anything. At the time there was a very slight breeze from the east but we did not notice anything amiss at the school until the alarm was sounded. This would tend to substantiate the theory that the fire was smoldering for sometime before it was noticed at 3:00 A.M. by young BRANDY.

6. At 7:00 A.M. the following message was dispatched by A.P. Airlines Radio to the Officer Commanding, Winnipeg Sub-Division:

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL HERE COMPLETELY DESTROYED BY FIRE EARLY MORNING TODAY STOP ALL CHILDREN AND STAFF MEMBERS ACCOUNTED FOR AND NO ONE INJURED STOP COMPLETE REPORT BY MAIL.

7. The Matron, Mrs. Rollins, sent messages to the various Reserves from which the children are drawn notifying everyone that the children were safe. A message was also dispatched to Berens River for delivery to Rev. Jones who is a passenger aboard the S.S. Keenora bound for Winnipeg.

8. All children and staff members are being billeted and cared for at the agency, and adjacent homes.

9. In view of the above this file will be considered closed unless otherwise instructed.

H.O.T.D.C.

The O.C., "D" Division,
R.C.M.P., Police, Winnipeg.

Dear Mr. Hamilton,

I beg to submit a report of the fire which destroyed Norway House Residential School on the 29th of May, 1946. The fire broke out in the wood storage pit on the outside of the building, adjoining the furnace room. When the fire was discovered the outside of the building was burning. The fire hoses from the third and second floors were immediately brought into operation, but the supply of water was inadequate to cope with the fire.

The children were removed at once when the fire was discovered. They were marched out onto the campus and counted.

When it was found impossible to put out the flames the staff proceeded to salvage as much of the contents as possible. The local Indians gave every possible assistance. Some of the staff have lost personal possessions.

Something will have to be done at once to provide water connection with the Principal's residence and Engineer's residence. Some temporary work has been done, but this work will have to be completed before the frost comes. I will interview Engineer Cow at the earliest opportunity and discuss with him the best means of doing this work.

I had left Norway House by boat Tuesday noon, the day before the fire and could not return until I got into Winnipeg.

Flames Raze Norway House Indian School

NORWAY HOUSE, May 30 (Special)—The Indian Residential School here was razed by a fire that swept through the building Tuesday morning. No casualties were reported. The blaze was of unknown origin.

Joseph Jones, principal of the school, had just left by boat for Winnipeg, where he was visiting. The school containing school records was saved, but the remainder of the equipment is a total loss.

The school, which accommodates 100 children, was ministered by the department of mines and resources. No estimates were available concerning the value of the building, but it was stated that no insurance is carried by the government.

Volunteer fire fighters saved a private residence adjacent to the school building from the blaze.

Reconstruction work will be handled by the department of mines and resources, although orders from Ottawa may be necessary.

In reply to your letters of June 12 and 20th and further to my telegram re the burning of the Residential School, the Residential School was totally destroyed by fire which had its origin in a lean-to woodshed. The fire occurred at about 3 A.M. on the 29th May. I was away at the time with Dr Corrigan at Warren's Landing. None of the outbuildings were in any way damaged. These comprise a workshop, gymnasium, ice house, teachers shop, barn, senior classroom, principal's residence, and paint shop. This latter (the paint shop) Mr Jones claims does not belong to the Department. I also submit a list of physical assets, which have been submitted to me by Reverend Joseph Jones. I believe that considerable equipment such as bedding, furniture, clothing etc was rescued before the school burned down but of this I have no definite knowledge.

In your letter of the 20th you ask what provision can be made for schools at Norway House for the years 1946-47. In answer to your questions: (a) There are 2 buildings which could very easily be used as day schools. There is a senior classroom which is fully equipped and the same size as Rossville day school and there is the gymnasium which is somewhat larger and would make an excellent day school. This would have to be equipped with blackboards, teacher's desk and chair and 40 single desks, 15 large, 10 medium, and 15 small size. (b) These buildings together with the present Rossville day school should provide 3 day schools which would accommodate about 125 pupils. (c) These 3 buildings will not accommodate all the children of school age in this community but it will accommodate more from this community than before the fire. It will be necessary to use the principal's residence for living accommodation for the 3 teachers required for these schools, otherwise there is no accommodation here for them.

Before the fire there were 54 Norway House pupils in the Residential School. The Rossville day school, which is old, decrepit and should be condemned accommodated the balance and was most of the time overcrowded as a refusal of the quarterly returns. It shows that this time I would also like to point out that there is an excellent Anglican day school at Jack river which was closed all last year owing to the fact that there was no teacher provided. There are 62 children who should be attending this school and I would suggest that the matter be brought to the attention of Bishop J. Lofthouse at Kenora who nominates the teacher.

I presume that you have seen Dr Corrigan and that you have got a great deal of information from him regarding the burning of the school and I trust that I have supplied what information you require. I have just returned from paying treaty inland, hence the delay in replying to your letter.

E. B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

However we have found a 500 gal tank unamaged. This is capable of servicing the community without the load imposed by the Residential school when it was in operation. We have installed this tank in the power house and attached the air compressor and motor which are now in operation and giving satisfaction.

The chlorine has been doubled in the water supply and is being carefully checked by Mr Stevenson. There will be no need under existing conditions to purchase a new tank. It will be necessary to re-organize the plumbing and sewage in the vicinity of the whole school basement and I have submitted a report on this and the materials that will be required, and labour, so Mr Stevenson may see of which I enclose for your information. I have a gang of men employed digging the new trenches and will lay the sewage and water pipes in separate trenches at a considerable distance apart. It will not take long to complete this work after the required material arrives. It will require a gang of 6 men, working a full week to salvage any useful material from the ruins and to fill in the basement and push the old walls in, which are in a dangerous condition. This work also is proceeding.

The work of filling in the old school basement has been completed and any material which was of value has been salvaged. The cost was higher than anticipated being $310.35. Please bear in mind that we have no equipment for doing such work and it all had to be done by hand with shovels. However the work has been well done and if the sewer drain pipe runs underneath survives the winter without freezing there will be no need for changing it. Thus considerable money will be saved from the $400.00 allowed for digging trenches and laying a new sewer. I see no reason why it should freeze and settle out a heavy layer of sand and shingles over the top. The laying of a new water line is also completed. The cost of which was $57.45 which was much less than anticipated. The material for this work we had on hand, so that providing the old sewer survives the winter there will be no need for further expenditure from the $400.00 allowed for this purpose.

Would you kindly have the amount of $310.35 forwarded to this office, as these costs have been paid from School's account accountable advance which now shows a debit balance.

Sir:

Referring to your letter No.123-5-10, dated Nov.7th, with regard to the girl Betsy Anderson, whose application for admission to Norway House Residential School has been held for further consideration, would say that this girl attended the Day School at the R.C.Mission on the Jack River, Norway House, for nearly two years, for seven quarters, to be exact.

The girl was sent to this school by her mother, where she was a boarder. Whether the father paid anything toward her board while she was at the school, I do not know. The father is a Protestant, and the mother is a graduate of several years ago, of the Norway House Boarding School, but at the time she sent the girl to the R.C.School was, I believe, considering becoming a Roman Catholic. As the family are away on their trapping grounds, I cannot interview them with regard to this latter point. Numbers 242, Thomas Anderson, and 243, William Anderson, of Norway House Residential School are brothers of Betsy, with the same father and mother. I understand that the father was opposed to sending the girl to the R.C. school, and placed her in the Protestant school.

I have not heard that any effort was made by the authorities of the Jack River R.C.School to secure the admission of this girl to their school after it was made a Boarding School. It is probable that they tried, and were refused by the parents.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir,

A little time ago Indian Agent Gordon of Norway House notified me that a discharge for three of our school boys had been recommended by the Department of Indian Affairs. These boys were as follows:

No. 242. William Anderson.
No. 221. Joe Muswagon.
No. 222. Geo. Paupenakis.

I was considerably surprised to learn this as none of these discharges had been asked for by myself. William Anderson was on my suggestion and on the advice of Dr. Turpel allowed to remain with his parents for this current year in order that he might possibly become a little more robust. He was not considered tubercular but being but eight years of age and a little inclined to brood for his parents if he became in any measure indisposed, we thought it wise to let him go to the bush with them this year feeling quite certain that he would be fine another year. To have his discharge effected was far from our thought. The other two boys I had already taken steps to have them return at once to school since there had been no permission given by myself for them to remain away. On the day that their discharge was reported to me the latter of these boys presented himself at the school to again take his place. Of course all that I could do under the circumstances was to tell him of his discharge and send him home again.

I am very much afraid that the action of the Department in recommending the discharge especially of Geo. Paupenakis may set a precedent that will make a good deal of trouble for the Principal of this school in the future. There has always been a very decided tendency on the part of the parents of children who are about to their final year, to attempt to get the children out before the expiration of their time. Two years ago out of a graduating class of fifteen pupils no less than eight were demanded at the opening of their final year. One did stay out and remained out as did another a year ago. Last summer when I was going about inland with the Treaty Party Indian Agent Gordon was very particular to impress on the people that they should not look to have their children removed until they were Eighteen years of age. In the case of Geo. Paupenakis no valid reason why he should be discharged was ever presented by his parents. I stood out for his return and with the result that he came in only to be sent home again. One other very undesirable aspect of this particular case is that in the regular round we this year find ourselves practically no large boys to manage out outside tasks. This boy had been carried by the school for several years and this year when we needed help we have been forced to hire from the outside. One very undesirable aspect of hiring outside help is that we find the outsiders are very apt to have an unsavoury influence on the other boys with whom they labor.

I am fully aware that the application forms read, "Until discharged by the Indian Department." I would like however if you would please give me a ruling as to who is to take the initiative in discharges. I have had the thought that that duty rested in the first place on the Principal, as the man most conversant with the case in hand. I have had a lot of trouble with parents approaching the Indian Agent to demand the discharge of children and then coming to me with the statement that he had stated that the child should go home to stay and be discharged. Again when I have approached Indian Agent Gordon I find that he gave no definite promise at all. Still they assumed that what he stated was a permission, when perhaps all he stated was, "We will see." It would solve the problem greatly if you would give a ruling as touching this matter.

As touching the above mentioned boys, it goes without saying that they now stand discharged for the present even though the copy of the letter sent by Mr. Gordon was explanatory of their absence rather than a recommendation for discharge.

As touching general matters pertaining to the school I beg to state that never have we had a better year that we are having this year. Our staff is working in the very best of harmony all round. A year ago we had unfortunately a couple members on our staff who were exceedingly lax in discipline in their departments. This spread itself to the other departments and gave me a good deal of continuous trouble. This year the staff are just fine and the discipline of the school has been a most satisfactory thing. We have practically no offences on the part of the children large or small and all are as happy as can be. Some children returning to school brought us an epidemic of whooping cough. We had over forty with it at once. It surely was strenuous period and at the end almost everyone was about worn to a "Frazzle" but we did not lose a child. When we learn of the terrific mortality out on the reserves we feel more than pleased that our care was so amply rewarded. Now it is all past and our monthly weight chart shows an almost universal increase in weight, Dr. Turpin's verdict is that never has he seen the school so well fed, dressed or so healthy. Almost every child is rosy and the picture of good health. Naturally we are very proud of the general appearance of our charges.

Our policy has been one of, "Plenty good plain wholesome food, Plenty of good warm clothes day and night with plenty of fresh air through exercise during the day and adequate ventilation at night without direct draft on their beds! We have striven to get Hope Island to producing hay and pasture and to that end have cleared and seeded to grass a considerable area. We have put the best sire of a dual purpose breed. During the cold secure at the head of our cows. Instead of bringing in cows that have not been acclimated, we are raising our own heifers. We have heifers now so that in two years more the school will have some Eighteen or Twenty cows. We are today milking ten fresh cows, and practically all that milk is being sterilized and going on the children's tables. All these things are telling on the condition of the pupil body of the school. I wanted while writing to report thus on the condition of the school. I trust that it will meet with your approval.

I am Sincerely Yours,

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School. From this letter, it appears that Reverend Mr. Shoup considers that pupils 221, 222 and 242 should not have been granted their discharge.

While your letter of October 16th, last, did not definitely recommend the discharge of the above three pupils, the Department felt that, from the information contained in your letter, it was doubtful if these three boys would return to the school and it was, therefore, considered advisable to grant their discharge by official letter of November 7th.

It is inadvisable to retain on the quarterly return the names of any pupils who will be absent from the school for a considerable period of time due to illness. In the case of such pupils, application should be made for their discharge in order that their names may be removed from the return. If their health improves and it is again considered desirable to place them at school, application can be made for their re-admission.

No doubt, you consult the Principal before applying for the discharge of any pupil. The Department considers such action very desirable. In the event of a difference of opinion between yourself and the Principal regarding the discharge of any pupil, all the facts should be placed before the Department in order that we can decide whether or not the discharge should be granted.

Reverend Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, I beg to say that, while Mr. Agent Gordon's letter of October 16th, last, did not definitely recommend the discharge of pupils 221, 222 and 242, the Department considered that, owing to the special circumstances in each of these cases, it was doubtful if the children would be returned to the school. Besides, it is undesirable to keep on the return the names of pupils who are absent from the school for a considerable length of time. If their absence is due to medical reasons, application should be made for their discharge and, if their health improves at a later date, you could again apply for their re-admission.

I feel certain that Mr. Gordon consults you before applying for the discharge of any pupil. The Department considers such a course advisable and, in order that there may be no misunderstanding in the matter, Mr. Gordon is being so advised. He is being further informed that, in the event of differences of opinion between yourself and the Agent regarding the discharge of any pupils, all the facts must be laid before the Department in order that we can decide whether or not the discharge should be granted.

Unless under very exceptional circumstances, no pupil should be discharged from the Norway House School without your first having been advised by Mr. Gordon that such discharge is approved by the Department. Statements made by individual Indians regarding their interviews with the Agent need not be given any credence.

This girl was not at any time a pupil of the St. Joseph's Residential School at Cross Lake. Her parents now are members of the United Church of Canada, at Cross Lake.

This girl was brought by her father to the school the end of last September. We were not very sure as to her health, and her father brought her to the doctor for examination. The doctor was out at the time. Later, when the father took her to the school, where he intended to make out the Application forms, the Principal was out. As he was in a hurry to get home to Cross Lake, he went back without making out the forms, and immediately went out to his winter camp. There appears to have been no opportunity to have the forms signed all winter.

In view of these facts, and that the girl has done well in school, I not only recommend her application, but that the school be allowed grant for this girl from October 1st last to March 31st. If admission is approved, she will appear on the June Quarter Return.

Your obedient servant

Wm. Gordon,

Dear Sirs,

Your recent communication re children in this institution who have been reported as Sixteen years of age and over is before me. Replying to it I may state that when I took over the management of this school it was stated to me that there had been no fixed age for discharge of pupils fixed by the Government, but that for years the generally acknowledged age was Eighteen years. I have proceeded on that basis in my recommendations for Graduation and discharge. I was acquainted with the clause relating to attendance at school of Indian Children up to Sixteen years but did not think that that clause was to be read that no child should attend school after that maximum age, but if a child's parents wished the child to go longer that it was their option without further permission being secured. For these reasons the names have appeared on our reports as you have noticed.

In addition I would like to respectfully call your attention to this fact that has a decided bearing on any proposal to discharge any pupils simply because they are Sixteen. The school with the approval of the Government for instance takes a pupil in at the age of seven. Up to sixteen the pupil is not able to be of any very marked assistance with the regular work of the school except for lighter tasks. During the years from sixteen to eighteen we find the pupils are able to carry our heavier tasks and so take the place of help that would have to be hired from the outside. The present financial condition of our schools will not allow
the engagement of much outside help on current wages. And in addition to all this is the fact that my experience has been that outside help very frequently causes the management of an institution considerable trouble through the influence of the help on the pupil body.

I trust that you will find these reasons entirely satisfactory to your Department management.

I am herewith inclosing a list of children whose names appear on my return as being Sixteen years and over, with request for their continuance in the school,

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of Rev. W. W. Shoup's letter of the 30th ultimo, in connection with the circular letter issued by the Deputy Superintendent General on the 15th ultimo.

The latter letter did not state that children must be discharged when they reach the age of sixteen years, but it pointed out that the Indian Act requires that, when pupils reach sixteen years of age and it is desired to keep them in school for a further period, permission must be secured. In future, therefore, you should, at the end of each academic year, forward to the Department, through the office of your local Indian Agent, a list of the children in the Norway House Residential School who are sixteen years of age and over. In the case of those whom you consider should remain for a further period, permission should be requested to retain them, and, in each case, your reasons for making the request should be stated.

Sir,

Chapin, principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School, has received an account from Wings Limited of Winnipeg, charging $162.00 for transportation by airplane, of 18 pupils from God's Lake and Island Lake to Norway House, at $9.00 each, when returning to school after holidays last summer.

There was an agreement apparently arrived at, whereby the parents should pay this transportation for their children, the mounts to be deducted from their earnings at the Island Lake Gold Mine, and in addition, the parents were to be supplied with the same rations as they would have received, had they transported the children by canoe.

As it turned out, the parents received their rations, amounting to $72.01 supplied from the personal stores of Mr Gavin Grieve, missionary at Island Lake, and $2.15 supplied from the personal stores of Mr Keith Armstrong, missionary at God's Lake, but the amounts of the fares were not collected from the parents and turned over to Wings Limited.

Moreover, only 13 of the 18 pupils were pupils of the Norway House Residential School, the other 5 being pupils of the Jack River R.C. Day School.

The Rev. Mr Chapin, does not feel that he should be called upon to pay the above accounts to Wings Limited and the two missionaries, as he did not authorize this expenditure.

Will you please advise me what should be done in the above matter, and if I should forward vouchers to the Department for the above accounts.

Your obedient servant,

2. 12.3.35

Accompanied by S/Cst. Robinson, A. of this Detachment, and with Police dog-train I left the Detachment at 9.00 am. of the above date and proceeded to Rossville in an effort to ascertain the truth of this report and make necessary investigations. Upon arrival at the premises concerned I found out that this offence had occurred on the night of the 6th inst., entrance having been gained by breaking a couple of panes of glass in a window leading into the storehouse on the west side, also the dividing sash had been broken, probably by an axe, in order that the person would be able to crawl in; size of the aperture was 15in. x 20 in.; an opening of this size would only allow a small person to enter. 3. STATEMENT OF WILLIAM GALL 12.3.35

On Saturday, March 9th, 1935 I opened Hyer's Ltd. store, where I am employed as a clerk, which is located on Mission Point, Rossville, at about 9.00am., when I went round to the rear for wood, I saw two panes of glass broken in a window in the store-house, which is a part of the store proper. I looked at the books and owing to being busy the day previous the cash sales were not put in the books. I cannot give a definitive amount missing, although there is some missing approx. £8.00 or £9.00. If the person or persons who broke in took anything from the store stock I could not tell that. I cannot place any suspicion on any person at all.

9. STATEMENT OF WILLIAM FOLSTER

On Friday, March 8th, 1935 I was looking after the lighting engine and water pump at the Norway House Indian Boarding School, where I am a pupil. I started about 6:00pm. I was alone. About 8:00 pm, the same evening, I went in the direction of Hyer's store. I went to the side of the store, I noticed one window was broken and the other side was not. I broke the window and part of the sash and crawled through. I was by myself, I went to the cash drawer and took $7.00, this was made up of one dollar bills. I came back to the school. On Saturday I went to Campbell's store and purchased one pair of pants, 2 pkgs. chewing gum, 3 chocolate bars, 1 pocket knife and one pkg. candies. I paid for the above, I do not know how much. Peter Loonfoot was with me. We returned to the school. On Monday, March 11th, 1935 I sent Nelson Flett & Zacharius Loonfoot to Campbell's to change the pants, they were too small. They purchased a pocket knife, they brought a larger size back and I wore them, the same day Mr. Chapin saw me with the new pants on, he said "You stole those pants I will go and tell Mr. Chapin" he did not say this, I later gave them to Mr. Chapin, later he called me in the office. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the summer holiday period at the Norway House and Cross Lake Indian Residential Schools.

While the Department prefers that principals of residential schools take only 43 days' holidays in the summer, at the same time, if the principals of these schools consider that it is in the best interests of the school and pupils to allow two months' holidays each summer, they may do so; but, it should be distinctly understood that the Department only allows grant for 43 days' holidays.

When a pupil is allowed out on holidays on July first and does not return until September first, the principal, in preparing the September quarter return, should ask grant for only 73 days (30 days in September plus 43 days' holidays for which grant is allowed). In other words, in preparing the September return, grant should only be requested for the actual number of days each pupil is in residence during the quarter, plus 43 days' holidays for which grant is allowed.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith the applications for Admission to the Norway House Indian Residential School, of William Apetakun, grandson of Mrs Annie Apetakun, of No 196 Norway House Band, and Abraham Monias, son of Jacob Monias No; 370 Cross Lake Band.

With reference to William Apetakun, I may say that this boy has never been paid annuity. His mother was a daughter of Mrs Annie Apetakun, and died when the boy was two years old. The putative father of the boy is a non-treaty half breed. Since the death of the boy's mother he was a treaty Indian, the grandmother having cared for him. The grandfather of course, is a treaty Indian. The boy has lost his left hand, having had to have it amputated as a result of the explosion of a dynamite cap, about two years ago. I am of the opinion that this boy might be admitted to treaty. He has lived on the Norway House Reserve with his grandmother all his life, and is practically an Indian in all respects, excepting that he does not receive annuity.

I would recommend the admission of both the above applicants to the Norway House Residential School as grant earning pupils.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

Re the quarterly return which I have just completed,- The children returned from their holidays throughout the week of August 12th. Some were a few days late, some were a few days late in leaving on their holidays, and some spent part of their holidays in the school to keep the summer's work moving. Taking the aggregate, there were 7 days overspent on holidays. These I deducted from the boy latest in coming back, Abel Wood. We opened the class-rooms August 19th.

I have asked for the discharge of the following pupils:- 214 Moses Apetakun, who has been out of school a year due to the development of a T.B.Knee. This has not cleared up, so, with the difficulty of the school stairs, I think it would be unwise to consider his return. 0240, Bella Ross; her people wanted her home this year, but she wanted to remain in the school another year. I asked permission for her return if she gained the consent of her parents during the holidays. She remained in the school until Aug. 2nd taking her holidays then. After some time I received word that she was married. 0246 Emily Knott Ross; when this girl returned to the school a year ago she was in poor shape, and has had special care and treatment during the year. She has not pulled up and the Dr advises her discharge. 0277, Betsey Anderson, and 0280 Emily Knott; both these girls have been out of school a year on account of their health, and neither were fit to enter this fall.

Yours truly,

Signed; R.T. Chapin.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I wonder if you remember
the time I called to see you at Mr.
Huggins' to find out about Norway
House and Indian Work in general.

Since then I've become better
acquainted with Norway House
and have taken such an interest
in Indians and their bush country that
I feel I could find the work satisfying
as a life-time vocation.

The Indians in this district
seem to have more self-respect
than at home and I believe are more
self-supporting. Yet I think it is
pretty safe to say that the average
intelligence of the children is below
that of white children. Their reactions
seem to be those of a normal white
child a year or two younger than themselves.
They love to play and learn new games readily if the rules are not too complicated.

They differ from white children that I have known in their tendency to use their hands in spare time to make things out of little or nothing, such as sling shots, bows and arrows, checkers and checker boards, snow snakes, and with the girls bead work and occasionally silk work or knitting. They are very disinclined to speak out when spoken to in English even after they know a person well. A great deal of their humour comes from picking out personal peculiarities of speech or manner of dress to ridicule or imitate for amusement.

The education they receive in the classroom is probably fairly satisfactory in the first three or four grades but beyond that I feel that much Indians subjects from Grade IV on are largely wasted. Geography, History, Grammar and Physics will be a memory and nothing more to 90% of them, for they have no books or newspapers to speak of and do not take any interest in the world outside, chiefly because they have no connection with it close at hand. Eaton & Co Winnipeg. Except for the brightest ones I should think the manual arts would be more useful for boys and girls after they have reached the standard set for the end of grade IV.

It was another matter, however which made me think of writing you, and I hope this preamble hasn't taken too much of your time. Last year a girl in this school, Martha Kennedy by name, was recommended by the principal and Indian Agent as a pupil who would profit from further education at the Brandon School. This recommendation was not accepted at Ottawa. The girl was 16 with just two years till graduation.
and in grade seven. I understood that the Department felt the expenditure would not be advisable, because the two years would not benefit her sufficiently to warrant it when the Government was so hard pressed financially. I realize that the line has to be drawn somewhere, and that the Department is trying to use its budget the best way possible.

Martha was very disappointed when she learned that she would not be able to go. She has had the ambition to be a nurse among her own people for a long time, and that together with a great liking for books made her wish very much to continue her studies. This year she has been doing well in grade eight. Her health is fine. Miss Oliver who has been the Hospital here as nurse said to me that not many of these girls had the constitution to go through a training course but she thought Martha had.
Not the least of her assets are her attitudes towards others and her work. She is honest and dependable and takes pride in doing her work well. I believe she has a deeper religious experience than perhaps any of the children here. It seems to me that in all probability she would make a real contribution to her own people if the opportunity were hers.

I feel that her education would be a good investment and I would be willing to pay the $100 high school tuition fee next year and half of the total cost of board and tuition for the next two or three years until she finished Grade IX or X which would give her the qualifications necessary to begin training. I expect to be teaching at Island Lake for the next few years.
And I'm sure I could spare one or two hundred dollars a year. I have a few hundred dollars of my own now.

I have confidence in Martha's ability. I believe she will apply herself, and I feel it would be a shame to deny her the chance of higher training if the way were open at all.

I would be grateful if you would consider this proposal and if it is not feasible perhaps you might suggest some other alternative.

Yours sincerely,

Walter Mutch

P.S. I have taken up developing printing for a hobby. There are some pictures taken this year.

P.S.S. Mr. Chepman, the principal, after reading his felt I had left the impression that Martha is more clever than she really is. Although she stands high in intelligence in this school, it is likely that she would only measure up to the average white child. She is not original in her thinking. What I would depend on is her desire to get ahead and the readiness with which she undertakes her studies.
Ottawa, January 30, 1936.

Dear Mr. Mutch:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, with the three snapshots showing groups of pupils at the Norway House Indian Residential School. Judging by the pictures, they appear to be a healthy group of children.

I note that, after your experience with the Indian children, you find their intelligence below that of white children of similar ages. In the north country, where it is doubtful if farming operations can be carried on, it might be in the best interests of the children - the boys especially - to grant them their discharge after they have reached the fourth or fifth grade, in order that they can return to their parents and learn to hunt and set traps, as it is likely that this will be their future means of livelihood for some time. However, this is a difficult point to decide, as the churches interested desire to keep the children, both boys and girls, until they reach at least 16 years of age.

I hope you like the work at Norway House and have become familiar with conditions, which, I am sure, you found entirely different from P. E. Island.

Regarding the case of Martha Kennedy, in July last, Mr. Agent Lazenby forwarded a request from Reverend R. T. Chapin, that this girl be transferred to the Brandon Indian Residential School, to take her 8th grade. We were unable to approve sending her a long distance and

- paying for

Walter Mutch, Esq.,
Indian Residential School,
Norway House,
Man.
paying for her maintenance and tuition at Brandon. As I understand it, she will not be able to pass her Entrance to high school until the end of the present school year, and, if sent to Brandon, it would require four years for her to obtain Matriculation. I note she wishes to take up nursing. Most hospitals now require that girls entering training have their Matriculation, and the nursing course would take three years. As Martha is now 17 and as it would take another 7 years before she would become a nurse, the cost involved would be greater than the Department could provide. I may say that we have paid the expenses of a number of Indian girls to obtain training as nurses. The Government is unable to provide them with positions upon graduation and there appears to be prejudice among white people to utilizing their services in private nursing. If Martha only obtained Matriculation, where would this get her? She would have to return to her own people, and the further education would be of little use.

The Department is spending a large amount on the higher education of Indian children and we sometimes wonder if the value received is in any way commensurate with the expense. However, if you are still of opinion that a year or so at Brandon would be of real practical benefit, the Department might favourably consider the transfer of Martha to the Brandon School in August, next, in time for her to begin studies when the schools re-open after the summer holidays. You might let me know if you still think that Martha would get anywhere by two years' further study at Brandon. In any event, I would strongly urge you not to spend any of your own money on her education, as, by so doing, it would be likely to lead to a misunderstanding of your interest in the girl.

Yours sincerely,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Residential School,
Norway House, Man.
Feb 15, 1936.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I received your very prompt reply (noted) to the letter regarding Martha Kennedy. I appreciate your interest in the case and also your friendly advice.

Seven years does seem a long time and Indian women rarely stay unmarried after 25 yrs. age in this country, so I believe you are right in thinking the nurses training is a gamble with the odds against the Government.

I was very pleased to note that the Government might favor Martha's going but for two years to Brandon school. I suppose it is a matter
which should be talked over among the principal agent and myself. If the Government were to take on the full expense, I would feel all the more responsible if she did not show in her Record at Brandon and later on in the Reserve that the further education was of positive benefit to herself and her people.

I think stability of character is the most important factor in deciding whether a pupil should be singled out for higher education. I believe Martha will measure up in this respect.

You will probably hear more concerning the matter from Mr. Layton by later in the term.

Thanking you once more and with kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,
Walter Muto

Sir,

With reference to the final paragraph of Departmental letter No; 123-5-10 of the 2nd December, I beg to say that the reason for the delay in the receipt by the Department of the Quarterly Return of the Principal of the Norway House Residential School, was the suspension on the 8th October of the mail service to and from Norway House.

Just why the service was stopped so early we do not know. It could easily have been continued for a further 10 days at least.

The returns in question lay in the post-office here, from the 16th October until the 28th November awaiting dispatch.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby.
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith the Principal's Return for the Norway House Indian Residential School, for the quarter ending 30th June 1937, with a copy of a letter addressed to me by him, asking that certain pupils, though sixteen years of age or more, be permitted to remain at the school for another year.

After receiving the return, I had opportunity for only a few minutes talk with the Principal before he left for Winnipeg, and I spoke to him about these particular pupils, but without achieving any direct result before the boat left.

I would advocate the discharge from the school of the healthy boy pupils as soon as possible after they reach 14 years of age, in order that they may return to their fathers or guardians, and learn to earn their living. Boys cannot learn to hunt and trap and fish at school; and these are the only means they have of earning a livelihood in this country; they must of necessity learn these things from their fathers, and they will learn better at the age of 14 or 15 years than they will if they are kept at school until they are 18, because when a boy reaches 18 years of age he is not so inclined to accept discipline from his father or guardian.

I realize of course that it is necessary that a certain number of the bigger boys are required at the school, to help with the outside work in the barns and gardens, and so on, but I do not consider that all the 11 boys mentioned in the Principal's letter are needed, and I think some of them might be discharged, making way for a number of beginners. This argument does not, obviously, apply to the girl pupils.

I am forwarding the Return, rather than holding in until the Principal's return from Winnipeg; but on his return, I will further discuss this matter with him and make a further report.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr Philip Phelan's letter No; 123-5-10 of the 30th August, and in reply to say that when I communicated its contents to the Principal of The Norway House Residential School, it appears that I had misunderstood his letter to me of the 13th August, a copy of which I forwarded to the Department with my letter of the 22nd August.

With his report for the June quarter, the Principal sent a request that he be permitted to retain 11 of the older boys for another school year, which neither the Department nor I approved of, and under date of the 27th July, Mr Phelan wrote me approving the discharge of all 11 of these boys.

On receiving the Principal's letter of the 13th, August, I interpreted it as asking for the discharge of eight of these boys, whereas his meaning was, that the five boys enumerated in his letter, which were included in the 11 he asked to retain should be discharged, leaving six that he wished to keep another year.

The six boys he wishes to keep for one more school year, are as follows:

No: 216 - William Folster
    215 - Kenneth Scribe
    241 - Nathaniel Queskekapow
    247 - Ross Flett
    262 - Robinson Harper
    271 - Chillon Monias

The first three named belong to Norway House Reserve; No; 247 to God's Lake; and the last two, to Island Lake. All the above boys, with the exception of No; 247 Ross Flett, have returned to the school since the close of the summer vacation.

September 18th 1937.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Sir,

I would like to bring before you the matter of two of our boys in the School.

1st re Michael Day, No.250. He was one of the boys I asked of the Dept. to be released this year pursuant to the policy to let the boys out at a younger age that they might be with their parents. At the close of the holidays when the children came back the parents of this boy sent him back to School from Island Lake along with his younger brother.

2nd re Peter Loonfoot, No.292, also from Island Lake. As he is past 17 years of age I had intended to have him graduate with the graduating class this Treaty time. However in the spring he expressed his wish to stay in the School another year. There were two reasons for this. His younger brother was in the hospital here and likely to remain. He wished to be near him. Then he had done considerable carpenter work the past year and he desired to stay another year and learn more about the work. He talked it over with his older brother in the spring when he was here on a freighting trip, and he agreed with Peter. I advised him to go home with the rest of the children at holiday time and talk the situation over with his parents and the missionary. During the holidays his brother from the hospital was sent home, but in spite of this fact he came back at the end of the holidays and said that both he and his parents wished for him to remain at the School this year, and that the missionary advised him this as his constitution will stand carpenter work better than trapping. I will give him special training in carpenter work during the year and practical practice to make him as proficient as possible.

Would the Dept. allow these two boys to remain this year.

Yours truly,

R. T. Chapin

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No; 123-5-10 of the 2nd April, advising that proper application should be made for the admission to Treaty of Reginald Andrew James Gamlin, before making application for his admission as a pupil of the Norway House Indian Residential School.

Before making application for this boy's admission to Treaty, I think it wise to acquaint you with his status. This boy is a son of James Gamlin, a white man, and Delia Hill, who was a treaty Indian, and a daughter of Daniel Hill, #26 God's Lake Band.

Some years ago, James Gamlin secured a divorce from his wife Delia, at Brandon, Man: after which, the wife returned to the north with the children.

At the time of the granting of the divorce, the presiding judge handed down no judgement regarding the guardianship of any of the children; that is, whether the wife or the husband should have specific charge over any or all of them. When the wife returned to this country after the divorce, she brought her children with her, and gave them to certain Indians to keep for her, but in none of these instances were there any adoption papers drawn. The mother, Delia, eventually re-married, becoming the wife of Andrew Crate Jr: #653 Norway House Band, thus becoming again, a Treaty Indian. The mother died this winter.

The situation seems to me, to be that the - father -

R.A.Hoey Esq;
Spuit of Welfare & Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.;
father, James Gamlin, is still the legal guardian of his children, although so far as I know, he has done nothing to support them since the divorce. If this is the case, could his children be admitted to Treaty without his consent?

I may say that there are two other sons besides the Reginald Andrew James Gamlin mentioned in your letter, living here in Indian homes. One of these, namely Billy Gamlin, attends the Rossville Indian Day School, and since his parents' divorce, has been living with Nathaniel Queskekapow, a treaty Indian of the Norway House Band. Two years ago, Nathaniel Queskekapow asked that this boy might be admitted to treaty, but I have hesitated to make the application as he has no adoption papers for the boy, and the boy's father might, according to law, be regarded as his legal guardian.

If one of these boys were to be admitted to treaty without the consent of the father, and the father learned of it, could he take any action against the Department for taking such action without consulting him?

After the foregoing points are taken into consideration, I should be glad to receive further instruction as to making application for the admission to Treaty of Reginald Andrew James Gamlin.

Your obedient Servant,

Sioux Lookout, Ont:
Sept. 14, 1938.

The Indian Agent
Norway House, Man:

Dear Sir,

Just received your letter addressed to "James Gamlin Esq;" in care of myself.

I am returning same to you under cover. I knew Jimmie Gamlin some years ago while a clerk at the Hudson's Bay Company at Norway House, and in the summer of 1935 he was working at one of the summer camps on the Lake of the Woods and on mentioning my name to the Rev. Broughtong of Keewatin he paid his transportation across to Sioux Lookout and Jimmie arrived at the school. I had no work on hand at that time but as he was up against it I told him if he would make himself useful around the place sufficient to cover his board I would be willing for him to stay till things opened up again in the spring.

He was in communication with an Aunt I believe, who lived in Toronto and when the spring came on again I gave him sufficient money of my own to pay his transportation to Toronto. The last I saw or heard of him was on the Sioux Lookout platform at that time.

Sorry I am unable to forward his mail on but his address is absolutely unknown.

I remain

Yours faithfully

Signed: John F Marshall
(Rev) J.F.J. Marshall
Principal.
Norway House, Man:
14th November 1938.

Sir,

With further reference to Mr R.A.Hoey's letters Nos 123-5-10, dated April 2nd, and August 13th 1938, regarding the children of James Gamlin, I beg to say that I made several enquiries as to the whereabouts of James Gamlin, and the only information I was able to secure, was to the effect that he had been working at the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, Ont:

I therefore wrote to James Gamlin, in care of the Principal of this school, giving him details of the present condition of his children now living on the Norway House Reserve with Indian families, and sending him a form of agreement to sign, relinquishing all claims to these children in favour of those who had for so long been caring for them.

However, in due course, my letter to James Gamlin was returned to me unopened, by Rev Mr Marshall, the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, under cover of a letter of his own, explaining his inability to forward the letter, not knowing James Gamlin's address. I am forwarding herewith a copy of the Rev Mr Marshall's letter in the matter.

I am of the opinion, that nothing further can be done from here, to ascertain the whereabouts of James Gamlin, and that in view of his long neglect of his children; the

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.;
care these children have been given by their present Indian guardians; and the unsuccessful attempt to discover his whereabouts, there is now no reason why application should not be made for the admission of the children to treaty, and eventually to an Indian Residential School as grant earning pupils.

I shall be glad to be advised of the Department's opinion in the matter, and to receive further instructions if considered necessary.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby,

Norway House, Man:
22nd July 1939.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that the Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School has requested that the Department make an allowance of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00), to cover a part of the expense of returning the children to the school from the inland reserves after the summer holidays.

Last year the Department allowed $125.00 for this purpose, but less will be needed this year. This is mostly for rations supplied for the long canoe trips from the reserves, and none is to be used for airplane fares.

The school provided all the children with rations for their trips home to their reserves for the holidays.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources

Dear Sir,

Through you may I ask permission from the Department for the following children, who are now 16 years of age or over, to remain in School the coming school year of 1939-40.

216 Cornelius McKay
239 Henry Moore
244 Donald Balfour
249 Levi Harper
265 Lazarus Bee
266 James Crow

0256 Irene Crate
0282 Ellen Ross
0284 Isabel Sinclair
0287 Christina Beardy
0293 Priscilla McKay
0325 Ella Scribe

I have personally talked with the parents of most of these children as to what they wished for their children for the coming year. These parents expressed it as their wish for the children to remain in school another year.

Lazarus Bee was A.W.L. one year and is, with the Departments consent, staying another year to make that up.

James Crow now has no parents or relatives except a sister. He is home visiting her now and before leaving expressed it as his wish to be able to return to school for another year.

Cornelius McKay - I have not seen his father personally, but Cornelius fully expects to remain in school. He is here helping with summer work as he was with his father on the rat hunt.

Ellen Ross and Priscilla McKay - I have not seen the parents of these girls but they were expecting to return after the holidays and I have heard nothing to the contrary from their parents.

Yours truly,

NORWAY HOUSE, MAN.
January 16th 1940.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Sir,

There has been considerable delay in connection with the application forms of John Robert D'Arcis and Francis D'Arcis. The children were admitted into the School August 31st and August 24th. We had to send back to God's Lake for proper signatures. The Missionary was away through the illness of his wife. Through late mails the forms did not get back here till Christmas. The Doctor took X-ray plates of both children and sent them out to be read. The report on them, which has been satisfactory, has just come back, and the Doctor has completed the forms.

Though we have been in conjunction with you in all these details this will enumerate them.

In my December Quarterly return I have put in these children's attendance from their admittance and I hope the Department will see fit to allow us the grant for that period.

Yours truly,

R.T. Chapin

CANADA
Ottawa,
February 28, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

On checking the December quarter return of the Norway House Indian Residential School it is found that the following children are over the age of 16:

No. 0256 Irene Crate No. 239 Henry Moore
" 0282 Ellen Ross " 244 Donald Balfour

Permission was granted last year for the retention of these children in your school until June 30, 1940. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing, and the further consideration that due to conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age. Consequently unless there are some exceptional reasons the above-mentioned children should be discharged at the end of June next. If, however, there are a few of them who you consider should be retained please let me have detailed information before the end of June.

Yours truly,

Rev. R.T. Chapin,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Norway House, Man.

Norway House, Man:
13th March 1940.

Sir,

With reference to the final paragraph of Mr Philip Phelan's letter No; 123-5-10 of the 25th January last, regarding the family of Harry D'Arcis, I beg to advise you that I wrote to Mr D'Arcis asking him for the required information as to his religion, etc;

Mr D'Arcis states that he himself is Protestant, belonging to the Church of England; that his wife, (Mary Ogemow, the mother of the two children in question), belonged to the United Church of Canada, until within a week of her death, when she was converted by the Roman Catholics.

The two children have been maintained by their father, Harry D'Arcis since the death of their mother, until, owing to increasing ill health, he himself was no longer able to support them.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Norway House, Man:
5th April 1940.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith the Quarterly Return for the Norway House Indian Residential School for the quarter ending 31st March 1940.

With reference to the pupil, No; 0333, Jane Muswagon, whose discharge is asked for, I may say that this child was one of the Typhoid Fever patients, and the fever has left her lungs in an active T.B. condition.

The other pupil whose discharge is asked for, James Crow, No;266, did not manage to get back to school after holidays last year. He has no parents now, his father having died last summer, and he was unable to get transportation to Norway House when the other pupils returned. He later made an attempt to get to Norway House, but the rivers froze up ahead of his small party and they had to turn back. This boy is sixteen years of age, and I understand that he has been trapping.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby
